But from another, it becomes clear that what is falling on the child is a shower of ash. The artwork has sold for a six-figure sum to Essex-based Banksy expert John Brandler. The artwork is expected to stay in Port Talbot, at least for the time being.

Photo: Matt Cardy/Getty Images

#Banksy #Art #PortTalbot  #Wales

Taking to the house floor for the first time, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez lambasted the government shutdown, saying it's ‚Äúnot normal to shutdown the government when we don‚Äôt get what we want‚Äù. President Donald Trump triggered the shutdown after the Senate failed to approve more funding for a long-promised wall on the US-Mexico border. The shutdown is entering its 27th day and is the longest in US history. Thousands of government workers haven't received their wages with many still expected to work.

A thick sandstorm hit Cairo this week turning parts of the city orange. The Middle East has experienced a harsh weather front this week with dusty winds, rain and extremely cold weather affecting the region. Many parks and zoos in the Egyptian capital were forced to close, and the low visibility has also disrupted travel. 
Photos: Joey Shea/Twitter + Xinhua/Barcroft Images + Amr Nabil/AP + Mohamed Hossam/EPA + Khaled Elfiqi/EPA

These billboard posters featuring quotes by Theresa May and pro-Brexit politicians have popped up around Dover, Essex and north-east London as part of a campaign to remind the public of Brexit promises and predictions made by MPs. By Donkeys, the pro-remain group behind the campaign, said it was "important to remember if these people are qualified or not to take us on this Brexit journey, and in many respects it's clear they are not."

Some people are comparing this giant ice disc to the moon. It‚Äôs almost 100 metres wide, moves in a counter-clockwise direction and is currently being used as a big raft for the local ducks and birds. Scientists say the formation of ice discs is rare but natural and is caused by changing water temperatures.

Photos: Reuters + Tina Radel
#10yearchallenge

18 months ago, Gina Martin went to the police to report a man she claims took photos up her skirt at a music festival. But gaps in the law meant that the photo wasn't illegal. The experience led Martin to launch a campaign to make upskirting a sexual offence. Yesterday, her campaign paid off as the House of Lords passed legislation to make it a crime punishable by up to two years in prison. Upskirting has been covered by legislation in Scotland since 2010.

Theresa May has faced a historic defeat after MPs rejected her Brexit deal by a majority of 230. Government defeats by more than 100 votes are incredibly rare; the only ones recorded in the past century happened in 1924. So what happens next? May will face a vote of no confidence on Wednesday. Depending on the outcome, she's said she‚Äôll go back and renegotiate with the EU to avoid a no-deal Brexit. At this point everything from a general election to a second referendum could happen. Follow the link in bio for a list of potential scenarios and the likelihood of each happening.
Photo: Richard Saker

Rahaf Mohammed al-Qunun, the Saudi woman who captured the world‚Äôs attention by barricading herself in a Thai hotel room after fleeing abuse in her own country, has spoken out after being given asylum in Canada at the weekend. She was greeted on arrival by Canadian Minister of Foreign Affairs Chrystia Freeland. The 18-year-old's story quickly gathered momentum and support around the world, after she used Twitter to publicise her plight, abuse and her decision to renounce Islam. Qunun hopes her ordeal encourages other women to be "brave and free." In Saudi Arabia women are still denied basic freedoms and are not allowed to work, marry and travel without the permission of a male guardian. Canada's prime minister Justin Trudeau said Canada is a country that "understands how important it is to stand up for human rights, to stand up for women‚Äôs rights around the world." But Qunun's family have released a statement saying they have disowned her and described her as "mentally unstable." Photos: Cole Burston/Getty Images + Carlos Osorio/Reuters

Thousands of people have gathered in cities across Poland to mourn the death of Pawe≈Ç Adamowicz, who was stabbed on stage at a charity concert. Adamowicz had been mayor of Gda≈Ñsk since 1998 and was a powerful liberal voice in a country governed by the rightwing Law and Justice party since 2015. He had long been considered a hate figure in far-right circles for his vigorous defence of migrants and refugees, supporting sex education in schools and LGBT rights, but no evidence has emerged that the attack was politically motivated. 
Photos: Beata Zawrzel/REX/Shutterstock + Attila Husejnow/SOPA Images + 
Wojtek Strozyk/AP + Adam Warlawa/EPA

This is Charlie. His owner, Helena, is among a growing number of people stockpiling food, medicine and even pet treats in anticipation of mass shortages after a no-deal Brexit. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really trust the government to look after me; I certainly don‚Äôt trust them to look after my dog,‚Äù she says. An anti-Brexit Facebook group called 48% Preppers ‚Äì gets between 100 and 200 requests a day to join. Everyone wants to be ready for a no-deal Brexit. Are they overreacting, or should we be following their example? 
Tap the link in bio to read the full story. 
Photo: Gareth Phillips

#Brexit #MeaningfulVote #NoDeal #Preppers #Stockpiling

Astronomers in Canada have picked up mysterious signals from deep space for only the second time in history. Some experts suggest they could be evidence of advanced alien life. Fast radio bursts, known as FRBs, are millisecond-long pulses of radio waves generated by powerful astrophysical phenomena billions of light years outside our galaxy. It's likely that many more FRBs with even lower frequencies often travel past our planet. Astrophysicist Dr Ingrid Stairs says further technological advances will help scientists detect more of them; ‚Äúwith more repeaters and more sources available for study, we may be able to understand these cosmic puzzles, where they‚Äôre from and what causes them.‚Äù Photo: Keith Vanderlinde/Dunlap institute

Plastic has become perhaps the most demonised material of the last 12 months. More than 8m tonnes of plastic end up in our oceans each year, while it's estimated that there will be more plastic in the seas by weight than fish by 2050. We cannot recycle our way out of the plastic problem. Here‚Äôs a few tips on how to reduce your own plastic footprint.

Chhaupadi, the practice of banishing girls and women to a hut or shed when they have their periods, has been illegal since 2005 in Nepal. Despite the ban, reports emerge each year of women dying in huts from snake bites, smoke inhalation or fire. Only this week, a woman and her two sons suffocated to death in a windowless hut while practising chhaupadi in the country‚Äôs Bajura district. Today, local authorities have announced tougher measures including the withdrawal of state food support on anyone imposing the practice. Forcing a menstruating woman into a ‚Äúperiod hut‚Äù is also now punishable with three months in prison and a 3,000 rupee (¬£33) fine.

Photo: Narendra Shrestha/EPA

Today, for the first time ever, the Guardian's print edition will be packaged in a biodegradable wrap, replacing the current polythene wrapping. The wrap is made of entirely compostable material and can be disposed of on a compost heap or in your garden or food waste bin. Though the change will increase production costs, we are committed to reducing plastic waste, following feedback from you, our readers. The change will roll out across the UK over the coming months, starting this weekend for readers in London, Kent, Essex, Hertfordshire, Norfolk and Suffolk. #sustainableliving

A town in Newfoundland, Canada has asked the federal government to help tackle an invasion of seals. Around 40 harp seals became stranded in Roddickton after they came ashore just before the water froze behind them. The mayor says the hungry and tired mammals are crying out, and may be too disorientated to find their way back to the ocean. Residents are unable to move them because it's illegal to touch marine mammals. While two of the animals have been killed, possibly struck by vehicles, federal fisheries officers say some seals have now been removed, and they are assessing the health of others.

Photos: The Globe and Mail + Mack Lamoureux + Brendon FitzPatrick + Donny Dooley via Twitter

Andy Murray‚Äôs tennis career is all but over. He expects his match against Roberto Bautista Agut in the first round of the Australian Open on Monday to be his last but, even if another hip operation were to help him reach a more emotional and perhaps more fitting farewell at Wimbledon, it will never be the same for the player who stood alongside Fred Perry as the greatest Britain has ever had. Via @guardian_sport

[Swipe for full effect] 
When you look up at the full moon, you only ever see one face, but scientists believe that the far side, eternally hidden from view, may hold the key to fundamental mysteries about the moon‚Äôs formation. Last week, a Chinese spacecraft made history by becoming the first to land on the far side of the moon. Today, China shared pictures showing a rocky surface with the jagged edges of craters in the background. Among the images is this 360-degree panorama stitched together from 80 photos. Researchers hope that low-frequency observations of the cosmos from the far side of the moon, where radio signals from Earth are blocked, will help scientists learn more about the early days of the solar system and the birth of the universe‚Äôs first stars. The pioneering landing also highlights China‚Äôs ambitions to rival the US, Russia and Europe with its space programme.
Photo: CNSA

One byproduct of the new golden age of TV and podcasting is an increased workload for police detectives asked to re-examine their files after new evidence emerges on the small screen. Since Surviving R Kelly aired on US TV, demonstrators have been calling for a boycott of his music after the documentary series raised claims of mental, physical and sexual abuse against young girls. Prosecutors in Illinois and Georgia are seeking new information from potential victims of the R&B singer, who have not yet come forward. Kelly and his lawyers continue to deny any wrongdoing. 
Photos: Scott Olson/Getty Images + Ashlee Rezin/AP + Joshua Lott/Reuters

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has criticised conservative media for its treatment of women in leadership positions after the Daily Caller published a fake photo of her nude in a bath. The image was quickly dismissed as fake by a Reddit user. @ocasio2018 said that the use of a discredited image by a prominent conservative outlet proves that women in leadership face more scrutiny. She also criticised the Daily Mail which she accused of sending a reporter to her boyfriend‚Äôs relative‚Äôs homes offering cash for stories.

Photo: William B. Plowman/NBC NewsWire via Getty Images

Imelda Cortez faced 20 years in prison after giving birth to the baby of the man who raped her. Today, a judge will formalise the decision to free her. El Salvador has a total ban on abortion, and the law is applied brutally. Cortez, 20, had been abused by her stepfather since the age of 12. Because she hadn‚Äôt told anyone about the pregnancy or sought medical attention, prosecutors argued she had attempted to murder her child. Hailed as a precedent-setting ruling, her case has given hope to women in central America and has shown that pressure from international reproductive rights groups can have an impact. 
Search ‚ÄòToday in Focus‚Äô on your podcast player to hear more about Cortez's story.

Joshua Tree national park has been forced to close after vandalism to its distinctive namesake plants. A skeleton staff and volunteers have attempted to maintain the attraction over the 18-day US government shutdown, but found themselves overwhelmed by visitors and sanitation issues. The park's iconic landscape is fragile and could take generations to grow back, officials said. With just eight rangers left to oversee the 800,000 acre park, the gates will likely remain closed until the shutdown ends.
Will the government's new 10-year plan for the NHS be enough to save it after years of cuts and unprecedented demand? Take a look at our explainer to find out.

A Dutch approach to transforming old homes through a dramatic green makeover has arrived in the UK. The "Energiesprong" (energy leap) initiative aims to radically upgrade the efficiency of homes by reducing energy bills by 50 per cent and also reducing carbon dioxide emissions. More than 150 social housing homes will receive cladding and solar panels, and similar projects are planned in Essex and Exeter, but a no-deal Brexit could jeopardise the future of Energiesprong in the UK. 
Photo: Energiesprong International/IET

This mural has popped up in Paris against the backdrop of the gilets jaunes protests. Street artist PBOY was inspired by Eug√®ne Delacroix's famous painting Liberty Leading the People, which commemorates the second French Revolution of 1830. France's yellow vest protesters have taken to the streets for eight successive weekends, with an estimated 25,000 across the country joining the last protest on Saturday 5 January. The demonstrations began in November to oppose fuel tax rises, but the movement has since grown to encompass wider grievances against President Emmanuel Macron and his centrist government.

Photo: Philippe Lopez/AFP

Sesame Street characters are helping some of the world‚Äôs most vulnerable children to learn through play. The Sesame Workshop initiative aims to counter the effects of trauma and displacement among Syrian and Rohingya refugee children, while developing the skills to build a brighter future for themselves in the process. Although half of the world‚Äôs 25 million refugees are children, less than 3 per cent of the global humanitarian aid budget is currently dedicated to education. In December, Sesame Workshop was awarded a $100m grant by the LEGO Foundation to expand its activities.

This is a 'bee brick'. Wildlife enthusiast Adam Cormack added it to the side of his house six months ago and recently discovered that bees have been moving in. He's not the only one; people have started fitting these bricks into walls to give solitary bees somewhere to live and create nests. Solitary bees aren't aggressive and don't live in hives or produce honey. Their numbers have declined in recent years and one of the reasons is loss of their natural habitat. Some people have criticised the idea of housing bees within the structure of a building and insist more should be done to preserve their natural habitat in the wild. 
Photos: Adam Cormack via Twitter + @greenandblueuk + @nonsuchtony + @lesleyawilliams

@CarolineLucasmp has called for a meat tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and help farmers with more sustainable agriculture schemes. "if the world's diet doesn't change, we simply can't avoid the worst effects of climate change," she said during a speech at the Oxford Farming Conference, an annual gathering of farmers from across the UK. Globally, livestock rearing is estimated to be responsible for about 15% of greenhouse gas emissions. Lucas' statement coincides with the push for people to try a vegan diet for a month (AKA ‚ÄúVeganuary‚Äù). Photo: Kevin Button/Getty Images

In an attempt to recruit young people, the British army is calling on ‚Äòsnowflakes, selfie addicts, class clowns, phone zombies, and me, me, millennials‚Äô. They say the campaign is aimed at 16-25 year olds, part of what is known as Generation Z, and suggests that what is seen as a weakness or a character flaw by the rest of society can be seen as a strength by the army. Major General Paul Nanson says it shows that the army looks beyond stereotypes and recognises people's ‚Äúneed for a bigger sense of purpose‚Äù. But critics on social media say the posters seem to insult the demographic it is trying to target. The design is based on the historic Your Country Needs You first world war poster featuring Field Marshal Lord Kitchener.

A series of photos by @straydreams highlights the stigma still attached to tattoos in Japan. The country's ban on tattoos was lifted in 1948, but suspicion and their association with criminality continues. As Japan prepares to host the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo, people with tattoos are still being refused entry to public swimming pools, beaches and often gyms. Tattoo artists have faced legal battles and having visible body ink can also be harmful to job prospects.

Photos: Behrouz Mehri/AFP/Getty Images

The founder of the left wing Aufstehen (Get Up) movement has said it will take to the streets in 2019, inspired by the gilet jaunes protests in France. Sahra Wagenknecht says growing inequality in Germany, and frustration over the government‚Äôs failure to adequately tackle it, was a powerful motivating force for setting up the protest movement last year. Aufstehen has almost 170,000 signed-up members, and supporters include famous Germant writers, political scientists, historians and actors. Wagenknecht hopes to galvanise support from ordinary voters across the political spectrum and unite Germany‚Äôs left wing parties, who are struggling in the polls, in a common front against the social problems affecting the whole of Europe. But critics within her own party Die Linke say she risks destroying it completely.

Photo: Michael Sohn/AP

Women formed a 620km human chain for gender equality in Kerala, India. Organisers estimate that three million women protested a ban on women of menstruating age approaching the Hindu Sabarimala temple. The deity Lord Ayyappa is celibate, so traditionalists believe women under 50 should not enter the temple to offer prayers for fear that they could ‚Äútempt‚Äù him. Despite India's supreme court overturning the ban in 2018, some were denied entry to one of Hinduism's holiest temples by conservative protestors. The "women's wall" protest was organised by the left-wing government in the southern Indian state to make a stand against discrimination.
Photos: T Sudheesh via Twitter + AFP/Getty Images + Prakash Elamakkara/EPA
As we enter 2019, it‚Äôs worth remembering that 2018 wasn‚Äôt all bad. Here's to more uplifting stories like these in the next 12 months.
What are your hopes for #2019?

Happy New Year ... from London, Edinburgh, Rotterdam, Sydney, Athens, Hong Kong, Malaysia & South Korea.

Photos: Kirsty Wigglesworth/AP + Victoria Jones/PA + Brook Mitchell/Getty Images + Brett Hemmings/City of Sydney/Getty Images + Raminder Pal Singh/ EPA +Mohd Samsul Mohd Said/Getty Images + Fazry Ismail/EPA + Alkis Konstantinidis/Reuters + Robin Utrecht/AFP/Getty Images +
Andrew Milligan/PA

It‚Äôs been another unrelenting and dramatic year for news, and there is perhaps no clearer demonstration of this than the range of stunning, uplifting and devastating images the world‚Äôs photographers have been capturing. Here are some of our favourites, with a brief quote on each by the person who took it.

Photos: Andalou/Getty, Getty, Reuters, Getty, Getty

With the 29 March deadline just three months away, will 2019 really be the year Britain exits the European Union? One thing that 2018 taught us is that the divisions opened up by the 2016 referendum have not healed, but hardened, splitting the country into two camps: leavers and remainers. Protesters have often clashed outside the Houses of Parliament. The only thing the two groups share is pessimism about the way Brexit is currently being handled. #ThisWas2018

Photos: Richard Isaac + Matt Dunham + Amer Ghazzal + Justin Griffiths-Williams + Mark Duffy + Harry Lloyd-Evans + Finbarr Webster+ Henry Nicholls + Gareth Fuller

Leading climate scientists have warned that we have 12 years to prevent global warming from exceeding 1.5C. The world remains on track for 3C warming, which scientists say will bring more catastrophic, extreme weather. Rightwing nationalism is damaging the global solidarity needed to avoid this catastrophe. Both the US and Brazil are led by climate-change deniers, while European leaders like Emmanuel Macron, Theresa May and Angela Merkel have been distracted by pressing domestic politics. But public opinion is way ahead of national politics, with more than 80% of Americans believing that climate change is happening. Civil society groups have pledged growing international protests next year to drive action on global warming and the recent school strikes in Australia, which started out as a solo protest by Swedish 15-year-old @gretathunberg back in August, show that there is a rising tide of protest among young people. Addressing the UN climate summit in Poland, Thunberg said: ‚ÄúIf children can get headlines all over the world just by not going to school, then imagine what we could all do together if we really wanted to." #ThisWas2018

Photos: @taylorti.a + Paul J Richards + Tt News Agency + Guy Bell

Psychologist Dr Christine Blasey Ford delivered one of the most powerful testimonies in the #MeToo era when she accused supreme court justice Brett Kavanaugh of sexual assault. She was made to relive a moment that she said "drastically altered" her life, when delivering her testimony in front of a Senate judiciary committee consisting of 17 male and four female senators. Ford accused Kavanaugh of trying to rape her at a high school party some 30 years ago. Kavanaugh, who testified after her, forcefully denied the allegation. He was ultimately confirmed in a 50 to 48 vote, with Republicans supporting Donald Trump's pick despite extensive opposition. His nomination inflamed a deep cultural divide in today‚Äôs era of reckoning on sexual assault and harassment. Ford and her family became the target of death threats, prompting the launch of a GoFundMe page to cover their $150,000 security costs. She recently shut down the page after raising nearly $650,000, and has pledged to donate all unused funds to charities that support trauma survivors. #ThisWas2018

Photos: Win McNamee/ Getty Images + Melina Mara-Pool/Getty Images

It's been a mixed year for LGBT rights around the world. In Australia, more than 3,000 same-sex couples married in the first half of 2018, after same-sex marriage was legalised in December. While Jared Polis became the first openly gay man elected governor during the recent US midterms, Donald Trump's government continues to reverse gains made by the LGBT community, withdrawing federal protections for transgender students and banning transgender people from serving in the military. With self-proclaimed "proud homophobe" Jair Bolsonaro declared Brazil‚Äôs next president, there are fears attacks on the community will continue in a country where violent deaths of LGBT people hit an all-time high in 2017. There was also disappointment in Romania, Hong Kong and Taiwan where motions to legalise same-sex unions were unsuccessful. However, India delivered big news this September when its supreme court finally overruled a colonial-era law that banned homosexual acts. 
Photos: Kin Cheung/AP + Patrick Hamilton/AFP/Getty Images + Kena Betancur/Getty Images + Michael N/Pacific/BarcroftImages + NurPhoto via Getty Images + Indranil Mukherjee/AFP/Getty Images + Arun Sankar/AFP/Getty Images

US gymnasts led the way in an exceptional year for female pioneers of sport, with Aly Raisman among the women who testified against Larry Nassar, who pleaded guilty to sexual assault charges. Their courage to speak out gave sport its #MeToo moment. The controversy over Serena Williams‚Äô catsuit during the French Open brought sexism in sport into sharp focus. The full-length outfit was designed to protect against blood clots, which Williams suffered from after the birth of her daughter. This didn‚Äôt stop the French Tennis Federation‚Äôs president from banning the catsuit and declaring that "one must respect the game and the place." Not long after, Alize Cornet was penalised at the US Open for fixing her back-to-front top, something male tennis players do regularly, while @ahegerberg was asked to twerk on stage moments after becoming the first female footballer to win the Ballon d'Or prize. While female football fans in Iran were allowed to cheer on the men's football team during the World Cup, the head of the country‚Äôs judiciary said women should be banned from stadiums as it was ‚Äúsinful‚Äù for them to watch ‚Äúhalf-naked men play soccer‚Äù. #ThisWas2018

Photos: Larry Marano + Christophe Simon + Christophe Ena + Alexander Demianchuk + Atta Kenare

There were joyous scenes in Ireland in May as a landslide majority voted to legalise abortion, marking a dramatic defeat for the Catholic church's one-time domination of the Republic. Nearly two in three Irish voters chose to repeal the eighth amendment, which made it illegal for a woman to have an abortion apart from circumstances where her life was at risk. 66.4% voted ‚Äòyes‚Äô, defying opinion polls that suggested the election would be too close to call. Tributes were also paid to Savita Halappanavar, who became the symbol of the Yes campaign. She died aged 32 due to complications following a septic miscarriage in Galway in 2012. #ThisWas2018

Photos: Clodagh Kilcoyne + Paul Faith + Charles McQuillan + Niall Carson + Aidan Crawley

Almost 18 million people in Britain tuned in to watch the Duke and Duchess of Sussex tie the knot on Saturday 19 May. Meghan‚Äôs African-American roots were honoured throughout the service, which featured gospel music and Bishop Michael Curry who became a social media hit with his passionate address on the power of love, referencing Martin Luther King and the resilience of faith during slavery. Critics of the monarchy, however, pointed out that taxpayers shouldn‚Äôt have to foot the event‚Äôs security bill, which came to a total of ¬£3.4m. Guardian journalist Gary Younge also weighed in, arguing that ‚Äúthe purpose of these highly scripted and tightly choreographed weddings is twofold: to renew the monarchy‚Äôs sense of legitimacy and to establish its relevance.‚Äù #ThisWas2018

Photos: Alexi Lubomirski/PA + Owen Humphreys + Oli Scarff/AFP/Getty Images + Ben Birchall/PA

After months of Guardian reportage exposing shocking cases of people wrongly targeted by the government‚Äôs ‚Äúhostile environment‚Äù policies, the Windrush scandal finally hit the headlines in April. The outcry led to home secretary Amber Rudd resigning, admitting her office had ‚Äúlost sight of individuals‚Äù and become ‚Äútoo concerned with policy.‚Äù The Windrush generation arrived from Caribbean countries after the second world war at the invitation of the British government. Until recently, an estimated 50,000 of them faced the risk of deportation if they hadn't formalised their residency status or didn't have the required documentation to prove it. Many people lost their jobs and were even held in detention centres. The Windrush scandal led to significant changes in the immigration system, with controversial checks on immigrants‚Äô bank accounts and NHS data suspended. #ThisWas2018

Photos: Alicia Canter + Corbis via Getty Images + Haywood Magee + James Shaw + David Levene + Christopher Thomond + Martin Godwin + Tophams + SSPL via Getty Images + Sarah Lee

March was the month of the explosive data breach scandal. Whistleblowers Chris Wylie and Shahmir Sanni revealed how Cambridge Analytica, the data analytics firm that was behind Trump‚Äôs 2016 campaign and played a role in Brexit, had used the data harvested from 87 million Facebook users without their consent. The Observer and The Guardian investigation led to the downfall of Cambridge Analytica and a public apology from Facebook‚Äôs Mark Zuckerberg who was forced to testify before congress. ‚ÄúWe exploited Facebook to harvest millions of people‚Äôs profiles," Wylie said. "And built models to exploit what we knew about them and target their inner demons. That was the basis the entire company was built on.‚Äù Facebook has since lost $120 billion from its share price. #ThisWas2018

Photos: Neil Hall/ EPA + Wiktor Szymanowicz/REX/Shutterstock + Al Drago + Getty Images

The Queen's Christmas Day speech, delivered next to an extravagant golden piano, was widely criticised on social media for being insensitive towards people struggling to make ends meet in the UK, where more than 14 million people, including 4.5 million children, are living below the breadline. The Queen used her speech to call for people to "come together" and not to be "riven by tribalism." Earlier this month, Emmanuel Macron received similar criticism for speaking about social inequality from behind a gold desk during recent anti-government protests in France. The former banker said he wasn't an arrogant "president of the rich" and that he understood ordinary French people's struggles.

Photos: John Stillwell/Getty Images + Ludovic Marin/EPA

February saw another devastating US school shooting when 17 people were killed by a gunman at Marjory Stoneman Douglas high school in Parkland, Florida. In a bid to end America‚Äôs gun violence epidemic, survivors campaigned tirelessly throughout the year for stricter gun control. Hundreds of thousands of students joined the pro-gun control #MarchForOurLives rallies across the US in one of the largest expressions of popular opposition in the modern era. Despite months of tireless campaigning ahead of the midterm elections in November, student activists were left frustrated as Florida selected pro-gun candidates in both the governor and US Senate races. But with Democrats taking control of the House, there is hope progress will be made on an issue that continues to bitterly divide America. #ThisWas2018 
Photos: Chip Somodevilla + Mark Wilson +Zach Gibson + Aaron P. Bernstein + Larry Marano

You‚Äôd be forgiven for feeling like 2018 was a bit of a blur; a lot has happened over the past 12 months, so to help gain some clarity, we‚Äôll be revisiting moments that had an impact on our world. Let‚Äôs start with the @timesupnow protest at the Golden Globes, where 300 women turned up in black to protest sexual harassment in US workplaces. The campaign was launched as a companion to the #MeToo movement and has raised more than $20m in legal defence funds primarily used to fight sexual misconduct cases brought by low-paid workers. The fund's co-founder, Roberta Kaplan, said the movement as a whole is encouraging thousands of women to ‚Äúcome out‚Äù as victims of misconduct. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs revolutionary and it‚Äôs not going to go back. I can‚Äôt see women agreeing to return to the days of isolation and shame.‚Äù #ThisWas2018

Photos: Frazer Harrison + Matthias Nareyek + Jonny Birch + Mario Anzuoni + Stephane Cardinale + Paul Sancya + Spencer Platt

The US government has been partially shut down since Friday after Democrats refused Trump's demands to allocate $5bn in funding for his long-promised wall on the US-Mexico border. Amidst the Washington showdown, Texas congressman Beto O'Rourke turned to his followers and asked them to share photos of landmarks that would be threatened by the wall. O'Rourke fears the wall will disrupt local communities and habitats, and destroy local ranches and farms. From the Santa Elena Canyon to the Big Bend National Park, it seems many have the same fears as O'Rourke - that a border wall will damage the wilderness and tranquility on both sides. 
Photos: Beto O'Rourke + Sarah M Vasquez + Cassie + Gage Brown + rosieg2m + Grayson Ridge + Laura Thoms via Twitter

At least 281 people lost their lives as a tsunami in Indonesia struck on the islands of Java and Sumatra without warning. Experts have confirmed it was caused by a chunk of the volcanic Anak Krakatau island slipping into the Indian Ocean. The fact it was triggered by a volcano rather than an earthquake meant no tsunami warning was triggered. The death toll is expected to rise, with 57 people still missing. There's also a chance the region will be affected by more deadly waves. Indonesia's natural disaster agency says it needs to develop a new early warning system for tsunamis. 
Photos: Antara Foto/Reuters + Fauzy Chaniago/AP + Tatan Syuflana/AP +Adi Weda/EPA + Jorge Silva/Reuters

This is the Korolev crater in the northern lowlands of Mars. It‚Äôs 50 miles wide and contains 530 cubic miles of ice, kept chilled by a trapped layer of cold Martian air. The stunning image was captured by the European Space Agency‚Äôs Mars Express probe, which first reached the planet on Christmas Day in 2003. In July, the probe discovered what astronomers believe to be a stretch of water beneath the planet‚Äôs surface.

Home Secretary Sajid Javid released the long-awaited Immigration White Paper on Wednesday. It sets out the government's vision for Britain's immigration policy after Brexit, ending freedom of movement and reducing the cap on skilled migrants from outside EU countries. Provisions like the proposed ¬£30,000 minimum salary have proved controversial, with critics warning it would devastate the NHS and farming.

Meet the Breunion Boys ‚Äì the Dutch boyband who want to stop Brexit. The five-member Breunion Boys, formed by artist Julia Veldman, have launched their first single Britain Come Back. The song partly blames Brussels for not fully appreciating the UK as an EU partner. Taking inspiration from British boy bands like Take That, Veldman spent a year auditioning dancers and singers who also had strong feelings about Britain's relationship with the EU. She says they haven't received any funding from the EU or political parties. The band hopes to tour British pubs before the 29 March departure date to get their message across.

A Tokyo-based news agency has claimed Japan is planning to resume commercial whaling next year and withdraw from the International Whaling Commission. The move has already drawn condemnation from Australia, with other anti-whaling nations expected to follow. Commercial whaling was banned by the IWC in 1986, when some whale species were driven to near extinction. The Japanese government is expected to justify their move by arguing that these species have now recovered sufficiently in the last 30 years. A fisheries agency official denied the news agency's report, and insisted that while they want to resume commercial whaling as soon as possible, no decision has been made on whether to withdraw from the IWC. Officials in Japan argue that whale meat is part of their culture. The country has also hunted whales for many years for scientific research.

Photo: Fernando Castillo/AFP/Getty Images

A charity in London has introduced sleeping pods to give homeless people privacy while they stay at the shelter. The pods cost ¬£700 each and provide a raised mattress as well as storage space for personal items. Tim Fallon, chief executive of the 999 Club shelter, said: ‚ÄúIf you get 20 to 30 people sleeping here it can be hard to get privacy ‚Äì and a big problem for people is snoring. The pods offer a little bit more security.‚Äù Between July and September this year, there were 3,103 people on the streets of London, which is the first time the number has ever exceeded 3,000 in a three-month period.

Could this mural on a garage in Port Talbot, Wales be the work of street artist Banksy? People have been flocking to see the artwork of a child standing in what looks like snow, but is actually ash from a fire. It's similar in style to Banksy's previous work, but has yet to be officially confirmed as one of his.

Photos: Andyj07 + Sue Charles via Twitter

A new report on femicide reveals that 76% of women killed by men in the UK last year knew their killer. The Femicide Census, organised by @womens_aid and campaigner @kareningalasmith, also found that 46% of the victims were killed by a current or former intimate partner, 17% by a man known to them and 12% by a male family member. Katie Ghose, the chief executive of Women's Aid, has called on the government to ensure its new domestic abuse bill delivers both the legislation and resources needed to tackle the issue.

Photo: Mark Kerrison/Alamy

The Ice Hotel in Swedish Lapland has opened its doors again for the 29th time. 34 artists from 13 countries have designed the hotel suites out of snow and ice over the last 12 weeks. The building process started back in March, with 2,500 tons of ice collected from the river Torne. It is then stored until October. This year some of the suites have been inspired by environmental issues like climate change and overfishing which is affecting the oceans. 
Photos: Asaf Kliger

After her surprise victory in this autumn's general election, @leilaelmi has promised to be a voice for immigrants and those affected by Sweden's swing to the far-right. Ali Elmi arrived in Sweden aged two after fleeing civil war in Somalia. As a councillor for the Green Party, she has campaigned for social justice and feminism. She said the only people who weren't surprised by her win were those who know that the Swedish suburbs needs a voice: "I speak for the suburb, not about it or to it. If you haven't lived there or spent a day in those people‚Äôs shoes, you cannot represent them.‚Äù Photo: Fredrik Hjerling

An American poacher was recently given a special addition to his sentence for illegally killing hundreds of deer in the midwestern state of Missouri. As well as a year-long jail term, the man was ordered by the court to watch the Disney classic Bambi at least once a month while in prison. Conservation agents have called it one of the largest deer poaching cases in the state's history.

Photo: Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images

American dictionary @merriamwebster has chosen 'justice' as its word of the year. Explaining the reason for why the word was selected, they said the concept of justice was at the heart of key debates including racial, social, criminal and economic justice. The word was looked up 74% more than in 2017. Oxford Dictionaries chose "toxic" as its word of the year, while Dictionary.com went with "misinformation".

Female photographers have taken portraits of the UK's 209 female MPs to celebrate 100 years since the first election in which some women were allowed to vote. Labour MP Tracy Brabin, who won the 2016 Batley and Spen by-election after the murder of Jo Cox, has praised the @209women project for tipping the scales of women's representation in parliament. "The photos are impressive and in some cases deeply affecting. This expression of our right to be in this place is a powerful and political act." Photos: Carol Sharp + Hannah Starkey + Rachel Louise Brown + Tereza ƒåerve≈àov√° + Polly Penrose + Julia Fullerton-Batten + Jooney Woodward + Sarah Lee

50 murals of inspiring women from history have been unveiled across London to mark the 100th anniversary of the first election in which some women were able to vote. @scarcurtis and @herstory_uk created the murals to engage people of all genders with women's history. "I believe there's a profound link between looking back and seeing the women who have come before and looking forward into our own feminist futures", @alice_wroe explained.

Photos: @maurawilding + @scarcurtis + @penguinplatform

Gordon Brown has called for a better tax and benefit system to tackle child poverty in the UK. With 5 million children expected to be living in poverty by 2022, the former prime minister says the current government's universal credit system is underfunded, and the minimum wage doesn't pay enough. Brown was visiting a family centre in Kirkcaldy, his old constituency, where some of the most deprived estates in Scotland are located. When the centre launched its first Christmas appeal in 2010, it assisted 80 families. This year 1,200 families will be seeking their help.

Japan has chosen the kanji character for "disaster" as its defining symbol of the year, after being hit by a devastating earthquake, typhoon, heatwaves and flooding in 2018. Following a public vote, television stations broadcast the announcement live as the master of an ancient temple in Kyoto wrote the winning term on a white panel. The symbol, which can be pronounced ‚Äúsai‚Äù, won almost 21,000 votes. Kanji are used widely in Japanese and other alphabets.

Photo: Jiji Press/EPA

Search and rescue ship Aquarius, which has saved tens of thousands of migrants from drowning, has been forced to end its operations this month. M√©decins Sans Fronti√®res, the charity that runs the ship, said it was forced to terminate operations because of a ‚Äúsmear campaign‚Äù by European governments. In November, Italian magistrates accused MSF of illegally dumping toxic waste at ports in southern Italy. The charity denied any wrongdoing and accused Italy of seeking to criminalise humanitarian search-and-rescue missions. Aquarius was the last charity ship operating off of Libya since 2016. According to the UN, more than 2,000 people fleeing war and poverty have drowned this year while trying to cross the Mediterranean. 
Photos: Nicol√≥ Lanfranchi + Jean-Paul P√©lissier/Reuters

Adverts showing a woman struggling to park a car or a man refusing to do housework while his wife cooks dinner will be banned from next year as part of an industry-wide crackdown on sexist stereotypes. Under the new rules, British companies won't be able to create promotions depicting men and women engaged in gender-stereotypical activities. The rules will also ban adverts that suggest that transforming your body will make you romantically successful, while also clarifying rules on the sexualisation of young women. People will be able to report adverts to the regulator if they feel they breach the code. Ella Smillie from the Advertising Standards Authority said: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt see ourselves as social engineers, we‚Äôre reflecting the changing standards in society. We know advertising can reinforce harmful gender stereotypes, which can limit people‚Äôs choices or potential in life.‚Äù

24 large blocks of centuries-old ice harvested from the Nuup Kangerlua fjord in Greenland are currently melting outside the Tate Modern in London. Ice Watch London, an art installation by artist Olafur Eliasson and geologist Minik Rosing, are trying to bring the effects of climate change closer to home by letting people touch, smell and even lick the icebergs. They want to highlight the chilling fact that 10,000 blocks of ice such as the ones on display in London are falling from the ice sheet every single second.

Photos: David Levene + EPA + Daniel Leal-Olivas

We're interrupting our Brexit coverage to bring you a story about chaos and the chocolate factory. This street in a western German town got a repaving worthy of Willy Wonka when a tonne of chocolate flowed out of a factory and solidified on the pavement. About 25 firefighters armed with hot water and shovels had to clean the scene up. They also used hot water and torches to remove remaining bits from cracks and holes.

Photo: Reuters

Time magazine has paid tribute to journalists who have risked their lives in pursuit of the truth. More than two months since Khashoggi‚Äôs disappearance, Saudi Arabia is still facing international condemnation over his brutal murder and alleged dismemberment at the hands of a Saudi hit team. Maria Ressa helped found Rappler, a Philippines news site known for reporting on President Rodrigo Duterte‚Äôs extrajudicial killings. The Capital Gazette team in Annapolis, Maryland was targeted by a gunman leaving five of their colleagues dead. The shooting made the US the fourth deadliest country in the world to be a journalist in 2018, tied with Mexico. Finally, Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo are currently imprisoned in Myanmar for investigating crimes committed against Rohingya Muslims; their wives feature on the cover.

48 Conservative MPs ‚Äì representing 15% of the parliamentary party ‚Äì have backed a confidence vote in Theresa May in an attempt to trigger a leadership contest. The vote will take place this evening between 6-8pm. 158 MPs would need to vote against her for this to work. If she defeats her critics, they would need to wait another year before they can challenge her again. It's going to be a long day, so if you're keen to stay on top of developments follow the link in bio for our live blog.

In response to the gilets jaunes (yellow vests) protests, President Emmanuel Macron has addressed the people of France on primetime television. While promising an increase in the minimum wage and cancelling a planned tax on pensions, he also said he understood the protesters‚Äô anger and indignation, which he said was ‚Äúdeep and in many ways legitimate‚Äù. But Macron also added ‚Äúno anger justifies attacking a police officer, a gendarme, or damaging a shop or public building. When violence is unleashed, freedom ends.‚Äù Despite Macron's speech, the protests have continued across France. Many demonstrators say the president's concessions are not enough to calm their anger and sense of social injustice. Further demonstrations are expected in Paris on Saturday. 
Photos: Zakaria Abdelkafi/Reuters + St√©phane Mah√©/Reuters + Pascal Guyot/AFP/Getty Images

The latest Brexit chaos explained: After listening to MPs' concerns about her Brexit deal, Theresa May realised too many of them objected to proposals for the insurance policy to prevent a hard Irish border. So May delayed the vote on the deal and said she would seek changes from the EU to please MPs. Critics, however, will argue she is mainly delaying it in the hope that something will come up and save her from a defeat that could end her career. Labour leader @JeremyCorbyn said the government had ‚Äúlost control of events and is in complete disarray‚Äù. He's come under pressure from the Scottish National Party and some of his own MPs to press ahead with a no-confidence motion in the prime minister and push for a second EU referendum. A Labour statement said the party planned a no-confidence motion ‚Äúwhen we judge it most likely to be successful‚Äù, seemingly when May presents her plan to the Commons again.

We've launched a six-month investigative series exploring who the new populists are, what factors brought them to power and what they're doing once they're in office. Follow the link in bio to find out more.

Nadia Murad and Denis Mukwege received the 2018 Nobel peace prize today for their efforts to end the use of sexual violence as a weapon of war and armed conflict. Murad is a Yazidi rights activist from northern Iraq and a survivor of sexual slavery. Mukwege has been operating on thousands of women and girls that have survived sexual violence in the DRC. In her acceptance speech, Murad said "thank you for the honour you bestowed on me, but no prize in the world can restore our dignity other than justice." Photo: Reuters/AFP

After receiving alleged racist abuse during a football match at the weekend, England and Manchester City player Raheem Sterling has accused some sections of the media of helping to "fuel racism" with their portrayal of young black players. Responding on Instagram, @sterling7 said he wasn't surprised by the abuse. He shared two stories published by MailOnline suggesting that young black players are portrayed differently to white players. The incident at Stamford Bridge came a week after a Spurs supporter was arrested for throwing a banana skin at Arsenal's Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang during the north London derby. Anti-discrimination charity @kickitout called it ‚Äúyet another great day of football damaged by prejudice." Follow @guardian_sport for more.

Photo: Jed Leicester/BPI/REX/Shutterstock

For some people, hostility is an everyday experience. Groups like the Windrush generation have been denied basic human rights. Paulette, pictured here with her daughter, was detained and threatened with deportation, despite having lived in the UK for 49 years. The Refugee and Migrant Centre achieved justice for her in the end and continues to stand up for many more in her position. This year's Guardian and Observer charity appeal will help charities like the RMC bring fairness, justice and dignity to vulnerable British citizens and migrants. Tap the link in bio to see how you can join the fight against #everydayhostility.

An investigation has found evidence of excessive and illegal overtime, basic pay rates as low as 85p an hour, no holiday or sick pay and high levels of exhaustion among the largely female workforce making toys for Disney, Mattel‚Äôs Fisher Price brand and other toy companies. The investigation found that, when costs were broken down, each of the women on the production line was receiving just 1p for every doll produced. Many of the biggest toy makers ‚Äì including Disney and Mattel ‚Äì are members of the International Council of Toy Industries Ethical Toy Program, which sets out expected industry standards to improve working conditions in factories. A spokesman from the council said: ‚ÄúWe take the issues raised (...) very seriously and have launched our own investigation. We will quickly and effectively address any issues identified which are in breach of our standards.‚Äù

Cuba is one of the last countries that hasn't rolled out full internet access on mobile devices. That changes today. Still, there are concerns many people won't be able to afford it. Nearly half of Cuba's population own mobile phones, but with the average state wage around ¬£23 ($30) a month, even the cheapest ¬£5 ($7) monthly internet packages will be too expensive.

A duet between two of the biggest pop stars has sparked a debate about gender standards. Beyonc√© and Ed Sheeran performed together at the Global Citizen festival in Johannesburg, South Africa. Sheeran was dressed in a casual outfit while Beyonc√© wore an extravagant couture dress. People are arguing it's a perfect example of how the baseline for what's acceptably attractive requires so much more effort for women than it does for men. Do you think this image represents a larger truth about gender norms?

Hundreds of red shoes have been left at Habima Square in Tel Aviv, Israel in protest against the government's lack of action on domestic violence. At least 24 women have been killed in Israel this year as a result of domestic abuse and most of the victims had told the police they feared for their safety. Israel's prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu has promised to fast-track a bill to tackle domestic violence.

Photos: Oded Balilty/AP + Jim Hollander/EPA

These photos of Paris were taken just five months apart. The first was captured during France's World Cup win. The second was during recent protests, which have lead to the worst violence the city has seen in half a century. After three weeks of demonstrations led by an extreme fringe of the 'gilets jaunes' (yellow vests) grassroots movement, the French government has cancelled plans to introduce a controversial fuel tax rise. Another protest is still planned for this Saturday. Protesters are demanding rises in salaries, pensions, social security payments and the minimum wage.

Photos:Charles Platiau/Reuters + Yoan Valat/EPA

This Banksy sculpture could be yours for just ¬£2. The legendary street artist has donated the artwork featuring a boat crowded with refugees to @helprefugeesuk's Choose Love pop-up shop in London, where it will be raffled off for charity. Entrants have to estimate the weight of the work to the nearest gram. The closest guess will win the sculpture on 22 December.

A new Guardian study sheds light on the day-to-day racism faced by minority ethnic groups in Britain. Bias in Britain is a week-long investigation into unconscious racial biases that affect minority groups in every facet of their lives. Tap the link in bio to discover the findings.

Founder of the #MeToo movement, @taranajaneen, says the campaign she started against sexual abuse back in 2006 has become unrecognisable and misrepresented as "a vindictive plot against men." The American civil rights activist says parts of the media has framed the movement as a witch-hunt, and that it no longer focuses on survivors of sexual violence. ‚ÄúThis is a movement about the one in four girls and the one in six boys who are sexually abused every year, and who carry those wounds into adulthood," she says. "My vision for the movement is part of a collective vision to see a world free of sexual violence. I believe we can build that world. Full stop.‚Äù Photos: Chelsea Guglielmino/FilmMagic

Global leaders have posed for their annual "family photo" at the G20 summit in Buenos Aires. Heads of state are expected to discuss issues including development, infrastructure and investment at the two-day summit, but with the US-China trade dispute, Brexit, the Ukraine conflict and the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi simmering in the background tensions are expected to be high through the weekend.

Thousands of children across Australia walked out of class today to urge the government to act on climate change. Earlier in the week, prime minister Scott Morrison encouraged students to be ‚Äúless activist‚Äù and not to take part in the strike. Resources minister Matt Canavan also criticised the demonstration, saying "the best thing you'll learn about going to a protest is how to join the dole queue." But their comments were drowned out by these dazzling protest banners. via @guardianaustralia

Photos: @NitaGTAlexander @mkcully @nickwray & @bobburtonoz via Twitter + Mark Metcalfe/Getty Images + @mikepbowers/Guardian

The UK has hit a significant UN target on the way to ending the HIV epidemic by succeeding in diagnosing and effectively treating more than 90% of people with the virus. Botswana, Cambodia, Denmark, Swaziland, Namibia and the Netherlands have also reached the target. However, 43% of people in the UK are diagnosed late, which means they could be sick and could have infected other people before realising their own HIV status.

A boy broke through security, clambered on to the stage and pulled the sleeve of a Swiss guard in the Vatican audience hall while Pope Francis was speaking. When his mother went up to get him, she explained to the pontiff that her son was impaired and couldn't speak. The pope then asked her to "leave him be, leave him to play here." As the weekly audience continued, the child was allowed to keep roaming around the podium.

Photos: Pierpaolo Scavuzzo Credit AGF/REX/Shutterstock + Gregorio Borgia/AP

Melania Trump's crimson trees have created tongue-in-cheek uproar, but psychology experts say the aesthetic may genuinely be jarring for the human psyche. Dr Toby Israel, a pioneer of design psychology, says the heavily red setup detaches viewers from nature, and therefore the psychological comfort associated with the natural world. "A green Christmas tree [is] about nature and the best that nature has to offer,‚Äù he explains. But with these towering red plants: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to recognise that as something that connects us to the universe.‚Äù What do you think?

American politician Harvey Milk was assassinated 40 years ago today. He was the first openly gay elected official in California and is still considered to be America's most influential LGBT politician. Voters sent a record number of LGBT candidates to Congress in this month's midterms and more than 500 LGBTQ politicians now hold public office in the US. Many believe Milk helped make this progress possible.

Photo: AP

NASA engineers are celebrating the successful landing of their InSight spacecraft on the surface of Mars after a seven-month, 300m-mile journey. After a nail-biting descent that started when the spacecraft slammed into the Martian atmosphere at 12,300mph, the lander eventually came to rest on the biggest "parking lot" on Mars. The probe will be used to study the makeup and dimensions of the planet, helping scientists understand how it was formed at the dawn of the solar system 4.6bn years ago.

Photos: NASA + Bill Ingalls/Reuters + Al Seib/Reuters

Footballers and referees in Italy's Serie A were among thousands of people marking @UnitedNations‚Äôs International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women yesterday, by wearing red marks on their faces. According to UN figures one in three women experience physical or sexual violence in their lifetime, 71% of human trafficking victims worldwide are women and girls and only 52% of women married or in relationships make their own decisions about sex, contraceptive use and health care. 
Photos: Claudio Peri/ EPA + Filippo Monteforte/ AFP/Getty Images + Giorgio Benvenuti/ EPA + 
Elisabetta Baracchi/ EPA + Matteo Bazzi/ EPA + NaFoto/Action Plus via Getty Images

India‚Äôs LGBT community celebrated their first queer pride parade in Delhi since the landmark ruling by the country‚Äôs supreme court to overrule a colonial-era law that criminalised homosexual sex. One of the organisers, Deepti, said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the first time we are not marching as criminals." Photos: Sujay Reddy/Barcroft Images + Dominique Faget/AFP/Getty Images

A family flees from teargas fired by US border officers at members of a migrant caravan trying to cross the US-Mexico border. Dozens of people ran towards the border crossing between Tijuana and San Diego on Sunday after travelling through Central America. The Mexican interior ministry has said they plan to deport up to 500 migrants for attempting to ‚Äúviolently‚Äù and ‚Äúillegally‚Äù cross into the US.

Photo: Kim Kyung-Hoon/Reuters

Implants fulfil a huge range of jobs and have improved many people‚Äôs lives, but when things go wrong the results can be catastrophic. 252 journalists in 36 countries have worked to uncover the damage caused by faulty medical devices around the world. We found stories of untested products on the market, and of patients not being told that devices inside them had been recalled. Follow the link in bio to see the #ImplantFiles

People have been lining up outside the Choose Love pop-up store in London to buy gifts for refugees. It's the second year @helprefugeesuk has run the shop, which includes a range of items people can buy for refugees including sleeping bags, emergency blankets and solar lamps. Last year the shop raised ¬£750,000, providing refugees with 800,000 meals, 3,556 nights of accommodation and 25,000 essential winter items. "When you look at how much money is spent on Black Friday and compare that to the need of the world, it's quite shocking", Jose Naughton, chief executive of Help Refugees, said. "We just really wanted to show there was another way to look at consumerism." Photos: Alex Green/HelpRefugees.org

Today marks 100 years since the first female officers joined London's Metropolitan Police, though they didn't have the power to make arrests until 1923. Jamaican-born Sislin Fay Allen became the first black woman to join the force in 1968. Today, just under 8,000 women are Met officers, making up 27% of the force. üëÆ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Photos: Central Press + Heritage Images + Keystone-France/Gamma-Keystone + William Vanderson & Getty Images + Linda Nylind/Guardian

Stranger Things star Millie Bobby Brown has become @Unicef's youngest-ever goodwill ambassador. The 14-year-old made a powerful speech to mark World Children's Day earlier this week and promised to "speak out for the millions of children and young people whose voices have been silenced for far too long." According to Unicef, 262 million children are currently out of school, 650 million girls are married before they turn 18 and over 5 million children die before their fifth birthday from preventable causes.

Three women walked along Dublin's Grafton Street in their underwear in support of victims of sexual violence. It's the latest in a series of Irish street protests against victim blaming, after a defence lawyer said an alleged rape victim's underwear indicated she was "open to meeting someone." The comment was widely condemned by women's rights activists and on social media, with hundreds calling for an investigation into how sexual assault cases are handled in Ireland.

Photos: Niall Carson/PA

To mark 100 years of women being able to stand for parliament in the UK, MPs invited female constituents to come to Westminster to encourage more women to run for office. It meant that, for the first time ever, there were more women in parliament than men. In the 100 years since the Qualification of Women's Act was signed, there have been just 491 female MPs. Women currently make up only 32% of total elected representatives in the House of Commons.

Photo: Sarah Lee

A dead sperm whale that washed ashore in eastern Indonesia had 6 kg of plastic waste inside its stomach including 115 plastic cups, flip-flops and more than 1000 other pieces of plastic. Because of its advanced state of decay, they're unsure if the plastic caused the whale's death. Nearly half of Indonesia's yearly 3.2 million tons of mismanaged plastic waste ends up in the ocean, according to a study published in the journal Science. The study says it's the world's second-largest plastic polluter after China.

Photos: AFP/Getty Images

Transgender Day of Remembrance honours trans people who have died, either at the hands of others or their own. According to the LGBTI Intergroup, there were 369 incidents of transphobic violence last year. This number is probably higher, with many people withholding their identity for fear of further violence. 
In the UK, Samaritans can be contacted on 116 123 and the domestic violence helpline is on 0808 2000 247. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is on 13 11 14 and the national family violence counselling service is on 1800 737 732. In the US, the suicide prevention lifeline is 1-800-273-8255 and the domestic Violence hotline is 1-800-799-SAFE (7233). Other international helplines can be found at www.befrienders.org

Photo: Manjunath Kiran/AFP/Getty Images

India has opened its first ever hospital for the largest patients in the world: elephants. It's spread over 12,000 square feet and includes wireless digital x-ray, laser treatment and dental x-ray equipment for treating injured, sick and elderly elephants. While the animals are an important part of India's culture, animal rights activists say they are still threatened by poaching, electrocution, poisoning and train accidents.

Photos: @STcom + @ReutersIndia + @tara via Twitter

People in Finland are reacting to Donald Trump's recent comments about their country's forest maintenance by posing with rakes. After visiting areas in California devastated by deadly wildfires, Trump said they should be looking towards the "forest nation" of Finland, where wildfires are avoided by raking the forest floor. Trump said he'd spoken to Finland's president, Sauli Niinist√∂, about this, but Niinist√∂ says he doesn't remember the conversation. #RakeAmericaGreatAgain

Photos: @njanjakoo + @aamukahvilla via Instagram & Pyry Luminen + Pauliina St√•hlberg + Ville Laitila + Meira Pappi via Twitter

Happy World Toilet Day! Most people living in high income countries probably won‚Äôt have thought twice about toilets this morning, but for the 4.5 billion people who live without sanitary facilities it's a serious health issue. World Toilet Day was created by the United Nations to draw attention to the issue and make sure everyone has a safe toilet by 2030.

Photo: Harish Tyagi/EPA

At 10 o‚Äôclock this morning, thousands of people started to gather on five of London‚Äôs main bridges to voice their concern over the looming climate crisis. An hour later all the crossings had been blocked in one of the biggest acts of peaceful civil disobedience in the UK in decades. The move was organised by a new group called @ExtinctionRebellion.
In the past two weeks more than 60 people have been arrested for taking part in acts of civil disobedience organised by the group. Organisers are planning to escalate the campaigns from Wednesday. ‚ÄúOnly this kind of large-scale economic disruption can rapidly bring the government to the table to discuss our demands‚Äù, they explained. ‚ÄúWe are prepared to risk it all for our futures.‚Äù Photos: Penelope Barritt + Amer Ghazzal + Steve Parkins

A United Nations inquiry into poverty in the UK has criticised the government for inflicting "great misery" on people with "mean-spirited and often callous" austerity policies. Philip Alston, the UN's rapporteur on extreme poverty and human rights, said that while the UK remains the world's fifth largest economy, the levels of child poverty are ‚Äúnot just a disgrace, but a social calamity and an economic disaster‚Äù. About 14 million people - a fifth of the population - live in poverty, and 1.5 million are struggling to afford basic essentials. Alston warns that child poverty could rise by 7% by 2022. The government says it ‚Äúcompletely disagreed‚Äù with Alston‚Äôs analysis. 
Photo: Stefan Rousseau/PA

A rape case involving a 17-year-old in Cork, Ireland has caused outrage after a defence barrister said the alleged victim's lace front thong suggested she was open to having sex. The jury later acquitted the man accused of rape. Since the trial, hundreds of women have shared photographs of their own underwear in protest and Irish MP Ruth Coppinger held some up in the Irish parliament to highlight the issue. 
Photos: Fiona Corcoran+ Rebecca Black + Lady Louisa +  Elizabeth Mohen +RT√â via Twitter

A small company in Otsu, Japan is getting attention for creating very realistic face masks. The masks, called Real Face, are made of resin and plastic, and are in demand in Japan's technology and entertainment industries. Company founder Osamu Kitagawa says the next challenge is developing a technology making it possible to produce silicone masks for medical workers and people with facial scarring. While the company works to make sure masks are not used for illegal purposes, Kitagawa said he "could not rule out those threats." Photo: Kwiyeon Ha/Reuters

Conservative party ministers are meeting today to discuss Theresa May's Brexit deal, which has been agreed by UK and EU negotiators. While the details of the agreement are still unknown, they will potentially impact 3 million EU citizens living in the UK. @laurapannack has been photographing couples in London who, as a result of Brexit, have been forced to contemplate separation. Caroline and Kadeem (photographed) say it's "hard to picture a clear future for us together in the UK, especially in terms of building a family. So far, we have never seen our nationality or politics as obstacles for our relationship, but with Brexit these could definitely become a challenge."

Comic writer Stan Lee, co-creator of iconic characters including Iron Man, the Fantastic Four, Spider-Man, Daredevil and the X-Men, died earlier this week, aged 95. Since his death fans have been sharing extracts from his old Marvel column Stan's Soapbox, where he spoke out against racism and bigotry at the height of the US Civil Rights movement in 1968.

Hundreds of inmate firefighters have been helping with the deadly California wildfires as part of a volunteer program run by the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation. While some inmates say they appreciate the sense of doing something good, the program has been criticised for human rights violations. Inmates are paid $1 an hour and their shifts can last up to 72 hours. They're also barred from joining the fire service once they've served their time.

Photos: Frederic J Brown/AP/Getty Images + Eugene Garcia/EPA + Gene Blevins/ ZUMA Wire/REX/Shutterstock

Kyrsten Sinema has won the Arizona Senate race in what has been described as a significant breakthrough for the Democrats. The last time a Democrat was elected to an open senate seat in this conservative western state was 1976, the year Sinema was born. In her victory speech, Sinema said: ‚ÄúArizonans had a choice between two very different ways forward: one focused on fear and party politics and one focused on Arizona and the issues that matter to everyday families. I am so honoured that Arizonans chose our vision.‚Äù

The Camp fire in northern California has killed 42 people, making it the deadliest in state history. Governor Jerry Brown has said victims are eligible for crisis counselling, housing and unemployment help and legal aid. While admitting that federal and state governments must do more forest management, Brown says climate change is the greater source of the problem. Of the 20 largest wildfires in California's recorded history, 15 have happened since 2000, when forests have become drier and warmer. Temperatures in the American west have increased by about double the global average since 1970, lengthening the wildfire season by several months. 
Photos: Josh Edelson/Getty Images + Chris Rusanowsky & Paul Kitagaki Jr/ ZUMA Wire/REX/Shutterstock + Noah Berger/AP

Female MPs from around the world gathered in parliament last week to mark 100 years since some women gained the vote in the UK. They pledged to form an international sisterhood supporting the fight for gender equality. International development secretary and minister for women Penny Mordaunt said the challenges faced by female MPs included balancing work with motherhood, sexual harassment and "the daily battle to be taken seriously when constantly being patronised." While the highest number of women in history are currently sitting in the House of Commons, only 32% of British MPs are women. Across the world just 24% of people elected into international parliaments are women.

Photo: Jessica Taylor/PA

A plant-based burger that ‚Äúbleeds‚Äù will make its hotly-anticipated UK retail debut in Tesco on Monday. The burger is made entirely from plants and uses beetroot juice to ooze a meaty red hue. The launch was delayed because of huge demand in the US, where it's sold in more than 10,000 stores and counts Bill Gates and Leonardo DiCaprio among its investors. The burger is expected to be a hit in the UK, where 22 million people consider themselves to be flexitarian, meaning they enjoy meat but want to decrease their consumption.

Emmanuel Macron and Angela Merkel took part in a joint ceremony to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the end of World War I this weekend. The war was one of the deadliest conflicts in human history, responsible for around 40 million military and civilian deaths. More than 60 heads of state attended the ceremony, where Macron delivered a speech warning of the rise of nationalism.
Photos: Barcroft Images

#remembrance ‚Ä®#ww1 ‚Ä®#firstworldwar‚Ä® #remembranceday #merkel #macron

One hundred years on from the end of the first world war, a group of veterans in Dorset are torn between their pride in their military careers and their anger over the lack of psychological support provided to them by the Ministry of Defence. We meet former soldier @allaboutandyprice on his difficult journey to launch The Veterans Hub, a peer-to-peer support network for veterans suffering with PTSD and their families. 
Link in bio to full documentary by @katyaochagavia with reporter @sprengerstreetfood

Today marks the 100th anniversary of the armistice that ended the first world war. It was signed at Compiegne, France on eleventh hour of the eleventh day of the eleventh month. Fighting continued up to that moment, with some soldiers killed just minutes before the conflict officially ended. It's estimated that the total number of military and civilian casualties was about 40 million. The photos show American troops near Saint-Mihiel, France, American soldiers from New York, who served on the frontline in Cambria, France and a gathering crowd in front of Buckingham Palace celebrating that the Armistice had been signed.

Photos: AP + Matt Cardy/Getty Images

Today is Equal Pay Day, which marks the point of the year when British women effectively stop earning relative to men due to the gender pay gap. Although the date of Equal Pay Day varies according to the pay gap each year, this is the second year it has fallen on the same day, showing the pay gap is not closing. It has been illegal to pay men and women different amounts for the same work since 1970, but three quarters of British companies still pay their male employees more than female employees on average, according to government figures released in April.
Photo: Alamy Stock Photo .
.
.
.

#equalpayday #paygap #equality #payparity #everydaysexism #womenatwork

Scotland has become the first country in the world to introduce compulsory LGBTI education. State schools will now be required to teach pupils about tackling homophobia and transphobia, the history of LGBTI movements and exploring LGBTI identity. The move was declared a "monumental victory" for the Scottish LGBTI community by Jordan Daly, co-founder of the campaign which pushed for the changes. ‚ÄúIn a time of global uncertainty, this sends a strong and clear message to LGBTI young people that they are valued here in Scotland," he added. 
Photo: Alan Wilson / Alamy

These 19 black women ran to be county judges in Texas and every single one of them won. Campaigning as Democrats with the slogan "Harris County Black Girl Magic", their wins have partly been attributed to the insurgent statewide momentum generated by Beto O‚ÄôRourke and his army of grassroots activists. But ultimately, it was their historic achievement, and one that has given liberal Texans hope despite O‚ÄôRourke‚Äôs Senate loss to Ted Cruz. 
Photo courtesy of Harris County Black Girl Magic.

A series of archive photos showing the attacks on Jewish businesses in Berlin by Nazis during Kristallnacht, Night of broken glass, have been placed in the same locations 80 years later. More than 1,400 synagogues and other Jewish premises were looted and destroyed across Germany and Austria during the antisemitic rampage on 9 November 1938. At least 91 Jewish people were killed in the violence, and up to 30,000 men were rounded up and taken to concentration camps. Historians believe it was the start of the economic and political persecution of Jews, and the beginning of the Holocaust. Spokesperson for the Jewish Community of Berlin, Ilan Kiesling, said that "the rise in antisemitism in Germany and across Europe has made events such as the commemoration of Kristallnacht even more important."

India burst into life on Wednesday night as people celebrated Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights. Diwali marks the triumph of good over evil, commemorating the return of Hindu deity Rama to his birthplace after defeating the demon king Ravana. In Delhi, revellers flouted strict restrictions on firecrackers implemented to limit the poisonous smog that has become an annual feature of the festival in major Indian cities. The ban has proved controversial, with many claiming it infringes Indians‚Äô right to worship. Swipe to see more pictures.
Photos: Asif Hassan/AFP + Narinder Nanu/AFP + Harish Tyagi/EPA + Rafiq Maqbool/AP + Navesh Chitrakar/Reuters

A viral clip of a brown baby bear climbing a mountain towards its mother has sparked a debate about whether wildlife photographers are doing enough to make sure their subjects are safe. Wildlife experts have criticised the footage, which appears to have been captured with the help of a drone. The noise drones make can sound like a helicopter and frighten wild animals. Clayton Lamb, who studies grizzly bear populations in British Columbia, said he doesn't "think people understand that any sort of interaction with wildlife can come at a cost. There‚Äôs a lot of positive ways to use drones to protect wildlife, but I don‚Äôt think this is one of them.‚Äù

Trailblazing candidates have broken new barriers this election, changing the face of Congress and statehouses across the US. Women have run in record numbers, and Native Americans, Muslims, Latinos, immigrants, millennials and LGBT candidates have already made history with their campaigns. Here are some of the key people who are diversifying American politics.

Democrats have won the House, a momentous win that will enable the party to block much of Trump‚Äôs agenda and bombard him with investigations. Swipe to find out what this means. 
Follow @guardian_us for more on midterms

üóì7 October: @TaylorSwift endorses Tennessee Democrats Phil Bredesen and Jim Cooper
üóì 6 November: It is reported that the state‚Äôs early youth vote has increased more than seven times compared to 2014, up from 12,800 to 98,000 üìà
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
There are a lot of factors clearly at play in the spike (Trump‚Äôs unpopularity among millennials being one of them) but given her profile and the size of her fanbase, you wouldn‚Äôt bet against the Swift Effect being a significant one. 
Via @guardian_us

Photo:¬†Dimitris Legakis/REX/Shutterstock

Archaeologists in Egypt believe a recent discovery throws light on how the pyramids were constructed. A ramp has been found in an ancient Egyptian quarry, which might have been used to carry the huge blocks of stones around. It means that, while the work of building the pyramids still involved the heavy labour of a large number of people, it would have been completed more quickly than previously thought. Inscriptions have allowed the scientists to date the ramp to around the time of Pharoah Khufu, or Cheops, who built the Great Pyramid. While there's no definite proof that the method was used to construct the monument, Egyptologists think it's reasonable to suggest it would have been if the technique was in use in Egypt at the time. 
Photo: Mark Brodkin/Getty Images

Hospital cleaner Geraldine Curran works 30 hours a week, but has been forced to use a food bank six times already this year. She is one of thousands of NHS staff who struggle to make ends meet on the government‚Äôs ¬£7.83 an hour minimum wage. Although last week‚Äôs budget announced it will increase to ¬£8.21 next year, Curran says it isn‚Äôt enough. ‚ÄúI take home about ¬£220 a week. But my mortgage is ¬£700 a month. Then there‚Äôs food, electric, gas and rates,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThe NHS is paying me buttons. I cannot cope. It‚Äôs impossible.‚Äù
Photo: Paul Mcerlane

The devastating civil war in Yemen has killed at least 10,000 people and left eight million at risk of starvation. This week, the UK indicated it will stop opposing a UN resolution designed to put pressure on Saudi-backed government forces and Houthi rebels to end the four-year conflict. The Houthi rebels, who overthrew the Yemeni government, have deep links to Iran while Saudi Arabia has led the brutal pro-government military response with an arsenal of modern military hardware bought from Britain and the United States.
Photo: Ghaith Abdulahad

Jewish nurse Ari Mahler wrote about his experiences of antisemitism on social media, after treating the gunman who killed 11 people and wounded six at a synagogue in Pittsburgh last week. The Washington Post has reported that at least three of the doctors and nurses who saved the gunman's life were Jewish.

The Tower of London was illuminated by 10,000 flaming torches on Sunday evening to mark the centenary of the end of the first world war. Representatives of the armed forces and around 100 volunteers lit the torches from a flame carried from the tower to commemorate everyone affected by war. The ceremony will be repeated every night until Remembrance Sunday on 11 November.

Uzma Nawaz is one of the first female car mechanics in Pakistan.
