The 24-year-old had to tackle entrenched gender stereotypes and financial hurdles to get her job at an auto repairs garage in the eastern city of Multan, but has since earned the respect of her male colleagues. ‚ÄúI took it up as a challenge,‚Äù she said of defying gendered expectations in Pakistan, which has the second largest gender pay gap in the world. ‚ÄúNo hardship could break my will and motivation.‚Äù Photos: S.S. Mirza / AFP

Meet the women who could become the face of the new ¬£50 note. The Bank of England has confirmed a scientist will feature on the new plastic note, which has never depicted a woman other than the Queen. Early frontrunners are Ada Lovelace, the 19th-century mathematician dubbed "the grandmother of computing‚Äù; Dorothy Hodgkin, the only British woman to have won a Nobel Prize in chemistry; and Rosalind Franklin, who laid the groundwork for the discovery of the DNA double helix structure.
Who do you think should feature on the new note? üë©‚Äçüî¨
Images: Hulton + Getty + Pearson Education

A report by supermarket chain Waitrose has revealed that one in eight people are now vegetarian or vegan, while 21% are ‚Äòflexitarian‚Äô, eating a plant-based diet occasionally supplemented with meat. Most people say they changed their diet because of animal welfare concerns and the environment is increasingly becoming another reason. A series of reports has shown that cutting meat and dairy is the single biggest way consumers can reduce their carbon footprint because farming animals is such a CO2-intensive process.

The Philippines has reopened its famous holiday island of Boracay after being on lockdown for six months. In April, president Rodrigo Duterte called the island a ‚Äúcesspool‚Äù and ordered visitors to be kept away to allow raw sewage to be treated. The island attracted 2 million visitors last year, earning the country more than ¬£700m ($1bn) in tourism revenue. Borocay isn‚Äôt the first idyllic destination to be closed to tourists because of pollution. In October, Thailand closed Maya Bay, one of the world‚Äôs most popular beaches.

Photo: Mark R. Cristino/EPA

1.8 billion children are breathing toxic air, storing up a public health time bomb for the next generation, according to a report from the World Health Organisation. Children are vulnerable because pollutants are more concentrated nearer to ground level. Their developing organs and nervous system are more susceptible to long-term damage than adults. Clean cooking and heating technologies, cleaner transport, energy-efficient housing and better urban planning can all help lower emissions.

After dominating European politics for well over a decade, Angela Merkel has said her fourth term as Germany‚Äôs chancellor will be her last. She has often been hailed the world‚Äôs most powerful woman but her long enjoyed German voters‚Äô support has been weakened since her decision to keep Germany‚Äôs borders open at the height of Europe‚Äôs refugee crisis. Here are some iconic images from her time in office.
Photos: Jesco Denzel/Reuters + Michael Kappeler/EPA + Sean Gallup/Getty + Steffen Kugler/AFP/Getty + Dmitry Astakhov/AFP/Getty + Guido Bergmann/EPA

‚ÄúIf there was a 60% decline in the human population, that would be equivalent to emptying North America, South America, Africa, Europe, China and Oceania", Mike Barrett, executive director of science and conservation at WWF has said. Recent analyses showed that even if the destruction were to end now it would take 5-7 million years for the natural world to recover. Barrett says that there is a link between the food system and depletion of wildlife, explaining that eating less meat is an essential part of reversing losses. ‚ÄúThis is actually now jeopardising the future of people. Nature is not a ‚Äònice to have‚Äô ‚Äì it is our life-support system.‚Äù

Hundreds of people gathered for a candlelit vigil near the Tree of Life synagogue on Saturday night, following what is believed to be the deadliest attack on Jews in US history. Eleven people were killed and six injured when a gunman spewing anti-semitic rhetoric attacked the synagogue in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Rabbi Jeffrey Myers, who was leading a service when the gunman struck, urged America‚Äôs political leaders to ‚Äústop the words of hate‚Äù that have sparked a rise in antisemitic incidents across the country. ‚ÄúIt has to start with you as our leaders,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf it comes from you, Americans will listen.‚Äù
Photo: Matt Rourke/AP

Around 7,000 people, including entire families and unaccompanied children, are heading to the US border to escape violence and poverty in Central America. They started in Honduras and have travelled 1500km in gruelling conditions through Guatemala and southern Mexico. The caravan has enabled Trump to campaign hard on illegal immigration ahead of the midterm congressional elections, claiming that ‚Äúhardened criminals‚Äù and ‚Äúunknown Middle Easterners‚Äù are among the group. Mexico has promised temporary shelter, schooling and jobs to people who register for asylum in an attempt to stop them from crossing the US-Mexico border. Meanwhile, a new group of migrants bound for the US set off from El Salvador on Sunday.
Photo: Guillermo Arias/Getty Images

Jair Bolsonaro, a deeply polarising figure who speaks nostalgically about Brazil‚Äôs 1964-1985 military dictatorship, has become the leader of Latin America‚Äôs biggest economy. Outside observers are asking how a candidate with such extreme views can command broad popular support. Follow the link in bio to understand how Bolsonaro managed to rise from political irrelevance in just over two years.

This is Sahle-Work Zewde, Ethiopia's first female president. She is also currently the only female president in Africa. An experienced diplomat, Sahle-Work has promised to work hard for gender equality in Africa's second-most populous country. After taking the oath, she told MPs that if they thought she was talking too much about women, she had only just begun.
Photo: Eduardo Soteras/AFP

A same-sex penguin couple at the Sydney Sea Life Aquarium have welcomed their first baby. After successfully incubating a dummy egg given to them by staff, Sphen and Magic fostered a real egg from another set of penguins who had two and weren't able to look after both. Baby Sphengic is the aquarium's first sub-Antarctic penguin chick and its gender will be known in two months. üêßüêßüêß
Photos: @jamie86 via Twitter + Sydney Sea Life Aquarium

2 million people in the UK suffer from a form of winter depression characterised by low mood, fluctuations in appetite and heavy sleeping. So what are the ways you can tackle it? Seasonal affective disorder, or Sad, a more pronounced form of depression in winter, should be dealt with by a qualified professional.

This viral photo of a young Palestinian protester has been compared to Eug√®ne Delacroix's iconic painting commemorating the second French Revolution of 1830. The photo captures 20-year-old A'ed Abu Amro protesting against the blockade on Gaza, which Israel argues is to prevent Hamas from accessing materials for military purposes. The decade-long blockade has led to the collapse of Gaza's economy and the enclave is regularly referred to as an open-air prison. 
Photo: Mustafa Hassona

The European parliament has overwhelmingly voted for a wide-ranging ban on single-use plastics, in an effort to tackle pollution in seas, fields and waterways. Their goal is to ban all plastic straws, cotton swabs, disposable plastic plates and cutlery by 2021, and recycle 90% of plastic bottles by 2025.

Marbella Ibarra, the founder of Mexico's first professional women's team, has been found murdered. In a country where women's sport has not often been taken seriously, Ibarra founded Xolas de Tijuana in 2014. She often subsidised travel costs, when the team had to cross the border to play in the US professional league. Mexico finally started up a professional women's league in 2017, and the turnout at the Mexican women's league final earlier this year set a world record for a women's club match with 50,000 supporters. Ibarra's murder is being investigated as a hate crime.

This is the extraordinary moment the son of murdered journalist Jamal Khashoggi met Saudi crown prince Mohammed bin Salman today. The Saudis claim Khashoggi, a prominent critic of the crown prince, was killed in a fight, however, Turkish investigators have steadily leaked evidence that allegedly proves he was tortured, murdered and his body dismembered. 
Photo: SPA/AFP

Archaeologists have found what they think is the world‚Äôs oldest intact shipwreck at the bottom of the Black Sea, where it appears to have lain undisturbed for more than 2,400 years. The 23-metre (75ft) vessel, thought to be ancient Greek, was discovered with its mast, rudders and rowing benches all intact just over a mile below the surface. ‚ÄúThis will change our understanding of shipbuilding and seafaring in the ancient world,‚Äù professor Jon Adams from the Black Sea Maritime Archaeology Project explained.

According to a leaked memo obtained by The New York Times, the Trump administration is attempting to strip transgender people of official recognition by creating a narrow definition of gender. The Department of Health and Human Services has undertaken an effort across several departments to establish a legal definition of sex where the options would be binary (male or female) and unchangeable once determined by genitalia at birth. Activists say this change would subject transgender and gender nonconforming people to discrimination, harassment and violence. The revision is the latest attempt by Trump‚Äôs administration to dismantle official recognition of about 1.4 million Americans who identify as transgender. 
Photo: Yana Paskova/Getty Images

The world's longest sea bridge is opening this week, linking Hong Kong and Macau to the Chinese mainland. The $20bn Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau bridge will connect the two cities to 11 Chinese ones to form a high-tech region to rival Silicon Valley in the US. But critics say the 55km bridge is a politically driven project, allowing Beijing to extend its control over the region. Conservationists have also blamed the construction work for the falling numbers of the threatened Chinese white dolphin. Private cars will only be allowed to use the bridge after applying for a special permit. 
Photos: Anthony Wallace/AFP/Getty Images + VCG/ Getty Images

Hundreds of thousands of protesters descended on central London today to demand a final say on the terms of the Brexit deal. People arrived on packed buses from all over the country. Louise Penn from Norfolk was pleased that so many people had turned up. ‚ÄúWe brought London to a standstill and that‚Äôs a message in of itself,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing this partly for myself, but for my children and their children. This is for the future of the country.‚Äù See our Instagram Stories for more action from the march. 
Photo: Vickie Flores/EPA

‚ÄúWhen I was young, I said I wanted to be rich and famous. I‚Äôm really embarrassed by that. I wanted to be a great actress of the stage, I wanted people to throw flowers at me. People have thrown flowers at me, I‚Äôve got my awards, all of that, and still, bam, disillusionment. Especially when you‚Äôre working so hard and you‚Äôre away from your family ‚Äì you‚Äôre exhausted. There‚Äôs no measuring significance and living a life of purpose. Significance is something way deeper. It‚Äôs about legacy.‚Äù @violadavis in today‚Äôs @guardianweekend 
Photo: @dylancoulter

Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are a hit down under. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are in Australia to open the Invictus games, where they've enchanted crowds with their fresh, laid-back attitude. The couple posed with surfers decked out in flower crowns, cracked jokes about drop bears and hugged countless fans, ditching royal protocol in the process. Follow the link in bio to find out how they won the country over, despite simmering Republican sentiments.

Photo: Dean Lewis/AFP

Saga Vanacek made the headlines this summer when she found a 1,500-year-old sword in a southern Sweden lake while skimming stones. Experts at the nearby J√∂nk√∂ping county museum say the sword could date back to the 5th or 6th century AD - before the Viking era. Saga has played down suggestions she should be crowned "Queen of Sweden" in an echo of the Arthurian legend of the sword in the stone and the lady of the lake. "I wouldn‚Äôt mind being queen for a day, but when I grow up I want to be a vet. Or an actor in Paris." Photos: Hilda Grahnat + Jonkopings museum via @guardianweekend

This is nine-year-old drum majorette Keisha Ncube, one of the portrait's from @alicemannnn's All-Female Drum Majorette series that has won the photographer first prize in the annual Taylor Wessing portrait competition. It is the first time judges have honoured a series of images rather than one shot. The drum majorettes go to school in one of Cape Town's poorest areas, and gang violence regularly disrupts their practice, but Mann's series focuses on the children's attempt to inspire their community through values like respect and trust.

China plans to launch an artificial moon to light up the south-western city of Chengdu in 2020. They'll use an illumination satellite that will harness the power of the moon to replace the city‚Äôs streetlights. It‚Äôs set to be eight times brighter than the moon with a ‚Äúdusk-like glow‚Äù. Photo: Tien Minh/AP

Vietnam's most famous blogger, Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh, known as ‚ÄúMother Mushroom‚Äù has been freed after serving two years in prison and ordered to leave for the United States. She was serving a ten-year prison sentence on charges of defaming the Communist government. Ms Quynh was a well-known dissident and blogged extensively about social injustice and environmental issues. Over the last two years, Vietnam has cracked down on activists and bloggers with dozens put on trial for national security law-related offences. Photo: Tien Minh/AP

Northern Irish author Anna Burns has won the Man Booker prize for her ‚Äòutterly distinctive‚Äô Troubles-era novel Milkman. The novel focuses on a young woman being sexually harassed by a powerful man, and was praised by the judges for "its deep, subtle and morally and intellectually challenging picture of what #MeToo is about." Burns becomes the first winner from Northern Ireland.

It took @marselvanoosten several days to take this photo of these endangered monkeys. His efforts were rewarded in this year's Wildlife Photographer of the Year prize. The Qinling golden snub-nosed monkey "is an endangered species and one that very few people even know exists", he explains. "It is not only rhinos, tigers and polar bears; and these kind of species deserve a lot more attention and all the protection they can get."

You might have spotted a blurry female figure in the background of both the Republican Club and Democratic Club paintings that have made the news this week. Artist Andy Thomas says this represents the first future female president approaching the table. Thomas believes it's only a matter of time before the US gets a female president. "50% of US presidents from now on will be women. Other countries are doing it and doing it well." How long do you think it will take for a woman to take charge of the White House?

Dads on social media have reacted to Piers Morgan mocking men who carry their babies in papooses by sharing selfies with their babies in carriers. Morgan posted a photo of actor Daniel Craig carrying his child on his chest, calling it "an emasculating look." But one dad posted on Twitter: "I loved wearing my baby. Fancy a dad enjoying being close to his child!" Photos: Elder Ordonez/SplashNews.com + @joapostrophed + @presenteric + @bencooper + @leslieaswords + @itsjordylive + @suchwinston via Twitter

The UN says up to 13 million civilians are at risk of starvation in Yemen, due to the civil war, which has gripped the country for three years. A Saudi-led coalition has been fighting Houthi rebels, who are backed by Iran, in support of the internationally recognised government, but thousands of civilians have been caught in the middle. Lise Grande, from the @unitednations, told the BBC: ‚ÄúMany of us felt as we went into the 21st century that it was unthinkable that we could see a famine like we saw in Ethiopia, that we saw in parts of the Soviet Union ‚Äì that was just unacceptable. Many of us had the confidence that would never happen again and yet the reality is that in Yemen that is precisely what we are looking at.‚Äù

An Israeli court has ordered Justine Sachs and Nadia Abu-Shanab to pay damages to three Israeli teenagers after they wrote a letter urging Lorde to cancel her concert in Israel. It's believed to be the first effective use of a 2011 Israeli law allowing civil lawsuits of anyone who encourages a boycott of Israel. However, Sachs, who is Israeli, and Abu-Shanab, a Palestinian, are refusing to pay the court-ordered amount. Instead, they've decided to redirect the donations they've received to the Gaza Mental Health Foundation. ‚ÄúOur advice from New Zealand legal experts has been clear", they said in a statement, "Israel has no right to police the political opinions of people across the world."

Fracking restarted in the UK today for the first time in seven years. It was only a week ago that a major report from scientists warned we have 12 years left to avoid catastrophic climate change. Fracking is the process of extracting gas or oil trapped in rocks and is one of the technologies turned to as easy-to-extract oil is becoming harder to find. Critics argue the process works against the reduction of carbon output, and there are fears it could contaminate water and trigger small earthquakes.

Photo: Christopher Thomond

Over 200,000 people marched in Berlin on Saturday to protest against racism, xenophobia and the far right in Germany. The demonstration was a response to several anti-immigration protests over the summer and a rise in support for the far-right Alternative for Germany party. Since 2015, more than 1 million refugees have arrived in the country, leading to increased support for the party, which entered Bavaria's regional parliament for the first time after making gains in Sunday's election. The result is likely to further weaken Angela Merkel's coalition government.

Photos: David Gannon/AFP/Getty Images + Cuneyt Karadag/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images

Donald Trump and rapper Kanye West displayed their celebrity bromance on Thursday in a strange White House collision between politics and music. Arguably one of Trump's most visible black supporters, West was invited to the White House to discuss prison reform, but instead launched into an impassioned, zigzagging stream of consciousness that skipped through race relations, tax breaks, criminal justice and mental health. West has received widespread criticism for his vocal support of Trump.
Photos: Oliver Contreras / Getty

Artist and director Simon Frederick poses with some of the inspirational black Britons he has photographed for his Black is the New Black exhibition at the @nationalportraitgallery in London. From Naomi Campbell to Sir Trevor McDonald, Frederick aims to recognise the impact of black individuals on British culture, and to celebrate black British achievement today.
Photo: Alicia Canter/The Guardian

United Nations launched its International Day of the Girl Child in 2012 to raise support and empower young women around the world via social media. This year's focus is on tackling gender bias in the workplace that still prevents women from taking the career paths they want. @unicef estimates that 600 million adolescent girls will start work in the next decade, with 90 per cent of those living in developing countries working in roles where abuse and exploitation is still seen as normal.

Kosovo held its second ever Pride parade this week. Its LGBT community called for more tolerance in a society where views on sexuality are still conservative. They waved rainbow flags and banners in the streets of Pristina and chanted the motto "in the name of freedom."
Photo: Valdrin Xhemaj/EPA

Writer @beth_mccoll has shared these highly practical tips that can help improve mental wellbeing. In her words, it is ‚Äúa list of potential actions for you to take to feel better and exist through a bad time. Try to pick a few and do them, but if you can't, that's valid too." Via @Guardian_US 
Icons (L-R) by Jamie Dickinson, Noura Mbarki, Luis Prado, RROOK, Lilsole, Vectors Market, Kevin, Delwar Hossain Arafat Uddin via the Noun Project. 
In the UK, Samaritans can be contacted on 116 123 or email jo@samaritans.org. In the US, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is 1-800-273-8255. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international suicide helplines can be found at www.befrienders.org.

A team of global experts commissioned by the Lancet medical journal have found that the quality of mental health services is routinely worse than the quality of physical health services in every country in the world. They estimate that 13.5 million deaths could be averted every year if the underlying mental health problems were addressed. They recommend a much higher priority for mental health and parity with physical healthcare, as well as integrating mental health care into routine primary care. #WorldMentalHealthDay

In the UK, Samaritans can be contacted on 116 123 or email jo@samaritans.org. In the US, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is 1-800-273-8255. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international suicide helplines can be found at www.befrienders.org.

A plastic washing-up bottle that is at least 47 years old has been found washed up on a beach in the UK with its lettering and messaging still clear, prompting warnings about the enduring problem of plastic waste. The item, found by a coastguard warden at a beach in Somerset, ‚Äústill looks almost new‚Äù, despite being dated back to before decimalisation was introduced in Britain in 1971. Some types of plastic bottles take 450 years to break down. The UK produces more than 170m tonnes of waste a year, much of it food packaging, and only a third of plastic packaging is recycled.
Photo: Burnham Coastguard

Tributes have been paid to journalist Viktoria Marinova who was raped and murdered in Bulgaria at the weekend. She had been reporting on alleged corruption involving EU funds linked to businessmen and politicians. Bulgaria was ranked 111 out of 180 countries in the Reporters Without Borders world press freedom index. Marinova is the third journalist to be murdered in the European Union in a year.

Photo: Dimitar Dilkoff/AFP/Getty Images

Donald Trump may like @TaylorSwift's music about 25% less after she expressed support for two Democrat candidates, but her words had impact. 24 hours after her Instagram post, 65,000 people registered to vote in time for next month's US midterm elections. Swift said she remains committed to the fight for LGBTQ rights and described the "systematic racism" towards people of colour in the US as "terrifying, sickening and prevalent." She urged young fans to educate themselves on their local candidates and "vote based on who most closely represents your values."

For the first time in history oil production is set to hit 100m barrels a day.  Opencast coal mining is on the rise in Europe and investments in tar sand oil production have doubled. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change is suggesting four essential ways of combating climate breakdown: new combinations of land use and technological change, reforestation, a shift to electric transport systems and greater adoption of carbon capture technology. By leaving fossil fuels in the ground and replacing them with cleaner energy technologies, environmental activist and Guardian writer George Monbiot argues we can recognise planetary boundaries as the limits of economic activity and set wellbeing as our goal.

We have 12 years to limit a climate change catastrophe, a scientific report has announced today. Following devastating hurricanes in the US, record droughts in Cape Town and forest fires in the Arctic, the report makes clear that climate change is already happening and has upgraded its risk warning. At the current level of commitments by world leaders, we're on course for a disastrous 3C of global warming. The authors of the report are refusing to accept defeat though and believe that the increasingly visible damage caused by climate change will shift opinion.
What does Brett Kavanaugh‚Äôs confirmation mean for the midterms? Follow the link in bio.

A man who punched a woman outside a Paris cafe, prompting outrage after a video of the assault went viral, was sentenced to six months in prison and ordered to pay a ‚Ç¨2,000 fine. The sentence also included a suspended six-month jail term and an order for him to undergo treatment for drug and alcohol problems. The woman‚Äôs lawyer said: ‚ÄúMy client wanted a punishment but she didn‚Äôt want his head to roll, she just wanted him to learn a lesson. If he never does that again, she feels she has won.‚Äù Days after the video went viral, lawmakers adopted a law imposing on-the-spot fines of up to ‚Ç¨750 on cat-callers and aggressively lecherous people.
Which poets have you been celebrating today? #nationalpoetryday

At least 1,424 people have died from a 7.5 magnitude earthquake and tsunami that hit the Indonesian island of Sulawesi last week. Countries around the world are pulling together to help people devastated by the impact. The UN estimates 200,000 people need assistance and has allocated $15m towards relief efforts. Australia is sending 50 medical professionals as part of a $3.9m aid package and the UK government has also pledged $3.9m. The US, China and New Zealand are also contributing to relief effort.
Photo: Fauzy Chaniago

One of the world‚Äôs most popular beaches, made famous by a 2000 film starring Leonardo DiCaprio, will be be closing indefinitely to allow it to recover from the damage caused by millions of tourists. Maya Bay on Thailand's Ko Phi Phi Leh island has sustained extensive environmental damage in recent years, receiving up to 5,000 tourists and 200 boats a day. Thanks to pollution from litter, boats and sun cream, it's estimated that more than 80% of the coral around Maya Bay has been destroyed.
Photos: Lillian Suwanrumpha/AFP, Jamie Monk/Getty

An extremely distant dwarf planet named The Goblin has been discovered in observations that are redefining the outer reaches of the solar system. Estimated to be just 300km across, the icy world has an extremely elongated orbit and takes an astounding 40,000 years to loop around the sun once. Astronomers made the discovery while hunting for a hypothetical massive planet known as Planet Nine suspected to be in orbit far beyond Pluto.
Artist‚Äôs concept courtesy of Carnegie Institution for Science.

Malala Yousafzai has expressed hope that a new portrait of her unveiled at the @nationalportraitgallery will remind visitors that girls across the world are fighting for change. The photo was taken by Iranian-born artist @shirin__neshat, who inscribed a poem on top of it by poet Rahmat Shah Sayel. Neshat said that she "was immediately taken aback by her timid, gentle and innocent demeanour. To this day, when I look back on our encounter, I am left with impressions of humility, wisdom and a rare sense of inner beauty.‚Äù
Photos: Jorge Herrera/PA

Restaurant owners in the UK will be banned from deducting money from tips earned by waiters and other staff. The decision follows revelations about companies deducting money from serving staff, typically from card payments. The restaurants included Bella Italia, Giraffe and Pizza Express, although they've since stopped the practice.

Calvin Ke's photo of a southern pig-tailed macaque holding a plastic bottle in Borneo, Malaysia was one of the Ciwem environmental photographer of the year winners. It highlights the growing concern that plastic is interfering with animals' otherwise pristine natural habitat.

Photo: Calvin Ke

Protests against Brazil's far-right presidential candidate Jair Bolsonaro took place in several cities around the world on Saturday, with tens of thousands of women filling the streets in cities across Brazil to protest against his extremist positions ahead of Sunday's elections. Organised through a Facebook group called Women United Against Bolsonaro, which has nearly 4 million members, protesters demonstrated in Sao Paolo, Rio de Janeiro, New York City and London, adopting the hashtag #elen√£o ('not him').
Photos: Penelope Barrit/Rex, Miguel Schincariol/AFP, Erik McGregor/Pacific Press

A statue of Roald Dahl's Matilda was unveiled in Buckinghamshire today, depicting her defiantly confronting Donald Trump. It marks 30 years since the children's classic Matilda was published. The Roald Dahl Story Company carried out a survey to find out what people thought Matilda would be doing if she was alive today. 42% of them agreed president Trump was the person she'd be standing up to.
Photo: David Parry/PA Wire

Passengers and crew members on a Air Niugini plane were rescued after it overshot the runway in the Federated States of Micronesia. Local fishermen took to their boats to the crash site almost immediately, with some passengers suffering broken bones and head injuries. Pohnpei based journalist Bill Jaynes, who was on the plane, praised the locals' reaction; "They immediately started coming out in boats. One might think they‚Äôd be afraid to approach a plane that just crashed, but they were awesome.‚Äù The Papua New Guinean plane has now sunk in the lagoon.
Photos: Lt. Zach Niezgodski/U.S. Navy via AP + James Benito/AFP/Getty Images + James Yaingeluo/Getty Images

At least half of the world‚Äôs killer whale populations are doomed to extinction due to toxic and persistent pollution of the oceans, according to a major new study. Poisonous chemicals, PCBs, have been banned for decades, but they are still leaking into the seas. Killer whales are one of the most widespread mammals on earth, but have already been lost in the North Sea, around Spain and many other places.

New Zealand prime minister @jacindaardern was met with applause at the UN following her speech calling for global cooperation and kindness from world leaders, in stark contrast to Donald Trump‚Äôs rejection of globalism earlier in the week. "We must rediscover our shared belief in the value, rather than the harm, of connectedness,‚Äù she added. At 38 Ardern is one of the youngest world leaders, and described this generation of young people as ‚Äúborderless‚Äù and ‚Äúglobal citizens‚Äù increasingly expressing ‚Äúdissatisfaction‚Äù with current political systems.

TV host and author Padma Lakshmi has said she was raped 32 years ago and can understand why women wait years to disclose incidents. She wrote in the New York Times that "we all have a lot to lose if we put a time limit on telling the truth about sexual assault and if we hold on to the codes of silence that for generations have allowed men to hurt women with impunity." She chose to share her story in the wake of Christine Blasey Ford's sexual assault allegations against supreme court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. Donald Trump has argued that the time lag between an alleged incident and a public complaint meant that these stories lacked credibility.

The popular Distracted Boyfriend meme has been ruled sexist by Sweden‚Äôs advertising ombudsman. The watchdog said recruitment advertisements posted on Facebook by internet services provider Bahnhof were gender-discriminatory. The ad labelled the boyfriend ‚ÄúYou‚Äù, the girlfriend ‚ÄúYour current workplace‚Äù, and the second woman ‚ÄúBahnhof‚Äù. ‚ÄúThe advertisement objectifies women,‚Äù the watchdog concluded. ‚ÄúIt presents women as interchangeable items and suggests only their appearance is interesting.‚Äù The Swedish advertising industry is self-regulating, which means that the ombudsman can criticise ads but it doesn't have the power to impose sanctions. This year, Stockholm council voted to ban ads deemed sexist or degrading from the city‚Äôs public billboards.

Photo: Antonio Guillem

Beyond the laughter that interrupted Donald Trump's speech at United Nations, he used the assembly to make some bold statements. Trump notably gave a list of friends and enemies. He thanked North Korean dictator Kim Jong-un for his ‚Äúcourage and for the steps he has taken‚Äù but targeted Iran, who he blamed for sowing "chaos, death and destruction" in the Syrian conflict. Russia and Vladimir Putin were absent from his speech, despite deep differences between the US and Russia over Ukraine and Syria. Trump also urged other nations to reject globalism, embrace patriotism and focus on their own national interests. This was a sentiment French president Emmanuel Macron decried in his own speech: ‚ÄúAll against all ends up to everyone‚Äôs detriment.‚Äù

A beach in western Greece recently turned into an arachnophobe's worst nightmare. Spiders in Aitoliko covered the town's beach in a 300-metre long web. The seasonal phenomenon happens during the spiders' mating season and the web disappears naturally. This year, an increase in the mosquito population made the perfect conditions for a population explosion in spiders. ‚ÄúThe spiders are having a kind of a party. They mate, they reproduce and provide a whole new generation", molecular biologist Maria Chatzaki explained.

Photos: Giannis Giannakopoulos/EPA

New Zealand prime minister @JacindaArdern is the first female world leader to attend the @UnitedNations general assembly meeting with her newborn baby. Ardern says she hopes one day it will be the norm for all women to balance a career and parenting if they wish to.

Photos: Don Emmert/AFP/Getty Images + Clarke Gayford/Twitter

Drug trafficking and the battle to control land in Colombia's Valle del Cauca department, are forcing indigenous and Afro-Colombian people to flee their homes. Mothers and children, some of them newborns, have to sleep on floors in shelters for displaced indigenous at Buenaventura and in  the Cabecera community near to the San Juan River. Many have lost their husbands and brothers killed in violence back home. 
Photos: Federico Rios for Christian Aid

A tour bus that transported Tinie Tempah, David Guetta and Sam Smith is being turned into a mobile homeless shelter in Manchester. Sid Williams and his charity Embassy Bus hope the bus will provide emergency shelter and support. Critics are concerned about people who have experienced complex trauma or have support needs being confined to small spaces in the bus. But mayor Andy Burnham supports the idea, as part of his target to eradicate rough sleeping in Manchester by 2020. About 500 people sleep rough in the city regularly, which is a ten-fold increase since 2010. 
Photos: Chistopher Thomond/Guardian

The 41 finalists in this year's Comedy Wildlife Photography Awards have been announced, with the final winners chosen in November. The competition is sponsored by the @bornfreefoundation and is designed to raise awareness of the natural world. Which one is your favourite? 
Photos: Sergey Savvi + Patty Bauchman + Jackie Downey + Mary McGowan + Danielle D'Ermo/Barcroft Images

Theresa May met a wall of resistance at the Salzburg summit yesterday. EU leaders dismissed her Chequers plan of sharing a rulebook for goods and services with Europe to avoid an Irish border. They say it would undermine the single market. Meanwhile, French President Emmanuel Macron accused Brexiteers of lying about how easy it would be to negotiate the deal and hard Brexit Conservatives are demanding the plan to be abandoned all together.

Photo: Lisi Niesner/Reuters

Dorothy Counts was the first black student to attend Harding High School in Charlotte, North Carolina. 61 years later Counts-Scoggins poses outside the school she attempted to integrate in 1957. A new bill is proposing towns in Charlotte, where more than 77% of the population are white, can develop their own charter schools. Residents would have priority admission, with kids from the rest of the country only able to enrol if places remain. ‚ÄúI did not think after all these years I‚Äôd still be fighting this.‚Äù Photos: Douglas Martin/AP + Logan Cyrus/The Guardian

Last year French artist @saype_artiste created grass art on the side of the Swiss Alps. This year he has produced a stunning land art painting in Geneva, Switzerland. The artist has collaborated with @sosmediterranee_switzerland, an organisation dedicated to helping refugees in distress in the Mediterranean Sea. Message From The Future can be found in La Perle du Lac park.

Photos: Valentin Flauraud/EPA

Windrush victim and campaigner Sarah O'Connor has died aged 57. She moved to Britain from Jamaica when she was six but told the Guardian earlier this year that she was facing bankruptcy after being classified as an illegal immigrant. She was formally recognised as a British citizen in July, but her problems continued. O'Connor was one of many long-term UK residents who arrived as children from Commonwealth countries in the 1960s now facing complex problems as a results of the government's "hostile environment" immigration policy. 
Photo: Martin Godwin/The Guardian

The lifeguard tower on the beach in Shek O, Hong Kong has been left tilted by the recent Typhoon Mangkhut. According to the Hong Kong Observatory, the super typhoon is officially Hong Kong's most intense storm since records began, injuring more than 100 people. 
Photo: Jerome Favre/EPA

Designer Suneet Varma and his partner Rahul Arora are the cover stars of the latest India Today magazine where the couple discuss what it's like for same-sex couples in India. It comes a few weeks after the Supreme Court decision that ended a colonial-era law, legalising homosexuality. 
Photo: @suneetvarmaofficial

Broadway actor Jenifer Lewis wore a custom Nike jumper to the 70th Emmy Awards yesterday in support of Colin Kaepernick's protest against racial injustice in America. Explaining why she wore it, Lewis said ‚ÄúWhat can I do? What can I do that‚Äôs meaningful? I‚Äôll wear Nike. I‚Äôll wear Nike to say thank you. Thank you for leading the resistance! We need more corporate America to stand up also." Nike have been criticised for featuring @kaepernick7 in their recent advertising campaign. Photo: Jordan Strauss/Invision/AP

Five grey squirrel siblings had to be separated after they got in a tangle. The young squirrels were attached to each other by grass and plastic from the nest their mother built them. After being taken to Wildlife Rehabilitation Centre, Wisconsin by a "caring finder", 20 minutes of careful cutting freed the kits and they were left to recover from their anaesthetic.
Photos: Wildlife Rehabilitation Center at Wisconsin Humane Society

Children in Calumpit, Philippines try to get across a flooded street in the aftermath of Typhoon Mangkhut. At least 64 people have been confirmed dead, with the death toll expected to rise. More than 5.7 million people have been affected by the storm, with the typhoon striking just weeks before the harvest, leaving crops flooded and the livelihoods of thousands devastated.

Photo: Noel Celis/AFP/Getty Images

Kenyan long distance runner Eliud Kipchoge is the new marathon world record holder after shaving 78 seconds off the previous record set by Dennis Kimetto in 2014. Kipchoge completed the 2018 Berlin Marathon in 2 hours, one minute and 39 seconds. Referred to by his fellow athletes as "the boss man", he has reinforced his case to be considered the greatest distance runner of all time. üèÜü•á
Follow @guardian_sport for more of our sports coverage. 
Photos: John Macdougall/AFP/Getty Images + Gora Andreas/ action press/REX/Shutterstock

Remember Juli Briskman, the cyclist who was fired from her job last year for giving Trump's motorcade the finger? She's planning to run for office in Northern Virginia next year. Speaking to the Washington Post, Briskman said she would "probably" flip Trump off again. ‚ÄúFolks say you should respect the president. Even if you don‚Äôt like what they‚Äôre doing, you shouldn‚Äôt show this sort of disdain. And I simply disagree, and I think the Constitution grants me that privilege.‚Äù Follow @guardian_us for more on US stories.

A French art college in Lyon has been criticised after a photo of white students was digitally manipulated to make some look black. The retouching was an attempt to broaden the college's appeal in the US. Former √âmile Cohl school students reacted to the picture on social media which was taken during a gallery visit. The school said the manipulation was done by a US communications agency and has apologised to students and parents. 
Photos: Twitter

@garyyounge on the racist cartoon of Serena Williams published in Melbourne‚Äôs Herald Sun earlier this week and their extraordinary response to accusations of racism. Read the full piece in the link in bio.

A cycle path made entirely of plastic waste has opened in the Dutch city Zwolle. The 30-metre path, made up of recycled bottles, cups and packaging is part of a pilot scheme that could see similar roads open up across the Netherlands. It is expected to be three times as durable as asphalt. Asphalt concrete is responsible for 1.5 tonnes of CO2 emissions a year.
Photo: Gemeente Zwolle

This photo of Boris Johnson, Jacob Rees-Mogg and veteran Eurosceptic MP Peter Bone has been added to "the growing iconography of Brexit," says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland. Taken at Brexit event earlier this week, the photo came as infighting between pro-Brexit Conservatives and the government continues. Papers released this week reveal the impact a no-deal Brexit could have on driving licenses, passports and phone bills.

Photo: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images

People on Wrightsville Beach, North Carolina are expecting the arrival of Hurricane Florence. It has been downgraded to a category two storm, but is still being described as a "disaster at the doorstep". The hurricane's wind speed has dropped, but its slow moving nature could cause disastrous flooding. Georgia is the latest state to declare an emergency, joining North and South Carolina, Virginia, Maryland and Washington DC.

Photo: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP/Getty Images

Actor Viola Davis has talked about how she ‚Äúregrets‚Äù her role in The Help. In an interview with the New York Times, Davis said she feels that the voices of the black maids in the Oscar-nominated film from 2011 weren't heard. She qualified her criticism by saying that the experience of making the films in terms of friendships and collaborators was extremely positive.

"When the wrong place is between school and his mum's house and the time is 4pm, when is the right time? Where is the right place?" A father remembers when he got the call saying his son had been stabbed on his way home from school. He still finds it hard to believe that someone could just be there one minute and gone the next. Tap the link in bio to watch the rest of our fictional drama series, #BeyondtheBlade.
Performed by: @obiscoco

Late snowfall in South Africa has caught some of its wildest residents by surprise. Photographer @kittyviljoen spotted these giraffes making the most of an unexpected cold front across the Western Cape.

John Legend has become the first black man to earn all four major annual American entertainment awards. The 39 year old is the joint youngest person to receive an Emmy award for his work as a producer on Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert. He has also picked up an Oscar, a Tony and his most recent Grammy award since 2015. 
Photo: Alberto E. Rodriguez/Getty Images

A subway station in New York has reopened for the first time since it was destroyed 17 years ago. WTC Cortlandt opened on Saturday, replacing the old Cortlandt Street station that was buried under debris when the two World Trade Center towers collapsed in the 11 September 2001 terrorist attack. Ann Hamilton's artwork 'Chorus' is featured in marble on the station walls, including text from the US declaration of independence and the 1948 UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
Photos: Dustin Tyler Joyce + Suss via Twitter

Naomi Osaka has been hailed as 'a new heroine' on Japanese social media after becoming the country's first tennis grand slam winner on Saturday. Through her US Open victory, Osaka, who is of Haitian and Japanese heritage, has raised hopes that the country of her birth will adopt a more inclusive definition of Japanese identity. Japan often sees itself as racially homogenous and mixed-race people are routinely referred to as "haafu" (half). Follow @guardian_sport for more. Photo: Alba Vigaray/EPA

Companies like Danone and Nestl√© are backing a government-implemented deposit and return scheme with the ambition for zero plastic packaging to be sent to landfill or escape into the natural environment by 2030, and for packaging to be made entirely from recycled or renewable materials or both. 1m plastic bottles are bought every minute around the world.

Surfing has become the first US-based sport to achieve gender pay equality. Female athletes taking part in @wsl events will receive the same prize money as men from 2019. Australian professional surfer Laura Enever said she was proud to be part of a sport sending a global message of equality. üèÑ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Photo: Jonny Weeks

Israeli artist Sigalit Landau made this ballerina tutu, which is covered in salt crystal formations from the southern Dead Sea. Landau is fascinated by the sea's unique ecological system, and her recent art highlights the environmental and geographic concerns it faces. The Dead Sea continues to struggle because humans are using up its fresh water sources from nearby rivers and streams.

Photo: Nir Elias/Reuters

India‚Äôs supreme court has just struck down a colonial-era law that effectively banned homosexual sex acts. The decision appears to mark the end of a difficult path to legalising homosexuality in modern India. Early cases filed in 1994 and then 2001 bounced back and forth for years between higher courts reluctant to rule on the issue. The law has frequently been used to blackmail gay and lesbian Indians and contributes to their marginalisation, while also inhibiting efforts to fight diseases such as HIV/Aids.
Photo: Arun Sankar/AFP/Getty

Photographer Paul Harmon has highlighted humanity's dependance on water in a series of images from the drought-stricken Murray-Darling basin in New South Wales, Australia. Under the leadership of the Indigenous people who live along the river banks, the vegetation cover was healthy. But the area is now threatened by new agricultural demands. Harmon hopes his work can add something to the current debate about "the cultural significance of country, the preciousness of water and the declining health of Australia's river systems and landscapes." Via @guardianaustralia 
Photos: Paul Harmon

This is the world's oldest living married couple Masao Matsumoto and Miyako Matsumoto posing for a photo with their great-grandchild and their care staff at a nursing home in Takamatsu, Japan. They were married in October 1937 and celebrated their 25th great-grandchild being born last month. With a combined age of 208, Miyako says their 80 years of marriage is "down to patience." Photos: Kwiyeon Ha/Reuters

This all-female panel was criticised on social media for being "gimmicky" and "too PC". The show's editor, Rob Burley, responded to the criticism saying he had "zero shame" for booking the five best guests available. Jo Coburn hosted the new BBC politics programme joined by MPs Emily Thornberry and Amber Rudd, the BBC‚Äôs political editor Laura Kuenssberg, the Guardian‚Äôs political editor Anushka Asthana and the Telegraph‚Äôs Camilla Tominey.

Photo: Reuters

Brazil's 200-year-old National Museum was engulfed by fire on Sunday night. Thousands of items have been destroyed in what's considered to be the biggest natural history museum in Latin America. Criticism was quickly aimed at governments for failing to support the museum and letting it fall into disrepair. It was also reported that firefighters didn't have enough water to put the fire out.
Photo: Leo Correa/AP

A city in northwestern Spain has replaced a standard zebra crossing with a 'cow crossing' to highlight how important the animal is in the Galicia region. The idea came from local dairy farmers in A Coru√±a, who wanted to bring awareness to the dairy industry and connect city people with the countryside. It's estimated that the city produces half of Spain's milk.

Photos: diarioferrol + karmayellow46 + rafapenide via Twitter

‚ÄúEveryone of us needs to show how much we care for each other and, in the process, care for ourselves.‚Äù Remembering Diana, Princess of Wales, who died 21 years ago today. 
Photo: Stefan Rousseau/PA

Children in the Gaza strip returned to school this week. Hundreds of thousands of Palestinian children rely on schools run by @unrwa (United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees), but with the US cutting more than $200 million in aid for Gaza and the West Bank this month, the UN agency faces a major budget crunch. 
Photos: Felipe Dana + Jaafar Ashtiyeh + Mohammed Salem + 
Ibraheem Abu Mustafa

Swipe to compare and contrast the most recent crop of Trump White House interns with a group from a fall 2016 program during the Obama administration. The first photo, which has not been officially released by the White House but was obtained by Vox, shows a majority-white intake, not unlike Trump's cabinet which is more male and white than any of his four predecessors. Via @guardian_us

Thousands of Aretha Franklin fans paid their respects to the queen of soul yesterday, as her body lay at the Charles H Wright Museum of African American History in Detroit. The city, which has become synonymous with the secular outgrowth of gospel music known as soul, is treating Franklin‚Äôs death as the passing of royalty, with a week of mourning including a free tribute concert at a park on Thursday. 
Photos: Paul Sancya + Mike Segar + Jeff Kowalsky

Misa Matsushima has become Japan's first female fighter pilot, three years after the country lifted its ban on women becoming fighter jet pilots. She says she was inspired by watching Top Gun in primary school and has promised to "open the way for other female pilots." Photo: Japan Air Self Defense Forces/EPA

After covering a series of bleak assignments including terrorist attacks in Paris and sex slavery in Spain, photojournalist @stefaniarousselle felt heartbroken. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt believe in love anymore.‚Äù In 2017, to find joy again, she decided to go on a road trip across France, asking random strangers to share their most defining and life-changing love stories with her.

John McCain quoting Mark Twain. McCain was a prisoner of war, presidential candidate and one of the most influential American politicians of his generation. The six-term senator from Arizona remained outspoken to the end, railing against Donald Trump and urging defense of the post-war liberal democratic order. His death will leave a void in a Republican party increasingly turning away from bipartisanship at home and engagement overseas in favour of the president‚Äôs brand of divisiveness and isolationism.

A year ago today, the ‚Äúethnic cleansing‚Äù perpetrated by Myanmar's military against the Rohingya sparked a massive refugee crisis. Nearly a million Rohingya ‚Äì those who escaped the flames and executions ‚Äì are now living in camps in Bangladesh. Photographer @hammond_robin spent time with one of the most persecuted minority groups in the world and has come to the conclusion that belief that time heals is a huge misconception. Follow the link in bio for the full story.

Gaza City‚Äôs Said al-Mishal Centre was a hub for theatre, dance and music. Its destruction in an Israeli air strike has shaken its creative community and rippled out to supporters worldwide. A day after the bombing, hundreds gathered for performances in the rubble of the building as a show of strength and solidarity. "It was a story of love and inspiration. All of our work was there; we lived there; our memories were there.‚Äù Photo: Mustafa Hassona

Halogen lightbulbs will be banned in Europe on 1 September. Their phase-out will prevent more than 15m tonnes of carbon emissions a year, an amount equal to Portugal‚Äôs annual electricity usage. LED lightbulbs, the more energy efficient alternative, consume one-fifth of the energy of halogen bulbs and have a life expectancy of 15-20 years.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, the British-Iranian woman sentenced to five years in jail in Iran for allegedly spying, has been temporarily released from prison for the first time in more than two years. She's been given a three-day furlough allowing her to reunite with her daughter. Her release is limited to three days, but could be extended. Her ordeal is the most high-profile in a string of cases involving dual nationals held in Iran and received huge attention in the UK after her fate became intertwined with the former foreign secretary Boris Johnson‚Äôs political career when he made an erroneous statement that complicated her legal battle.

The oldest and thickest sea ice in the Arctic has started to break up, opening waters north of Greenland that are normally frozen, even in summer. This phenomenon ‚Äì which has never been recorded before ‚Äì has occurred twice this year due to warm winds and a climate-change driven heatwave in the northern hemisphere. These waters are normally so frozen that they were referred to, until recently, as ‚Äúthe last ice area‚Äù.

Remember the police officer we posted about yesterday, who was photographed breastfeeding a malnourished baby in Argentina? Well she's been promoted! Announcing Celeste Ayala's promotion from officer to sergeant, the minister of security of Buenos Aires tweeted: ‚ÄúWe wanted to thank you in person for that gesture of spontaneous love that managed to calm the baby‚Äôs cry. That‚Äôs the type of police we‚Äôre proud of, the police we want.‚Äù
Photos: Cristian Ritondo + Marcos Heredia

Donald Trump has suffered a huge double blow after one of his former associates pleaded guilty and another was convicted of financial crimes, potentially leaving the president himself in legal jeopardy. Tap the link in bio to find out what's happening.

In a bid to save its crumbling economy, Venezuela is devaluing its currency and raising the minimum wage by more than 3,000%. Hyperinflation is when prices spiral out of control, accompanied by plunging currency values. In effect, it destroys purchasing power and encourages hoarding of goods, as people and businesses anticipate further price increases. About 90% of Venezuelans now live in poverty and more than 60% admitted to waking up hungry.

@Greenpeace has blockaded Volkswagen's UK headquarters to highlight the country‚Äôs air pollution crisis. In 2015, VW was caught cheating on diesel emissions tests and the company is now facing the largest group litigation action in UK history. Last month, it was revealed that the repeated hospital admissions of a nine-year-old girl who died in an asthma attack show a striking association with spikes in illegal levels of air pollution around her home in London. In the UK, air pollution leads to the premature deaths of at least 40,000 people a year.

Olympic champion @simonebiles won her fifth all-around title at the US gymnastics championships this Sunday and used her outfit to make a statement for those affected by the sexual abuse scandal that's rocked the sport. She designed her leotard all the way down to the light shade of teal ‚Äì the designated colour for survivors of sexual abuse, a group that includes Biles herself, who revealed in January she was among the victims of former USA Gymnastics team doctor Larry Nassar.
Photo: Brian Snyder/Reuters

Kofi Annan, the former United Nations secretary general, has died at the age of 80 after a short illness. Annan joined the UN system in 1962 as an administrative officer with the World Health Organization and rose through the ranks. As head of UN peacekeeping operations, he was criticised for the UN‚Äôs failure to halt the genocide in Rwanda in the 1990s. ‚ÄúThe UN can be improved, it is not perfect but if it didn‚Äôt exist you would have to create it,‚Äù he told the BBC in April. Annan used his final speech as secretary general in December 2006 to deliver a parting shot at George W Bush's administration, accusing the US of committing human rights abuses in the name of fighting terror. The speech amounted to a broad condemnation of the neoconservative ideology guiding US foreign policy under Bush and was a clear break with protocol for a departing UN chief.
Photo: David Sandison/The Independent/REX/Shutterstock

John Travolta and Olivia Newton John have reunited for Grease's 40th anniversary. Even without the excuse of a birthday, the film is never far away ‚Äì it‚Äôs a staple of the few UK drive-in cinema experiences. Film writer Terri White explains: ‚ÄúTo people who love Grease, it‚Äôs more than just a film. It reminds them of when they first watched it, it reminds them of what it meant to them when they were a kid, what it taught them about being in love, what it taught them about teenage rebellion. I think it stays with you throughout your whole life.‚Äù Photo: Mark Ralston

Professional, emerging and junior photographers have entered the @australiangeographic nature photographer of the year competition with more than 100 photographs showcasing the natural wonder of Australia, New Zealand, Antarctica and New Guinea. Click the link in bio to view the full gallery. 
Photos:
Dylan Toh
Johnny Gaskell
Sean Scott
Justin Gilligan

Aretha Franklin, queen of soul, has passed away. Her musical influence is immeasurable. ‚ÄúThe soulfulness comes from the gospel,‚Äù Beyonc√© once said. ‚ÄúIt comes from Aretha, who listened to all of that, who sang in the church.‚Äù It is almost matched by her political legacy. Her father CL helped Martin Luther King organise the Walk to Freedom; at King‚Äôs funeral in April 1968 she performed Thomas Dorsey‚Äôs Precious Lord. Respect, meanwhile, became hailed as a defining song of both the feminist and civil rights movements. #Respect

An art installation featuring a list of 34,361 refugees and migrants who lost their lives trying to reach Europe has been torn down for a second time in Liverpool. Artist Banu Cennetoƒülu has decided not to reinstall the artwork, leaving the ripped remains as a ‚Äúreminder of this systematic violence exercised against people‚Äù.

A diverse crop of candidates have made a historic win in the US primary elections. These include Christine Hallquist, America‚Äôs first transgender nominee, @ilhanmn, who could become the first Somali-American member of Congress and @realjahanahayes, who could be the first black woman elected from Connecticut.

Major breakthrough alert: New Caledonia has announced tougher protections to safeguard 28,000 square kilometres of water containing some of the world‚Äôs last near-pristine coral reefs. The move will protect the area from exploitation including commercial and industrial fishing, helping to conserve habitats and allow marine life to feed and reproduce undisturbed.
Photo: Marc Le Chelard

An important story for your attention. Swipe for the full reportage.
Video: @fae_notsy + @maeveshearlaw Richard Hall

It's been a year since violence broke out between white supremacists and counter-protestors in Charlottesville, resulting in the death of Heather Heyer who was run over by a man with far-right links. While a large part of the far-right has retreated to the online world, the movement continues to hold an influence on mainstream politics, numbing voters to candidates and ideas that a year ago would seem unacceptable. The extent of this will be measured in November's midterm elections, when voters elect new members of Congress.

New Zealand will ban single-use plastic bags over the next year, following a statement from the government. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre phasing out single-use plastic bags so we can better look after our environment and safeguard New Zealand‚Äôs clean, green reputation,‚Äù explained prime minister  @JacindaArdern.

Swipe right to see how @thebrownhijabi stays motivated when it comes to defending her values and fighting Islamophobia. Sometimes your cause may seem futile, but there are some simple things you can do to stay focused and energised. Tap the link in bio for more of the @galdemzine @guardianweekend takeover 
Video: @jamesdrewturner @shanimalss @elenistefanou

2,000 people in California are now under mandatory evacuation orders after the state's largest ever wildfire destroyed thousands of acres of land and property. The total number of fires in California hasn't actually increased in recent decades, but what global warming has done is caused the character of wildfires to change, with flames spreading more rapidly and with greater intensity.
Photo: Noah Berger/AP
A Guardian reader sent us this letter on 29 August 2016. It's still as relevant as ever.

Iranian photographer @parisapourtaherian was recently told she wasn't allowed inside the Vatani Stadium to cover a men's football game. She still became the first female photographer in Iran to cover a men's football match by taking pictures from a nearby rooftop. Iranian women were allowed to watch the recent World Cup in a football stadium for the first time in nearly 40 years, but the restrictions on women from attending men's sporting events in the country is still officially in place.
Photos: ali_noorani_teh/Twitter + IranianWin/Twitter

Donald Trump attacked basketball superstar LeBron James on Twitter after watching his CNN interview. He said the interviewer ‚Äúmade Lebron look smart, which isn‚Äôt easy to do‚Äù. Since Trump questioned James‚Äôs intelligence, @guardian_us decided to see how their two educational projects compared ... cc @ipromiseschool

South Korean women marched in record numbers last weekend to protest against "molka"- spycam videos of women being secretly filmed in public places. The number of spycam crimes has risen from around 1,100 in 2010 to more than 6,500 last year. Since May, monthly demonstrations in Seoul have become the biggest-ever women's protest in South Korea, with the #MeToo movement inspiring a wave of activism in the country.

Photos: Ed Jones/AFP/Getty Images/ & Jung Hawon/Getty Images

Artist @danielmercadante wanted to bring warmth and colour to the bleak winter landscape of Connecticut with his Rainbow Road series of photographs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all very homemade,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI set a long exposure and run through the frame carrying this Rainbow Rig.‚Äù The rig is made of cheap coloured lights attached to a broom handle. He was instinctively drawn to the image of a rainbow, which brought a sense of childhood nostalgia ‚Äì he cites Mario Kart and The Wizard of Oz as influences, saying: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs this universal symbol of hope and optimism.‚Äù Tap the link in bio to see the full gallery.

Today marks 73 years since the first atomic bomb hit Hiroshima. 140,000 people lost their lives in the attack, with the bombing of Nagasaki three days later killing another 70,000. Last year, a global treaty was approved to ban the bombs, a move that supporters hope will lead to the eventual elimination of all nuclear arms. However, all countries that bear nuclear arms and many others that either come under their protection or host weapons on their soil boycotted the negotiations. The most vocal critic of the discussions was the US, pointing to the escalation of North Korea‚Äôs nuclear and ballistic missile programme as one reason to retain its nuclear capability. The UK didn‚Äôt attend the talks despite government claims to support multilateral disarmament.

Photo: Jiji Press/EPA

Fifteen Church of England cathedrals, including Salisbury, Liverpool and York Minster, have signed up to green electricity tariffs. Church leaders are urging more to follow their example, describing climate change as "one of the great moral challenges of our time, hurting the poor first and worst."

@joritagoch created a mural in Bethlehem, West Bank to honour Palestinian activist Ahed Tamimi. Tamimi was arrested in December after slapping and kicking Israeli soldiers outside her home. She was released this week and says she used her eight months in prison as an opportunity to study international law. She hopes to one day lead cases against Israel in international courts. The Palestinian government has launched several international complaints against Israel, including for alleged war crimes and what it says is a system of governance that amounts to apartheid. Israel has vehemently denied the allegations.
Photos: Getty Images

Hawaii is the bird extinction capital of the world. The fabled  ª≈ç ª≈ç was last seen on the islands in 1985. Our new Daydream exclusive takes you back in time to meet the legendary bird and hear its last song in 360 virtual reality. Tap the link in bio for more.
In the 1960s James Baldwin was one of America‚Äôs most prominent public intellectuals. Now his ideas are used to explain everything from Donald Trump to Black Lives Matter. #bornonthisday

Denmark's ‚Äòburqa ban‚Äô comes into effect today. Garments covering the face, including Islamic veils like the niqab and burqa will be banned under the new law. Marcus Knuth of the ruling liberal party Venstre, said the dress worn by some conservative Muslim women was ‚Äústrongly oppressive‚Äù. But opponents are calling the measure ‚Äúdiscriminatory‚Äù against a minority group with demonstrations planned later today. Other European countries have similar bans, claiming they're not aimed at any religion in particular.

Photo: Andrew Kelly/Reuters

Republicans have been trying to whittle away the Endangered Species Act since Donald Trump took office, and their efforts reached a crescendo last week. Under the new rules, wildlife managers would limit protections for species designated as ‚Äúthreatened‚Äù (a level below endangered), consider the economic costs prior to defending a species and de-emphasise long-term threats such as climate change. More than 1,600 species are listed as endangered or threatened. These are just six that may be affected by the proposed changes. Follow @guardian_us to stay informed about stories like this.

A US mother has started the Free Mom Hugs movement to support LGBTQ youth in need of acceptance. Sara Cunningham became an "accidental activist" when her son came out and became aware of hostile political climates for LGBTQ groups across the country. The group travels around the US to offer their support to local LGBTQ youth. Cunningham hopes they can make the world "a kinder, safer place for our kids." Photo: Sara Cunningham/@FreeMomHugs

A female duck was spotted with 76 baby ducklings. Wildlife photographer Brent Cizek captured the rare moment on a recent trip to Lake Bemidj, Minnesota. A common merganser duck usually lays up to a dozen or so eggs, but this hen has decided to adopt a few more chicks. Adult animals raising unrelated young has been observed in dolphins, whales and porpoises too.
Photo: Brent Cizek

More than $119bn has been wiped off Facebook's market value, after the announced user growth had slowed since the Cambridge Analytica scandal. The number of people who use Facebook in Europe has dropped from 282 million to 279 million. Are you still on Facebook?

Mary Ellis, the last surviving British female pilot from the second world war, has died aged 101. 
She joined the Air Transport Auxiliary in 1941 and delivered Spitfires and bombers to the front line over the next four years. A total of 168 women served in the ATA during the war.

Photo: Gareth Fuller/PA

More than 350 golden retrievers attended an event marking 150 years since the first pup of their breed was born. The event was held at their ancestral homeland at the Guisachan Estate in Tomich, Scotland üêï 
Photo: Sandra Mailer

Pakistanis take to the polls in today‚Äôs general election. Millions are expected to take part in a fiercely contested campaign that has been marred by violence. At least 29 people were killed in a suicide attack near a polling station in the city of Quetta. Voters are deciding between the parties of ousted former prime minister Nawaz Sharif, led by his brother Shehbaz Sharif, and former cricket star turned politician Imran Khan.
Photo:
Arif Ali

At least 49 people have been killed after a devastating wildfire hit a small town near Athens. By dawn on Tuesday, fires were still burning around the capital, while others broke out elsewhere during the night. Greece has invoked European Union civil protection agreements to seek help. A military transport plane is due to arrive with 60 firefighters from Cyprus, while two water-dropping planes are expected from Spain.
Photos: Angelos Tzortzinis/AFP/Getty Images
"Every bad situation is a blues song waiting to happen." Remembering singer Amy Winehouse who died seven years ago today.

The Met Office has issued a heatwave warning in the UK, advising people to stay out of the sun until Friday (particularly between 11am and 3pm). Temperatures are expected to rise to 30C. Even if things cool down for the rest of July and August, this will still be one of the 10 hottest summers on record.

Photo: Paul Marriott
Standup comedian @hannah_gadsby caused a sensation with her show about homophobia and sexual violence. We interviewed her about shame, rage and Louis CK. Link in bio

Students at the University of Manchester have painted over a mural of a poem by Rudyard Kipling, arguing that the writer ‚Äúdehumanised people of colour‚Äù. The poem If, written around 1895, had been painted on the wall of the university‚Äôs newly refurbished students‚Äô union, but students painted over the verses, replacing them with the 1978 poem Still I Rise by the American poet and civil rights activist Maya Angelou.

More than 140 of Larry Nassar‚Äôs sexual abuse survivors were honoured at the Excellence in Sports Performance awards last night. They received the Arthur Ashe Award for Courage In a statement, gymnast Sarah Klein said ‚Äúwe must start caring about children‚Äôs safety more than we care about adults‚Äô reputations. If we can just give one person the courage to use their voice, this is worth it.‚Äù Nassar has been sentenced to up to 125 years in jail.
Photo: Getty Images

Born 100 years ago on the 18 July 1918, Nelson Mandela led South Africa from apartheid to democracy. He was a humble, eloquent and inspirational figure who advocated peace, democracy and human rights and his words mobilised a movement and made him an icon to millions.

A US model has been widely praised for breastfeeding her 5-month-old daughter during a swimsuit show. Mara Martin hopes her actions will normalise breastfeeding and show that "women can do it all." Photos: Larry Marano/REX/Shutterstcok & JLN Pohotgraphy

The Kerala government in South India has changed its labour laws to allow women working in retail to sit at work. Employers are no longer able to deny them access to chairs and lifts. The new laws also include a minimum monthly starting salary, an eight-hour day and a lunch break. 
Photo: Amit Dave / Reuters

Helsingin Sanomat, one of Finland's largest newspapers, unveiled 300 billboards celebrating the country's free press ahead of Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin meeting in Helsinki today. The campaign highlights the importance of free press, with billboards filled with headlines revealing both Trump and Putin's attitude towards the media.

The Republic of Ireland will become the world‚Äôs first country to sell off its investments in fossil fuel companies. Scientific research shows that in order to keep to international targets to limit global warming to a 2C rise and prevent catastrophic levels of climate change, between two-thirds and four-fifths of fossil fuels need to remain in the ground.

Over a million fans gathered in Paris to celebrate France's World Cup victory over Croatia on Sunday, filling the streets around the Champs-√âlys√©es and the Arc de Triomphe. As the game finished 4-2, supporters singing the French national anthem poured on to the streets to cheer France's second World Cup win. Follow @guardian_sport for more

Russian protest performance group Pussy Riot claimed responsibility for a pitch invasion during the World Cup final.
The group said the pitch invasion was a protest demanding: ‚Ä¢ ¬†Free political prisoners ‚Ä¢ ¬†Do not put people in jail for social media ‚Äúlikes‚Äù ‚Ä¢ ¬†Stop illegal detentions at political rallies ‚Ä¢ ¬†Allow political competition in Russia ‚Ä¢ ¬†Do not fabricate criminal cases and detain people for no reason

These girls in a Rohingya refugee camp in southern Bangladesh are using thanaka to protect themselves from the sun. Thanaka is a yellow paste made from ground bark. The girls have said that the traditional cooling paste helps bring a sense of normality to camp life. More than 700,000 Rohingya refugees have fled Buddhist-majority Myanmar. The country doesn't recognise them as an indigenous ethnic group and denies them citizenship. The United Nations has struck a deal with Myanmar aimed at allowing hundreds of thousands of Rohingya Muslims sheltering in Bangladesh to return safely, but they won't have explicit guarantees of citizenship or freedom of movement.

Photos: Clodagh Kilcoyne/Reuters

Greenpeace has installed these life-size sculptures of whales in Rome, Italy. They‚Äôre covered in single-use plastic to raise awareness of plastic pollution and the brands that pollute the most. The plastic was collected from beaches along the Italian coastline with 80 percent coming from large companies including Coca-Cola, Unilever, Nestl√© and Haribo.

Photo: Stefano Montesi/Getty Images, Alessandro Serrano/AGF

Gareth Southgate and his players have helped redefine the way the England team is perceived around the world. New heroes have emerged, with a new respect and a new outlook. This England feels different: a band of brothers, so assured and comfortable in their own skin. This England does many things well and is growing in confidence in front of our eyes. Cc @guardian_sport 
Photos: Shaun Botterill, Kai Pfaffenbach, Maxim Shemetov, Owen Humphreys, Kirill Kudryavtsev

Thousands of Bosnian Muslims gathered at the Potocari Monument Cemetery to mark the 23rd anniversary of the Srebrenica genocide. After taking part in a peace march, a collective funeral was held for 35 recently identified victims. More than 8,000 people were murdered by Bosnian Serb militias in one of Europe's worst massacres since the second world war.

Photos: Anadolu Agency/Getty Images

Students hold up drawings and letters outside the hospital where the 12 boys and their football coach are being treated, after their rescue from the Tham Luang cave complex. The boys spent more than two weeks trapped in the cave. 
Photos: Athit Perawongmetha/Reuters

Six LGBT activists from Spain, the Netherlands, Brazil, Mexico, Argentina and Colombia have been walking around Moscow in their national team's football colours to form the rainbow flag. The Hidden Flag is an initiative "aiming to celebrate diversity and love in a place where celebrating diversity is not easy." Rainbow flags are rarely seen in public since the Russian government passed the infamous "gay propaganda" law in 2013. The law led to a rise in hate crimes against the LGBT community. 
Photos: TheHiddenFlag.org

Meet Valeska Valle, Lesther Alem√°n and Douglas Costa - three students from Nicaragua who have had their lives turned upside down since joining a non-violent student uprising against President Daniel Ortega. Ortega has been accused of increasingly autocratic rule, but has vowed to fight on despite the recent violence claiming more than 300 lives. The students have little money and food, and Valeska admits most of them have been rejected by their families. "Of my seven brothers and sisters, five told me it would be better if I said I was an only child." Photos: Tom Phillips

A woman takes care of her newborn at her home in Jeich, South Sudan, after a @worldfoodprogramme_official plane dropped sacks of maize and sorghum. The small village is surrounded by swamps and has been cut off by floodwater. Ongoing conflicts in the area have also isolated the villagers. 
Photo: Patrick Meinhardt/AFP/Getty Images

The sun shone on London's annual LGBT Pride celebration at the weekend. 30,000 people from 472 organisations took part in the parade, and up to one million others lined the streets to watch it. 
Photos: Jack Taylor/Getty Images & Dinendra Haria/REX/Shutterstock

Gavin McGregor was rummaging around in his friend's attic when he stumbled across a treasure trove of LGBTQ+ campaign material from the 1980s ‚Äì a pivotal time in the fight for equality. Ahead of London Pride we look at some of his favourite badges which serve as a reminder of the bravery of activists from the time. Does the collection inspire any memories? Gavin would love to hear from you if so https://paudspins.wordpress.com/

Since the news broke of 12 boys and their football coach being trapped in the Tham Luang Nang Non cave, the local community has been helping the rescue effort in any way they can. They've provided food, massages and haircuts for the rescue workers, and money for the parents of the missing boys who have stopped work to wait at the cave for updates. The rescue efforts have been helped by mostly dry weather, but once the monsoon rains start the fear is that water levels could rise again.

Photos: Lauren DeCicca/Getty Images, Rungroj Yongrit/EPA & Ye Aung Thuye/ AFP

This year‚Äôs Rencontres de la Photographie ‚Äì the 49th instalment of the annual photography festival in Arles, France ‚Äì brings together more than 30 exhibitions under the title Back to the Future. The exhibition is on until 23 September.
Photos: Cristina de Middel & Bruno Morais / Aurora Valade / Gregor Sailer / Frantisek Pekar / Wiktoria Wojciechowska

Pro-animal rights activists protest against bullfighting and bull-running in Pamplona on Thursday, on the eve of the San Fermin festival in Northern Spain. The festival is a symbol of Spanish culture that attracts thousands of tourist to watch the bull-runs despite heavy condemnation from animal rights groups. 
Photo: Ander Gilleneaander / AFP / Getty

On 5 July 1948 the UK launched the world's first free health and social security service. It was founded on the principle that everyone should have access to good healthcare regardless of wealth. These archive photographs show the NHS at its inception 70 years ago.
