Two activists rest after placing a vest with the words "Open Arms" on a 60-metre high statue of Christopher Columbus in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday. The activists, from Spanish NGO Proactiva Open Arms performed the stunt to turn attention to the loss of life of migrants and refugees in the Mediterranean Sea.
Photo: Emilio Morenatti / AP

In Nigeria, women‚Äôs hairstyles can carry a number of different meanings and messages. These plaits and elaborate structures take anywhere between 30 minutes and five hours to create and can mark special occasions such as weddings and birthdays, denote a particular family or region or respond to political and artistic movements of the day. The acclaimed Nigerian photographer JD ‚ÄôOkhai Ojeikere spent 40 years immortalising nearly 1,000 of these hairstyles, until his death in 2014.

Between 2011 and 2013 German photographers Sabine Haubitz and Stefanie Zoche focused their lenses on the the colourful churches in South India, with their unusual mix of local building styles and Western influences. During their 18 years of working together Haubitz and Zoche focused on architecture and public space, but the partnership was cut short when Haubitz died in an accident in 2014. Since then Zoche has continued to publish work under the Haubitz + Zoche name; ‚ÄúI‚Äôll carry on doing artwork in both of our names because she‚Äôs still present in whatever I do."
Photos: Sabine Haubitz/Stefanie Zoche/VG Bildkunst

A young Thailand football team and their coach have been found after monsoon rains trapped them inside Tham Luang Nang Non cave for nine days. Footage of the 12 boys was shot by the divers who found them first. Experts warn it may take months before they can be safely rescued because of the high water levels. The military are sending in food provisions to last the group for up to four months, while a medical team have been sent in to assess them. There has been jubilation in Thailand after the news broke, especially among relatives who have been keeping a vigil outside the cave entrance since the boys were reported missing. Tap the link in our bio for the latest updates on the Thailand cave rescue.

Photos: Royal Thai Navy/AFP + Lillian Suwanrumpha/AFP/Getty Images

A report in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences says this may be an example of evolution in action, as specimens currently succeeding in coastal ecosystems today share a gene that resists the virus, suggesting that the virus catalysed a process of natural selection.

There's only a few more days left to apply for this year's Guardian Digital Fellowship. So if digital media and coding excite you, don't let this opportunity pass you by. Tap the link in our bio for more details about the scheme, and how to apply.

Firefighters in Greater Manchester are continuing to battle a huge fire on Saddleworth Moor after working through the night to try to control the 6km-long blaze. The fire has been declared a major incident and the army is on standby to step in. Health officials issued advice to people in the neighbouring area to stay inside their homes and keep their doors and windows closed to deal with the smoke coming from the moor.
Photo: Anthony Devlin/Getty Images

In an interview with the Guardian last weekend, David Lynch said that Donald Trump ‚Äúcould go down as one of the greatest presidents in history because he has disrupted the thing so much. No one is able to counter this guy in an intelligent way.‚Äù His words were misrepresented by Breitbart News and Trump himself, who joked that Lynch‚Äôs career was over for signalling support for his presidency. Lynch has just issued this clarification.

Netflix has brought 47 of its black leads and creators together to recreate an iconic photo. The original image is called A Great Day in Harlem and was captured by Art Kane who photographed 57 jazz musicians on the steps of a New York brownstone building in 1958. The tribute image is part of Netflix's @strongblacklead campaign; a commitment to support black creators in film and television.
Photos: Lacey Duke (2018) & Art Kane (1958)

San Francisco's city hall was lit up in rainbow colours after the city's 48th annual pride celebrations. It remains one of the largest pride parades in the US.

Photo: Josh Edelson/AFP/Getty Images

Mumbai has become the largest Indian city to ban single-use plastics. As of today, residents caught using plastic bags, cups or bottles face penalties of up to 25,000 rupees (¬£276) and three months in jail. While India's use of plastic is less than half the global average, a 2015 study revealed it was one of the worst offenders when it comes to mismanaging plastic waste. About 6.3bn tonnes of plastic has been discarded globally since 1950, and most of it won't break down for at least 450 years.

Photos: Divyakant Solanki/EPA
cc @garyyounge

Models walked down a rainbow runway during Paris Fashion Week as US designer Virgil Abloh revealed his first collection for Louis Vuitton. The colourful backdrop coincides with pride month, which celebrates the LGTBQI community. June marks the 1969 Stonewall riots in Greenwich Village, recognised as the start of the modern fight for LGBT rights in the US. 
Photo: @_paul_roberts via @guardianfashion

When Melania Trump boarded a plane to Texas, where she was scheduled to meet detained children, she appeared to be wearing a jacket with the caption 'I really don't care. Do U?'. In response, @parkermolloy set up IReallyDoCare.com to raise money for groups helping families who have been separated as a result of the Trump administration's "zero tolerance" policy on unlawful border crossings. #IReallyDoCare is now a trending hashtag. The authorities have been arresting, prosecuting and jailing adults while putting their children in separate camps. Donald Trump has retreated from the policy but his administration hasn't said how it plans to reunite more than 2,300 children who were taken from their parents in recent weeks. 
Photos: @l0prah @mrsjfroco @bethfpoetry @magdalenkala

70 years ago today the Empire Windrush docked in Essex carrying nearly 500 settlers from Jamaica, including men and women who served in Britain's armed forces during the second world war. As we celebrate this anniversary, it's important to remember that the UK government was set on deporting members of the Windrush generation until it was forced to change course due to public outcry. As Guardian journalist @GaryYounge writes today: "it has yet to fully sink in that what was wrong for the Windrush generation is wrong for all immigrants, and that when we argue for a more humane and less hostile environment for immigrants we do so not just for the sake of foreigners. We do it for ourselves."

The Gorilla Foundation has announced the death of Koko the gorilla. Koko was famous for her ability to communicate complex emotions and thoughts through sign language. She died in her sleep at the age of 46. She was featured in multiple documentaries and fascinated millions with her compassionate care of her very own pet kittens.

Iranian women have taken advantage of an opportunity not available to them back home: cheering on their national team during the World Cup in Russia. '#NoBan4Women' banners could be seen during Iran's first match in St. Petersburg last Friday. The ban on women attending sports events in Iran has been in place since the 1979 revolution, but it was lifted to allow women in Tehran to watch Iran v Spain on Wednesday night. Follow @guardian_sport for more on the World Cup.

This is an aerial view of the Kapoho Bay in Hawaii. Once home to thriving coral and abundant fish it is now covered in fresh lava from the weeks-long eruption of the Kilauea volcano. ‚ÄúFrom a human point of view, what‚Äôs happening is tragic,‚Äù said David Damby, a volcanologist with the United States Geological Survey (USGS). ‚ÄúBut from the volcano‚Äôs point of view, that‚Äôs the job she does: to build new land and change the landscape. That‚Äôs the way the earth works.‚Äù Photo: LE Baskow/AP

While the UN warns of food scarcity in the rest of North Korea, is this funfair in Pyongyang just a welcome distraction for the privileged few?

Video: @katyaochagavia, @maeveshearlaw and @fae_notsy

In April, US attorney general Jeff Sessions announced a ‚Äúzero-tolerance‚Äù policy under which every migrant who crosses the border illegally ‚Äì even those seeking asylum in the US ‚Äì is subject to criminal prosecution. Since children aren't allowed to be held in a federal jail, they're taken from their parents and placed in the care of the Office of Refugee Resettlement. Almost 2,000 children have been separated from their families at the US southern border over a six-week period during a crackdown on illegal entries.
The Trump administration is facing increasing pressure from prominent lawmakers and human rights groups to halt this separation of families.
Photo: John Moore

If you go down to the Serpentine lake in Hyde Park this summer, you'll find the Mastaba, a floating art installation made from over 7000 stacked barrels. It's the work of Bulgarian artist Christo Vladimirov Javacheff who, along with his late wife Jeanne-Claude, is famous for large-scale environmental projects. While the artist has been coy about the meaning behind the Mastaba, it's been described as a protest on how we're polluting the planet.

Photo: @davidlevene

Happy Father's Day! Tap the link in @guardianfashion's bio to see what four new dads think about parenthood.
Photo: @alexbramall

Gina Martin was at a festival when a man secretly photographed up her skirt and shared it with his friends. When the police told her they couldn't do anything because 'upskirting' wasn't a crime, she started a campaign. ‚ÄãAfter a 71 year-old male MP blocked a bill that would make it illegal to take photos up women's skirts, @beaniegigi describes how it felt when it happened to her and why she's committed to changing the law.
Video: @fae_notsy + @maeveshearlaw + @josh_tou

The Eid al-Fitr holiday marks the end of Ramadan, the Islamic holy month of fasting for many of the world‚Äôs 1.6 billion Muslims. It‚Äôs Islamic custom to celebrate Eid with a small sweet breakfast and to give charity before Eid prayers in congregation. Many Muslims celebrate by giving gifts, wearing new clothes and visiting friends and family.
Photos: @jeszmann/Getty Images + Jack Kurtz/ZUMA Wire/REX/Shutterstock + Omar Sobhani/Reuters + @gulshanii/AFP/Getty Images + Henry Nicholls/Reuters + @_BrookMitchell/Getty Images

What do North Koreans believe? On a rare press trip to Pyongyang, we were given a guided tour of the Juche Tower. The flame-topped structure is a symbol of Juche, the philosophy of the ruling Korean Workers' party which was invented by Kim Il-sung, the country‚Äôs Eternal Leader and grandfather of Kim Jong-un. It's an ideology of self-reliance and is said to be the key behind North Korea‚Äôs progress and success.
Video: @katyaochagavia + @fae_notsy

Twitter have launched this emoji to celebrate the growing influence of women working in the football industry. It‚Äôs part of Women in Football's #WhatIf campaign where businesses, celebrities and members of the public choose one way they can contribute to the improvement for girls and women within football. Chair of Women in Football @annasofiakessel says the emoji is "a simple, but obvious and effective way of increasing women's visibility in the game." Photo: Twitter

Today marks a year since 72 people were killed in the blaze at Grenfell Tower, an event which shook the nation. Shortly before 1am this morning ‚Äì the time the fire service received the first emergency call ‚Äì a procession reached the tower, now shrouded in white and topped with banners bearing green hearts and the words: ‚ÄúGrenfell: forever in our hearts‚Äù. A London Underground driver also stopped his train on a bridge near the tower and waved a green banner in support of people holding a vigil for victims.
Video: AP
Photos: @aliceaedy + Tolga Akmen/AFP/Getty Images

At least one in five wild mammals in Britain faces a high risk of extinction within a decade including the wildcat and the black rat. Overall populations are also falling. There are just over 500,000 hedgehogs, two-thirds lower than in 1995 and rabbits, red squirrels and water voles are falling in numbers. The main cause, according to analysis by @mammalsociety, @naturalengland and @sussexuni is the destruction of wild places by roads, buildings and intensive farming, which combine to reduce and fragment habitat.
Photo: Steve Heliczer/PTES/BHPS

Did you know England has already hosted a World Cup this summer? The @conifaofficial World Football Cup was established in 2013 for self-declared regions, ethnic minorities and "sportingly isolated territories" not officially recognised by Fifa. Teams like Tuvalu, Sz√©kely Land, Tibet, Matabeleland and the Isle of Man get the chance to play on the international stage. Some are just happy to play international opponents. Others hope Fifa will one day acknowledge their existence. Karpatalya, representing the Hungarian minority living in Carpathian Ruthenia, beat Northern Cyprus in a tense final. For more like this, visit @guardian_sport.
Photos: Tom Jenkins

A rainbow installation standing for LGBTQ rights in Warsaw, Poland made a welcome return on the eve of the city's Pride event. The original artwork was created in Zbawiciela Square in 2012, but was burnt down and vandalised. The new rainbow returns in the shape of a projection, which is much harder to destroy.

Photos: Alik Keplicz/AP

US president Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un held the first meeting between a sitting US president and a North Korean leader. The agreement from their 38-minute meeting aims to establish peace between the US and North Korea, work towards denuclearisation and peace in the Korean Peninsula and commits the nations to recover the remains of prisoners of war and soldiers declared missing in action in the Korean war. Critics have called the agreement vague but say resulting meetings may bring clarity.
Photo: Kevin Lim/The Straits Times/ZUMA Wire/REX/Shutterstock

Influential feminist Millicent Fawcett was born 171 years ago today. She took an interest in women's suffrage after hearing a speech by a radical MP at the age of 19. At the age of 81 she was in the House of Commons when women were finally given the right to vote on the same terms as men in 1928. She died one year later. The Fawcett Society continues to fight for gender equality.
Photo: Hulton-Deutsch Collection/Corbis/Getty Images

This photo of Angela Merkel and other world leaders standing over Donald Trump at the G7 summit has gone viral. It's been likened to renaissance art and a scene from the Apprentice. Merkel‚Äôs office posted the picture on Instagram explaining how it was taken during a spontaneous meeting. The summit brought world leaders together from Germany, Japan, Canada, the US, Italy, France and the UK to discuss trade.
Photo: AFP Photo/Bundesregierung/Jesco Denzel

Volunteer medics are worried the white-coat strategy isn't working, after Gaza health worker Razan al-Najjar was shot dead by Israeli soldiers last week. The 21-year-old was the second medic to be killed in the last 10 weeks. She was an icon in Gaza, often portrayed with colourful headscarves and a determined expression on her face when helping wounded protesters. The white-coat strategy is a tactic used by Gaza's medics to prevent them from being shot by Israeli snipers. A preliminary Israeli investigation found ‚Äúno shots were deliberately or directly aimed toward‚Äù al-Najjar and Israeli officials have sought to discredit her by accusing her of helping terrorists.

Photos: Facebook & Oliver Holmes

TV chef Anthony Bourdain has died at the age of 61. He cultivated an image as a ‚Äúculinary bad boy‚Äù and delighted in eating from the extreme end of the food spectrum. CNN, who employed Bourdain, released a statement saying: "his love of great adventure, new friends, fine food and drink and the remarkable stories of the world made him a unique storyteller." In the UK, Samaritans can be contacted on 116 123. In the US, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is 1-800-273-8255. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international suicide helplines can be found at www.befrienders.org.

This is Spain's first female-majority government. 11 women and six men have been appointed to the new prime minister's cabinet. Pedro S√°nchez says his government is ‚Äúunmistakably committed to equality‚Äù and intends to reflect recent changes in Spanish society. Citing Spain's nationwide feminist strike on 8 March as marking ‚Äúa before and an after‚Äù in gender equality, he added: ‚ÄúThe new government is a faithful reflection of that movement.‚Äù Photos: J J Guillen/AFP/Getty

Saudi Arabia has issued its first driving licenses to 10 women, as it prepares to lift the world's only ban on female drivers in three weeks' time. The women already held licenses from other countries, and were issued with the licenses in the capital, Riyadh after a brief driving exam and eye test. Across the country Saudi women are preparing for the right to drive on 24 June by taking driving courses on female-only college campuses. However, several activists who campaigned for the right to drive remain under arrest, are facing possible trial. Activists say prominent women‚Äôs rights campaigners were targeted.

Photo: AP

Late last year, the South African government announced that ‚ÄòDay Zero‚Äô was looming. This is a moment, after three years of unprecedented drought, when dam levels would be so low that taps would be turned off and people would have to fetch water at communal collection points. After taking remedial measures, Capetonians managed to push back the date of Day Zero until next year. We went to find out how the apocalyptic notion has changed lives across the city.
Video: @katyaochagavia + @melaniegouby

This is the moment Malian migrant Mamoudou Gassame was presented with the Grand Vermeil medal by the mayor of Paris. The medal is awarded to people who have achieved a "remarkable act concerning the capital." Gassama was labelled "Spider-Man" after scaling four floors of an apartment block with his bare hands to rescue a child. He has now begun a new life as a trainee fireman after joining the Paris fire service.

Photo: Francois Guillot/AFP/Getty Images

Avoiding meat and dairy products is the single biggest way to reduce your environmental impact on the planet. New research shows that without meat and dairy consumption, global farmland use could be reduced by more than 75% ‚Äì an area equivalent to the US, China, European Union and Australia combined ‚Äì and we could still feed the world. Loss of wild areas to agriculture is the leading cause of the current mass extinction of wildlife. "My personal opinion is we should interpret these results not as the need to become vegan overnight, but rather to moderate our consumption", said Dr Peter Alexander from the University of Edinburgh.

The roads of S√£o Paulo were filled with rainbow flags, wigs and makeup on Sunday for the city's 22nd annual gay pride parade. This year's theme was Power for the LGBT ‚Äî Our Vote, Our Voice, with focus on Brazil's national elections in October. Brazil is home to the world's largest gay parade and legalised gay marriage in 2013, but the country still has a strong conservative streak, which has partly been blamed for an all-time high in violent deaths of LGBT people in 2017.

Photo: Nelson Antoine/AP

Today marks one year since the London Bridge terrorist attack, which killed eight people. Christopher Chessun, the bishop of Southwark, who will address a service of commemoration this afternoon, said that ‚Äúeven within those eight minutes of terror, the seeds of hope were being sown by those behaving so bravely, standing their ground, refusing to let terror triumph ‚Äì at enormous cost.‚Äù

Four Greenpeace activists descended by ropes from the ceiling as the Total chief executive Patrick Pouyann√© began his presentation. They hijacked the oil company's meeting in Paris to protest its plans to drill in the mouth of the Amazon and French Guiana. At least 250 others chained themselves to fixtures in the hall and protested outside the venue. Total wants to explore Brazil‚Äôs Foz do Amazonas basin, which geologists estimate could contain up to 14bn barrels of oil, more than the entire proven reserves in the Gulf of Mexico. 
Photos: Reuters

Competitors in the Scripps National Spelling Bee often struggle to contain their emotions when asked to spell complicated words. This year‚Äôs contest featured a record 515 young people, 16 of whom advanced to Thursday night‚Äôs finals. 14-year-old Karthik Nemmani from Texas romped to victory after his opponent failed to spell ‚Äòbewusstseinslage‚Äô.
Photos: Cliff Owen/AP

The skeleton of a man trying to flee the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD has been found crushed by an enormous stone. Pompeii officials estimate the victim to be over 30 and say a leg infection may have caused walking difficulties and impeded his escape before the large block of stone was ‚Äúviolently thrown by the volcanic cloud‚Äù. The site's general director Massimo Osanna called it "an exceptional find‚Äù that contributes to a better ‚Äúpicture of the history and civilisation of the age‚Äù.
Photos: Ciro Fusco/EPA

Wheelchair ballroom dancer Cheryl Angelelli and her partner Tamerlan Gadirov have been leading training sessions at the Fred Astaire Dance Studio in Michigan. They took second place last year at an international competition in Germany and hope para dance will become an official sport in the 2028 Paralympics. 
Photos: Carlos Osorio/AP

It's the final day of a public inquiry into the Grenfell Tower fire, which claimed 72 lives last year. Friends and families have been paying tribute to victims, including Sakineh Afrasehabi‚Äôs son. "The night when she was burning, she told me not to come", he recounted, "even though she was being burned by fire and smoke, she told me not to come. In one sentence she taught me something I couldn‚Äôt find in any books - the meaning of life. If you want to know the meaning of love - unconditional love - look on the face of your mother."

This is Mia Noblet, a Canadian slackliner, balancing on a long line in high heels. The Tianmen Mountain Female High-Heeled Highline challenge requires competitors to cross a 60-metre line over Zhangjiajie national forest in China. How's that for a challenge? 
Photos: VCG via Getty

Ireland has voted by a landslide to legalise abortion in a stunning outcome that marks a dramatic defeat for the Catholic church‚Äôs one-time domination of the Republic. Orla O‚ÄôConnor, the co-director of the Together for Yes campaign, said it was ‚Äúa monumental day for women in Ireland‚Äù, calling the result ‚Äúa rejection of an Ireland that treats women as second-class citizens‚Äù.
Photo: Niall Carson/PA

Nguyen Thi Kim Ngoc is often visited by her granddaughters in her 6.7 square-metre home in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Tucked away in winding alleys, hidden under new developments and sandwiched between street food stalls and shops, families are trying to keep their postage stamp-sized plots as Vietnam's busy southern hub continues to develop.

Photos: Thanh Nguyen

Full funeral rites from the monks of Bangkok's Wat Krathum Suea Pla temple used to be for humans only, until a new and lucrative market emerged. The pet funeral business is now booming, with the temple performing up to 300 a month. Buddhists believe that as part of the samsara life and death cycle, animals can potentially be reincarnated as humans. By giving their pets full rites, including prayers for forgiveness, a blessing by a monk and filling the coffin with fake gold, many owners hope to give them a better chance of returning to this world in a higher form. Follow @guardiancities for more stories from Bangkok. 
Photos: Cory Wright

The world‚Äôs 7.6 billion people represent just 0.01% of all living things, yet since the dawn of civilisation, humanity has caused the loss of 83% of all wild mammals and half of all plants. The study by Professor Ron Milo also reveals that livestock and poultry kept by humans exceed the number of wild animals. "I would hope people would take this as part of their world view of how they consume,‚Äù said Milo.

Visitors across Manchester have been adding messages of tribute, solidarity and love to Japanese maple trees on the one year anniversary of the Manchester Arena attack. 28 trees form the Trees of Hope that trail from the city's Victoria station to St Ann‚Äôs Square. Every message will be preserved and kept in an archive of the city's response to the attack.
Photos: Christopher Thomond

Pro-democracy protesters in Thailand have clashed with police after being blocked from marching to Government House during a rally in Bangkok. Hundreds of protesters marked the fourth anniversary of the military coup led by the general Prayuth Chan-ocha. Prayuth‚Äôs junta government enjoyed public support when taking power in 2014, but criticism of its repressive policies and lack of transparency has grown. Elections have been promised in 2019, but similar election promises have been broken in the past. 
Photos: Rungroj Yongrit/EPA

Thousands of people will mark the one year anniversary of the Manchester Arena attack today. Bells across Manchester will ring at 10.31 pm to mark the exact time 22 people lost their lives after an Ariana Grande concert.

"There has been much debate about whether Markle will actually make a difference to the monarchy and the future of race relations in this country. But this royal wedding is very different from the ones we have had before." - Guardian journalist Angela Foster

Photos: @alexilubomirski /PA Wire + @hugoburnand/Clarence House/PA Wire + PA + Alamy

The Duchess of Sussex has made her online debut on the palace website. The profile highlights her quote from the 2015 United Nations conference in New York: ‚ÄúI am proud to be a woman and a feminist.‚Äù As the fanfare dies down around the royal wedding, some people are asking how the duchess will continue to be vocal while retaining the neutrality of the royal family.
International human rights lawyer Amal Clooney at the #royalwedding. And her husband was there with her.
Don't see the appeal of the royal wedding? You're not alone. Tap the link in bio to understand it through the eyes of a republican.

Officials in the Democratic Republic of the Congo have said the Ebola outbreak in the vast central African country has entered ‚Äúa new phase‚Äù after a case of the deadly virus was detected in the north-west city of Mbandaka. The country‚Äôs ministry of health announced 11 new confirmed Ebola cases and two deaths, taking the total number of cases to 45 (14 confirmed, 10 suspected, 21 probable). The first batch of a newly developed vaccine was sent by the World Health Organisation to Kinshasa on Wednesday. The health ministry said vaccinations would start by early next week.
Photos: Mark Naftalin/AP + Kenny Katombe/Reuters

People gather in London for a demonstration in favour of extending abortion access in Ireland. Today marks a week until the landmark referendum on the 8th amendment that will decide whether women can get abortions up to a 12-week limit. Under current Republic of Ireland law, it's illegal unless a woman‚Äôs pregnancy poses an immediate threat to her life.

Are you voting to save/repeal the 8th? We want to hear your views. Email us at instagramstories@theguardian.com
Photo: @davidlevene

For hundreds of years, residents of Geel in Belgium have been giving a home to strangers with mental health problems. Maria Lenaerts (left) was seven years old when she came home from school one day to find a stranger, then 18 year-old Jefkae Harbant (centre), at the kitchen table. Harbant has been with the family for 76 years, and Lenaerts and her husband (right) became his foster family when her father died in 1982. This foster program started when a local church ran out of space to house people, so villagers began taking them in. One in four people will experience mental health problems in their lives with the majority saying their pain is deepened by social stigma.
Photos: @judithjockel

It will take more than ash plume from the Kilauea volcano on Hawaii's Big Island to disrupt a game of golf. Since the volcano erupted on 3 May, officials have warned residents to stay away from the southeastern part of the Big Island. The US Geological Survey have issued a red alert, suggesting a major eruption will happen soon. 
Photo: Mario Tama/Getty Images

82 women working in the film industry held a silent protest at the Cannes film festival last weekend to highlight the lack of female directors in the programme. The number of women was chosen to match the amount of female filmmakers whose films have appeared in competition at the festival in its 71-year history. In that time, 1,645 male directors have seen their films selected. ‚ÄúWomen are not a minority in the world, yet the current state of our industry says otherwise,‚Äù they said in a statement. ‚ÄúAs women, we all face our own unique challenges, but we stand together on these stairs today as a symbol of our determination and commitment to progress.‚Äù

Protesters gathered outside the US Consulate General in Johannesburg, South Africa today to demonstrate against the killing of at least 59 Palestinians by Israeli forces. Senior UN officials have condemned the killings as an ‚Äúoutrageous human rights violation‚Äù. Watch our Instagram Story for more information.
Photo: @gulshanii

London is considering introducing car-free days in an attempt to tackle the city‚Äôs air pollution crisis. Details are still being hammered out but the hope is to introduce separate car-free days in each London borough this year, with the potential for city-wide car-free days next year. London‚Äôs air pollution crisis is responsible for 9,000 early deaths a year. New figures show that every person in the capital is breathing air that exceeds global guidelines for one of the most dangerous toxic particles.

Israeli forces have killed dozens of Palestinians after protests against the opening of the US embassy in Jerusalem. It's been the deadliest day in Gaza since the 2014 war with an estimated 52 Palestinians killed. President Donald Trump's decision to move the US embassy has upset Palestinians, who see East Jerusalem as the capital of a future independent state. There is still a lack of basic provisions like medicines, clean water and electricity in Gaza, with many homes and infrastructure left destroyed. 
Photos: Mustafa Hassona, Amir Cohen, Alaa Badarneh

For the third Friday in a row Spanish newsreaders are wearing black in protest against alleged political interference, gender bias and unequal pay at public broadcaster RTVE. They believe that the ruling conservative People's party is meddling in the channel's coverage and say that they are "suffering the consequences of sexism and are not prepared to keep working under unequal conditions." Photos: RTVE

How do you prevent girls from dropping out of school and marrying young? PE teacher Dogan Deniz Celebi set up the Malatya Women‚Äôs Sports Club in Turkey to keep girls in education. Malatya is a largely poor, conservative city with most girls dropping out of school in their early teens to work in apricot processing. They also end up marrying very young and domestic violence and drug abuse is common. Celebi has spent most of his modest teacher's salary on keeping the club alive, but it's unclear how long he can keep it going. He blames a lack of support for women's football in Turkey on the country's gender inequality. Despite gaining the vote in 1934, Turkish society still marginalises women. The World Economic Forum ranks Turkey 130th out of 144 countries for gender equality.

Photo: Patrick Keddie

Orangutans in Indonesia face an uncertain future because of the continued deforestation of the country's rainforests by palm oil producers. Naturalist and nature photographer @chris.packham says that 100,000 Bornean orangutans have been lost in the last 16 years alone. All three Orangutan species - Bornean, Sumatran and the Tanauli, are now on the critically endangered list. Global demand for palm oil has increased six-fold since 1990, and it is now included in half of all packaged supermarket products.

Photo: Alejo Sabugo/International Animal Rescue

Nationalist politician Meral Ak≈üener is the only credible candidate running against Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan in the upcoming Turkish elections. Polls show an easy victory for Erdoƒüan in the first round, but a much tighter race within the margin of error in the second round if he is pitted against Ak≈üener. Ak≈üener has pledged to put the country‚Äôs relations with the EU back on track and to restore the rule of law in Turkey, where freedoms have been curtailed under a state of emergency since a failed coup attempt in July 2016. Ak≈üener has to contend with the ultranationalist and racist history of her political forebears, a legacy that has earned her party comparisons with Europe‚Äôs populist, anti-immigrant wave, a charge she denies.
Photo: @muradsezer/Reuters

Four former Chelsea youth footballers who claim they were subjected to racist abuse have received public backing from two white players who were at the club. Grant Lunn and Gary Baker have come forward in support of the group who have chosen to remain anonymous. One player says he was so traumatised by his experiences that he can't even watch them play on television because of the flashbacks he suffers.

Would ¬£10,000 make a lasting difference to you? Thinktank Resolution Foundation has proposed giving millennials that sum each each to tackle the UK's generational gap. The ‚Äúcitizen‚Äôs inheritance‚Äù described is intended to redistribute wealth at a time when young people need it most for housing, education or to start a business. The hope is it would also reduce resentment towards baby boomers (born 1946-65) who have typically done better out of the housing market and pensions than subsequent generations. Tap the link in bio to read why Iman Amrani disagrees.

As Cannes begins, the majority woman jury of this year's Festival de Cannes is being seen as a step in the right direction for equality. Cate Blanchett is president of the jury which includes actors Kristen Stewart and L√©a Seydoux, Selma director Ava DuVernay and Burundian musician Khadja Ni. However, of the 21-film official selection for this year, only three are directed by women. "The selection committee now has more women on board than in previous years, which will obviously change the lens through which the films are chosen. But these things are not going to happen overnight," said Blanchett.

This is Umm Mizrah holding her son at the Al-Sadaqa hospital in Yemen. The 25-year-old is severely underweight as she enters the second trimester of her pregnancy. Her 17-month-old son is also just half the normal weight for a boy his age. The ongoing conflict between Yemen's Shia rebels, known as Houthis, and the Saudi-led coalition has driven the country to the brink of famine. More than 10,000 civilians have been killed, with another 3 million people forced to leave their homes, since the fighting started three years ago. Martin Griffiths, the UN's new envoy to Yemen, recently said he hoped to rekindle peace talks in the war-torn country.

Photo: Nariman El-Mofty/AP

Writer and actor @lenawaithe stood out on the Met Gala red carpet wearing a suit and LGBTQ pride-flag cape designed by @carolinaherrera. Waithe recently made history as the first black woman to win an Emmy for writing. The award-winning 'Thanksgiving' episode of Master of None was based on her own coming-out process that spanned over a decade of Thanksgiving dinners, but Waithe almost didn‚Äôt write the episode. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think my coming out was that interesting". Photos: @andrewhwalker/REX/Shutterstock + 
Justin Lane/EPA

May 1968 in France is remembered for student protests that gave way to unauthorised strikes where over 9 million workers brought France to a standstill. Students and workers were disillusioned by the leadership of President Charles de Gaulle and an oppressively hierarchical society. 50 years later, student sit-ins against university admissions, train strikes over changes to state railways, and opposition to a new immigration law mark a similar mood among some French citizens.

Photo: AFP Photo

Travellers at London's Heathrow airport were surprised by otherworldly messaging in honour of #StarWarsDay. Today's departure board destinations included Tatooine (flight no. R2D2), Deathstar ‚Äì passengers were warned to 'allow extra time for boarding ... possibly a trap' ‚Äì and Alderaan where the flight status simply read, 'Cancelled'.
Photos: @quickshotofficial + @heathrow_airport

More than 1,000 people have been ordered to evacuate on Hawaii‚Äôs Big Island after the eruption of the Kilauea volcano led to lava flows into residential areas. Since Monday, hundreds of earthquakes ‚Äì most of them about 2.0 magnitude ‚Äì have been recorded in the area. Officials said it was impossible to predict how long the eruption would last.

Photos: Kevan KamibayashiAFP/Getty Images + AP

Selling boxes and scrap is the only way some older citizens are able to get by in Hong Kong. According to research at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, the city now has the longest life expectancy in the world ‚Äì 81.3 years for men and 87.3 years for women. But one third of Hong Kong‚Äôs elderly live in poverty, and public funds from the government are considered too low. Critics have been campaigning for a universal state pension for everyone regardless of their income, but this has yet to materialise.

Protestors took to the streets in Spain after last week‚Äôs incendiary acquittal of five men on rape charges in Pamplona. Urged by journalist Cristina Fallar√°s, women spoke up about sexual violence using hashtag #Cu√©ntalo (tell it). The message was picked up across the Atlantic by hundreds of thousands of Latin American women to denounce the rampant gender violence blighting their region and their lives. Each day 12 Latin American women are victims of murder, according to the UN‚Äôs Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean.

Photo: Xabier Lertxundi/AFP/Getty Images

Musician Will.i.am has spoken out against Kanye West, after the rapper suggested that enslavement of African Americans over 400 years may have been a "choice." In the interview, West spoke about his support for Donald Trump, free thinking and labels before his slavery comments caused a newsroom confrontation. West later tried to clarify his comments on social media, saying he knew slaves were not put on boats by free will, but that to have stayed in that position for centuries meant that they were mentally enslaved. Later he tweeted that he was once again being "attacked for presenting new ideas."

Live in England? Don't forget to visit your polling station tomorrow 3 May between 7am-10pm to cast your vote in the local elections. People are really engaged in politics at the moment with intention to vote at an all-time high of 62%. It matters who runs your council for the sake of everyone who relies on good services, including education, transport and policing. So remember to make your vote count üó≥üëå

Claire Foy will receive backpay for her performance in The Crown after it was revealed that co-star Matt Smith was paid more, even though he had a supporting role. Now the makers of the Netflix drama are attempting to close the gender pay gap. In 2017 Emma Stone topped the best-paid actress list on ¬£19m ($US26m), while Mark Wahlberg was the highest paid man, with ¬£49m ($US68m) in estimated annual earnings.

These people are demanding an end to violence in Nicaragua. Human rights groups say at least 26 people have been killed during several days of anti-government protests and clashes with the police. The unrest was triggered by social security reforms designed to reduce benefits and increase taxes. Alleged electoral fraud in Nicaragua has allowed president Daniel Ortega to control the country's national assembly and make important changes to the constitution, including his own right to serve more than two terms.

Photos: @cabezasphoto/Reuters

The world‚Äôs oldest known spider, known as Number 16, has died at the ripe old age of 43 after being monitored for years during a long-term population study in Australia. Number 16 was among other trapdoor spiders monitored in the wild. The observation of the species helped scientists unlock the key to their extensive life span, which is credited to "how they live in uncleared, native bushland, their sedentary nature and low metabolisms,‚Äù Mason said. The spider did not die of old age but was killed by a wasp sting, researchers said.

Photo: Leanda Mason/AFP/Getty Images

Gideon Mendel's Drowning World is one of 15 works being shown in unique spaces at the Kyotographie photography festival. Presented in a former ice factory and anchored by a series of portraits and videos, Mendel seeks to connect people affected by flooding and the catastrophic impact of industrial and environmental change. Tap the link in bio to see more from the festival.

Photos: @_takeshiasano / @gideonmendel

Amber Rudd has resigned as home secretary after more than 200 MPs signed a letter accusing her of making up immigration policy ‚Äúon the hoof‚Äù in an effort to overcome the Windrush scandal. The Windrush generation arrived in the UK after the second world war from Caribbean countries at the invitation of the British government. Until recently, an estimated 50,000 of them faced the risk of deportation if they hadn't formalised their residency status or didn't have the required documentation to prove it. Many people lost their jobs and were even held in detention centres. The problem stems from a policy set out by Theresa May when she was home secretary to make the UK "a really hostile environment for illegal immigrants".

It's a great day for bees in Europe as one of the world's most widely used insecticides has been banned by the EU. The ban on neonicotinoids is expected to come into force by the end of 2018 and will mean they can only be used in closed greenhouses. Pesticides pose a major threat to bees, which are vital for global food production.
Photo: Altaf Qadri

Hundreds of thousands of lifejackets were left on Greek shores after more than 850,000 refugees arrived by sea in 2015. When @makersunite.eu heard about the problem, they decided to bring 5,000 lifejackets to Amsterdam. Over the past year, as part of a coaching programme to help refugees establish careers in the Netherlands, 71 refugees have been involved in making and selling products upcycled from the lifejackets. One of these refugees is Ramzi Aloker from Damascus. ‚ÄúThese bags can tell people about the tragedy taking place between Damascus and Europe. It might get people thinking about the dangers we faced and why we are here.‚Äù
Photos: Thessa Lageman

Gandhinagar railway station in Jaipur, India is the only station run entirely by women. These ticket-sellers, station masters and conductors are bucking the trend in a country where women are quitting the workforce at an alarming rate. They hope to inspire a generation of girls passing through the station.

Photos: Sajjad Hussain/AFP/Getty Images

The UK‚Äôs biggest food bank network gave out a record 1.3m food parcels to an estimated 666,000 people in 2017-18, up 13% on the previous year. Many people claiming universal credit had come to food banks after administrative problems and long waits for payment had pushed them into debt, ill health and rent arrears. The report said: ‚ÄúPeople are falling through the cracks in a system not made to hold them. What little support available is primarily offered by the third sector, whose work is laudable, but cannot be a substitute for a real, nationwide safety net.‚Äù

Mourners pay their respects to victims of the Toronto van incident. 10 people were killed and 15 injured after they were hit by a rental van, driven along the sidewalk in Toronto for more than 2km. The suspect was taken into custody after being arrested in a dramatic confrontation with a police officer.
Photos: @dchanyyz/Sipa USA/REX/Shuttershock

Participants and visitors gathered in Dunbar, Scotland for the 2018 European Stone Stacking Championship, one of Europe's largest competitions. The activity is considered a meditative artistic skill that promotes a balanced mind (and stack). Locations next to bodies of water are popular as they offer lots of natural materials to work with. Categories include 'most stones balanced one on top of the other' and 'most artistic balance'.
Photo: @andy_buchanan_photos/AFP/Getty Images

Tributes have been paid to Verne Troyer who died on Saturday, aged 49. The actor racked up 30 film credits in a career spanning 24 years. A statement on his Facebook page said "Verne hoped he made a positive change with the platform he had, and worked towards spreading that message everyday." Photo: Matt Carr/Getty Images

Firefighters who responded to the Grenfell Tower fire last year ran the London Marathon this weekend to raise money for people affected by the fire. Some ran in full gear, wearing an extra 30kg of weight. 71 people are now known to have died in the worst residential fire that the @londonfirebrigade has ever dealt with. 
Photos: London Fire Brigade/Twitter/PA Wire

Somaliland poet Naima Abwaan Qorane has been jailed for three years for ‚Äúanti-national activity of a citizen and bringing the nation or state in contempt‚Äù. Prosecutors said she had expressed opinions on social media that undermined the semi-autonomous state‚Äôs claim to full independence. Activist Said Abdi Hassan says that Qorane ‚Äúis a role model for many of our youth by calling for unity and against tribalism.‚Äù Since December, there has been a series of arrests and detentions of activists, bloggers and writers in Somaliland.

25 years ago today a gang of white men plunged a knife into the chest of 18-year-old Stephen Lawrence. The police investigation that followed the murder was later exposed as incompetent and racist ‚Äì with arrests only made two weeks after the stabbing despite locals giving names of the suspects. Only the extraordinary determination of Stephen‚Äôs parents, Doreen and Neville, confronted the wider public with the reality of racism, influencing the debate on UK race relations for decades to come.
Photo: Sean Smith

Scientists have finally uncovered the secret behind the Bajau people's ability to hold their breath underwater for up to five minutes. Over time, they've undergone natural selection, resulting in certain versions of genes becoming widespread. Many of these genes are linked to biological changes, eg having a larger spleen. The discovery could eventually prove useful in medical scenarios, potentially allowing experts to identify patients that might be at greater risk of death if they experience a lack of oxygen.
Photo: @jamesmorganfoto

New Zealand prime minister @JacindaArdern walked the halls of Buckingham Palace in a traditional MƒÅori cloak adorned with feathers during this week‚Äôs meeting with Commonwealth heads of government. The MƒÅori cloak is bestowed on chiefs and dignitaries to convey prestige, respect and power. In the MƒÅori world, birds are given the task of carrying spiritual messages between the gods and people, and their feathers are prized and sacred.
Photos: Toby Melville AFP/Getty Images + Reuters
Have spring colours started to blossom in your neighbourhood? Check out this view of more than 30 million tulips at the Holland Sea of Flowers in Yancheng, China.

Saudi Arabia has lifted a 35-year ban on cinemas with an invitation-only showing of Black Panther. Public viewings will begin soon, according to cinema company AMC, who plans to open at least 40 more locations in the country over the next few years. Saudi Arabia had some cinemas in the 1970s but its powerful clerics closed them, reflecting rising Islamist influence throughout the Arab region at the time. The lifting of the ban comes as Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman promotes an image of an evolving regime in order to pique interest in political and economic investment in the capital of Riyadh. 
Photos: Majed Al-Malki

Peking University, China‚Äôs top academic institution, admitted this month that a professor was involved in ‚Äúinappropriate student-teacher relations‚Äù with a female student 20 years ago. Former classmates of that student say she was raped and the assault pushed her to kill herself less than a year later. #Metoo is now a fledgling movement in Chinese universities and campaigners, including Zheng Xi (pictured), are beginning to make their voices heard.

In the UK, Samaritans can be contacted on 116 123. In the US, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is 1-800-273-8255. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international suicide helplines can be found at www.befrienders.org.

@KendrickLamar has won a Pulitzer prize for music, which up until now, was almost exclusively awarded to classical scores. Lamar's album Damn addresses issues including black empowerment, protest and the Trump presidency and proved that it‚Äôs possible to make a huge mainstream impact with music that doesn't underestimate its audience‚Äôs intelligence. The @nytimes and @newyorkermag were also honoured with the Pulitzer prize for public service for investigating accusations of sexual harassment against Harvey Weinstein.

Andrew Merry shot these aerial photographs of sprawling new suburbia in Sydney 12 years ago. "People just assumed they were in America. It really struck them that this was Australia ‚Äì they couldn't believe it", he recalls. For more great photos of Australian cities follow @guardiancities 
Photos: Andrew Merry

Andrew Follows is an Australian photographer who was born with a rare genetic disorder, retinitis pigmentosa, that leaves the retina unable to sufficiently process light. Blind in one eye and with poor vision in the other, he relies on sound and his guide dog Leo to compose his images of the Commonwealth Games. ‚ÄúThe camera has really become my eyes and allowed me to see what everybody else can see". Follow @guardian_sport for more action. 
Photos: Carly Earl
Looking for a podcast to inspire you? Tap the link in bio to hear from people who believe hope > fear.

@amivitale has won first prize in the World Press Photo nature stories category. The image shows a rescued baby elephant being tended at the Reteti Elephant Sanctuary in northern Kenya. The sanctuary lies in a region where different ethnic groups have fought over the land and its resources. But the groups have started working together to protect the 6,000 elephants they live alongside. 
Photo: Ami Vitale/National Geographic/World Press Photo

The number of homeless people who have died in the UK has risen from 31 in 2013 to 70 in 2017. At least 230 people have died in the last five years. The figures are likely to be a substantial underestimate, because the UK government doesn't record homeless death statistics at a national level, and local authorities aren't required to count rough sleeper deaths. Experts have blamed rising rents, welfare cuts and a lack of social housing for the rise, and urge the government to address the root causes of poverty in the UK.

Lorenzo Meloni is one of four photographers visiting Red Cross camps to document the impact of a nine-year Boko Haram insurgency which has left 20,000 people dead and around 8 million people in need of aid. Nigerian politician Kashim Shettima says that ‚Äúbeneath the mayhem of Boko Haram, underneath the nihilism, lies the real problem, which is extreme poverty. Once you engage the youth, once you create jobs, this madness will evaporate.‚Äù
Photo: Lorenzo Meloni / Magnum Photos

Following a petition set up by local women, Ealing council in west London has voted for the UK's first 'safe zone' around an abortion clinic. They hope the move will shield women from being intimidated and harassed by anti-abortion protesters outside a local clinic. It could also pave way for councils across the country to take similar action. The Catholic anti-abortion Good Counsel Network has held regular protests outside the clinic, which have included handing women teddy bears and calling them ‚Äúmum‚Äù. Photos: John Stillwell/PA Wire, Sister Supporter & Andy Hall

At least 42 people were killed on Saturday in a toxic gas attack in Douma near Damascus, Syria. Nearly 2,000 civilians have been killed in a two-month campaign by Syrian president Bashar al-Assad‚Äôs forces to oust rebels and the opposition from their last stronghold. Donald Trump warned there will be a ‚Äúbig price to pay‚Äù for the chemical strike and the UK and France have called for an urgent meeting of the United Nations security council.
Photo: Anadolu Agency/Getty Images

Wildlife rescuers and volunteers worked for over 20 hours over the weekend to free a stranded humpback whale in Mar del Plata, a city on Argentina‚Äôs Atlantic coast. Sadly the rescue efforts were not enough to save it in the end. While humpback whales were once hunted to the brink of extinction, the numbers have recovered in recent years, but entanglement in fishing gear and collisions with sea vessels continue to threaten its existence. 
Photos: Xinhua/REX/Shutterstock, Pablo Hugo Funes & Reuters

A scientific study has found a 30% drop in plastic bags on the seabed around Britain following the introduction of a 5p levy per bag in 2015. The authors of the study, published in the Science of the Total Environment journal, said "If we all work together towards a better environment, we can make changes. A lot of people live in doom, but (‚Ä¶) don‚Äôt give up yet.‚Äù

Maher Attar was recently reunited with Samar Baltaji 33 years after his portrait of her made the cover of the New York Times. Attar took the portrait of Samar and her daughter as they walked through Beirut during the civil war. Samar, now a double amputee, has turned to begging to provide for her family. Maher says the chance meeting has left him with a ‚Äúpersonal duty‚Äù to help Samar. ‚ÄúNow I know she needs help.‚Äù Photos: @sam7tarling + @bymaherattar

Swipe right to find out what the gender pay gap means for both men and women. 
Video: @eleni.stefanou + @jamesdrewturner + @bruno.rinvolucri

For her book Perfect Imperfection,‚Äã‚Äã ‚Äãpet photographer‚Äã‚Äã Alex Cearns‚Äã (@houndstoothstudio)‚Äã ‚Äãset‚Äã ‚Äãout to capture the personalities of animals who ‚Äãadapt‚Äãed‚Äã to their damaged or different bodies‚Äã without complaint‚Äã.‚Äã ‚ÄòThese are the creatures who have lost a leg, been born without eyes, or are still showing the scars of former abuse,' she says. ‚ÄòThey push on, wanting to be included and involved in everything as much as they can,‚Äô ‚Äã Part of the proceeds from sales of Perfect Imperfection go to the Australian Animal Cancer Foundation‚Äã. ‚ÄãF‚Äãollow the link in our bio‚Äã to see more pictures and find out more information about Alex, her book and the foundation‚Äã.‚Äã

The Commonwealth Games have begun on the Gold Coast in Australia. The opening ceremony took place yesterday at the Carrara Stadium and the same venue will host the closing ceremony on 15 April, but not before more than 4,500 athletes from 71 nations have competed for 275 gold medals. Follow @guardian_sport for all of our sports coverage. 
#sport #goldcoast #commonwealthgames #australia #gymnastics #swimming

Maya Angelou was born on this day in 1928. She published more than 10 volumes of poetry, composed songs for musicals and films and wrote scripts for more than a dozen plays, films and television programmes.

Shakila Zareen, 23, lost much of her face after being shot by her husband in Afghanistan. After multiple surgeries in India, her offer of resettlement in the United States was withdrawn for 'security-related reasons'. Zareen has now settled in Vancouver, Canada, where she plans to start a new life despite her fear of repercussions from her husband. "I‚Äôm stronger now,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúso I‚Äôm not going to be silent.‚Äù
Photo: Radar Akbar

When you have to flee your home, what do you take with you? More than 688,000 Rohingya people have escaped to Bangladesh since August 2017. @briansokol photographed some of them, along with the items that mean the most to them. 
Photos: @briansokol/UNHCR

These schoolchildren in Liverpool thought they were taking part in a sports commentary competition, so they were very surprised when @liverpoolfc player Mohamed Salah burst through the wall. Follow @guardian_sport for more action. 
Photos: Andrew Powell/Liverpool FC/Getty Images

Malala Yousafzai, the youngest Nobel peace laureate, has made an emotional return to her native country Pakistan. It's her first time back since she was shot by a Taliban gunman in 2012 for advocating education for girls. Since then, she's become a global symbol for human rights and a vocal campaigner for girls‚Äô education.

Photo: Facundo Arrizabalaga/EPA

Thousands of people gathered at Pushkinskaya Square in Moscow to pay tribute to the victims of the Siberian shopping centre fire that killed at least 64 people, including 41 children. Investigators said the fire alarm system in the shopping centre had been out of order since 19 March and a security guard failed to turn on the public address system to warn people to evacuate the building.
Photo: Mladen Antonov/AFP/Getty Images

In Japan, there's a long-held tradition of enjoying the blooming of cherry trees. The blossom only lasts for about a week and marks the beginning of spring. The short-lived existence of the blossom is also said to symbolise how fleeting life is.
Photo: Carl Court/Getty Images

Vietnamese pop star and pro-democracy campaigner Mai Khoi has been detained by the country's authorities, as part of a crackdown on dissidents in the one-party communist state. The singer has previously been harassed, evicted and had her concerts shut down for her outspoken views. During Donald Trump's visit last year, Mai Khoi held up a banner along his motorcade route. Vietnam's media is heavily censored and bloggers and activists are often threatened or intimidated.

Photo: Bennett Murray

Linda Brown, the girl at the centre of the 1954 ruling that ended school segregation in America, has died at the age of 76. After several black families in Topeka, Kansas were turned down when trying to enrol their children in white schools near their homes, Brown's father became the lead plaintiff in Brown v Board of Education. This landmark case led to the supreme court's unanimous decision that separating black and white children was unconstitutional. Kansas deputy education commissioner Dale Dennis said Brown‚Äôs legacy was not only in the state but nationwide. "The effect she had on our society would be unbelievable and insurmountable.‚Äù Photo: AP

Dogs were recently invited to an exclusive screening of Wes Anderson's Isle of Dogs film at @thecameocinema in Edinburgh. It was the first time water bowls and blankets were in higher demand than popcorn. Any howls or growls from the screen were met by answering barks from the audience. 
Photos: Murdo Macleod

These three women are among 3,000 prisoners recently pardoned by Zimbabwean President Emmerson Mnangagwa. Most female inmates have been released in Mnangagwa's first act of clemency. The move comes just months before the presidential elections. The Zimbabwe Prisons and Correctional Services says the country's prisons have around 20,000 inmates, but the holding capacity is only 17,000. 
Photo: Philimon Bulawayo

Tributes have been paid to policeman Lieutenant-Colonel Arnaud Beltrame and the other three victims of the attack on a supermarket in the French town of Trebes last Friday. It is reported that Beltrame swapped places with a hostage during the siege. 
Photos: Eric Cabanis

Skiers in eastern Europe were greeted by these eerie scenes at ski resorts over the weekend, as dust from a sandstorm in the Sahara desert caused snow to turn orange. Meteorologists say this happens about every five years, and is caused by sand, dust and pollen being stirred up and swept across from storms in northern Africa.
Photos: @katrin.jd @margarita_alshina @ksusha_knopik & @sinyaya_ptiza

This massive area of rubbish floating in the Pacific Ocean is more proof that plastic is a threat to the world's oceans. The Great Pacific garbage patch is over twice the size of France and contains at least 79,000 tonnes of plastic. Around eight million tonnes end up in the ocean every year. Dutch non-profit organisation @theoceancleanup is trying to tackle the garbage patch. It is estimated that there will be more waste plastic in the sea than fish by 2050.

Photos: The Ocean Clean Up, AFP & Getty Images
Swipe right to watch five of the most powerful speeches from the #MarchForOurLives anti-gun protest.

Today, in Washington DC and more than 830 places worldwide, people of all ages came together to demand solutions to gun violence in America. Follow @guardian_us for more coverage.
Photo: Evelyn Hockstein

Student journalists from Parkland, Florida are guest editing @Guardian_US ahead of the @marchforourlives protest against gun violence. They‚Äôll be reporting from Washington as Guardian correspondents, interviewing Bernie Sanders and exploring the impossible choice their teachers faced when a shooter entered their school. Tap the link in the bio to read their manifesto.

Photos: Ali Smith

Today is #WorldWaterDay and this year's theme is Nature for Water, which the UN has defined as ‚Äúexploring the nature-based solutions to the water challenges we face in the 21st century‚Äù. 2.1 billion people don't have access to clean drinking water and more than 800 million have to travel and queue for at least 30 minutes to access safe supplies. But progress is happening; the proportion of the world‚Äôs population with access to clean water near home has risen from 81% to 89% since 2000. 
Photo: Noah Seelam/AFP

Jason Barker's debut feature film, A Deal With The Universe, dives headfirst into his pregnancy as a trans man. Transmasculine pregnancies are becoming increasingly common despite being stigmatised as a novelty. Follow the link in bio to read Jason‚Äôs experience.

Which poems have you been enjoying today? 
#WorldPoetryDay

These visitors are busy exploring Leandro Erlich's Building installation at the @moriartmuseum in Tokyo. The Argentinian artist uses optical illusions and sound effects in his work to challenge visitors' ideas of reality. 
Photo: Toru Yamanaka

World Down Syndrome Day is dedicated to raising awareness of how people with the condition play an important role in our lives and communities. It's held on the 21st day of the third month of the year to highlight the uniqueness of the 21st chromosome, which causes Down's syndrome.

With Vladimir Putin securing a record win in the recent Russian presidential election, political punk group Pussy Riot released a new song attacking the country's corruption, censorship and erosion of democracy. The song Elections includes the lyrics "six years we're gonna fight, fight/ we're not gonna obey during this term." Pussy Riot have been outspoken critics of Putin for a long time, with members Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova both serving jail terms after an anti-Putin performance back in 2012. 
Photos: Christian Palma, Pedro Pardo, Hutton Supancic & Mikhail Metzel

Sudan, the last male northern white rhino, has died aged 45. Hopes for the species now rests on advanced IVF technologies, which will use stored semen and genetic data that could potentially impregnate the only two northern white rhinos left, Sudan's daughter Najin and granddaughter Fatu. It's another wake up call to the disastrous consequences of uncontrolled hunting and poaching. 
Photos: Dai Kurokawa, Thomas Mukoya & AP

Banksy has unveiled a mural in New York highlighting the case of a Turkish artist who was jailed for nearly three years over a painting. Zehra Doƒüan was reportedly imprisoned in 2017 for her painting of a damaged Turkish city. Doƒüan was sentenced to two years and 10 months in prison for painting the city Nusaybin damaged by state security forces, according to freedom of expression advocate PEN.

Photo: EPA/Jason Szenes

Gurgaon, a city 32km outside the Indian capital New Delhi, has risen from a former agricultural wasteland. The city was built almost entirely by private companies, but its people are made up of the two extremes of India‚Äôs developing society. @arthurcrestani‚Äôs Bad City Dreams contrasts the glossy ideal sold by developers with urban reality. @guardiancities

The traditional closing ceremony has brought the curtain down on the 2018 Winter Paralympics in Pyeongchang.

Photos: @naomibakerphoto/Getty Images, @thomaslovelock/Reuters & Adam Davy

Crowds of people in Rio de Janeiro have paid tribute to councillor and human rights activist Marielle Franco, who was shot dead after a political event earlier this week. Franco was a popular politician who focused on improving the lives of people living in Rio's favelas, areas affected by drug-related crime and police brutality. Amnesty International has called on the Brazilian state to guarantee "an immediate and rigorous investigation" of the assassination.

Photos: Mario Vasconcellos, Marcelo Sayao, Leo Correa, Leonardo Benassatto, Midia Ninja

A new piece of research looks at the way female and male leaders are treated on social media. Social enterprise Atalanta, which focuses on female representation in government, compared Theresa May to Jeremy Corbyn alongside pairs of female and male political leaders in South Africa and Chile. This is what they found.

Today marks seven years since the start of the Syrian uprisings, which lead to a harrowing civil war. An estimated half a million lives have been lost and, with calls for a ceasefire ignored, the violence shows no signs of ending. The United Nations warns of unprecedented levels of suffering in a country that has already witnessed so many crimes and so much desperation. For Syrians marking seven years of war this week, their country has never looked as helpless, fragmented and abandoned by the international community.

This is Hannah Njenga standing next to a sculpture by her husband Edward Njenga. The 95-year-old artist has made powerful social statements through his work, from the oppression Kenyans faced during British colonialism to his Portraits of Poverty, created during the country's post-independence period. Speaking about his wife Hannah, he said "it took nearly two years to convince her that we were meant for each other, and she finally came around." Photos: Yasuyoshi Chiba

Students across the US are walking out of class today, a month after the mass shooting in Parkland, Florida. Their protest will last 17 minutes to mark the 17 people who were killed on that day. According to event organisers, nearly 3,000 schools are taking part.

Stephen Hawking, the brightest star in science, whose insights shaped modern cosmology and inspired global audiences in the millions, has died aged 76.
Photo: Murdo Mcleod

Refugees and students from Paris' International Fashion Academy recently came together to design clothes for the Hope Walk fashion show at a temporary theatre set up near a centre for asylum seekers. All the outfits were made from unused clothes donated to Emmas Solidarit, the largest humanitarian charity in France. The aim of the project was to offer migrants a break from the loneliness and administrative problems they experience.
Photos: @justin_sutcliffe

Fashion giant Hubert de Givenchy has died at the age of 91. He dressed Audrey Hepburn and Jackie Kennedy and is famous for the little black dress. ‚ÄúThe dress must follow the body of a woman‚Äù, he once said, ‚Äúnot the body following the shape of the dress.‚Äù
Photos: Sunset Boulevard/Getty Images + Alamy Stock Photo

The world wide web turns 29 today. This year we're about to cross the tipping point when more than half of the world‚Äôs population will be online. Yet despite the UN declaring internet access a human right in 2016, you‚Äôre more likely to be offline if you are female, poor, live in a rural area or a low-income country, or some combination of the above.

University staff are striking over proposed changes to their pensions, which they argue could leave them up to ¬£10,000 a year worse off when they retire. The union says young lecturers would be worst affected, with some losing up to half their pensions. Universities UK (the representative organisation for UK universities) says its pension scheme has a ¬£6bn deficit and it has a legal duty to put a credible plan in place to tackle it by this summer. Many students are supportive of striking staff but are demanding compensation for the hours of tuition they will miss.
Photo: Jane Barlow/PA

Black Panther star Michael B Jordan is one of the first people to respond to Frances McDormand's call for inclusion riders during her Oscars speech. His production company will now include a clause in contracts that demand projects have diverse casts and crews. The idea of inclusion riders was proposed by Stacy L Smith of the Annenberg Inclusion Initiative, which found that just 4% of 1,100 top Hollywood movies were directed by women in the past decade, while 5.2% were directed by African Americans and 3.2% by directors of Asian descent. 
Photo: Tolga Akmen

A crowd of thousands gathered at Santa Croce Basilica in Florence for the funeral of Fiorentina captain Davide Astori yesterday. The popular footballer died last week. Both Fiorentina and former club Cagliari will retire Astori's number 13 shirt in his honour. Check out @guardian_sport for more sport stories and images.

Photos: Filippo Monteforte, Gianni Pasquini & Alessandro Bianchi

Happy International Women's Day! The mood this year feels different. There are loud conversations around harassment and pay inequality. Time‚Äôs Up and #MeToo have edged beyond hashtags into palpable anger and hunger for action. We‚Äôll be bringing you updates on the day as it rolls across the globe and you can also get in touch to share what‚Äôs going on where you are. Visit gu.com to follow and contribute to the live blog.
Illustration: @andreasillustrations

Recognise Us is an art installation in Southend-on-Sea, Essex that challenges the idea people with learning disabilities are invisible in local communities. Using stencils and spray paint, local people with learning disabilities created these portraits of themselves. They are now being released as postcards to celebrate the exhibition's success, and to raise more awareness of the active roles people with learning disabilities have in their communities. 
Photos: Ian Chapman/ Southend Care

12-year-old¬†Sahin Suna has been breeding birds for four years. He was spotted with one of his doves at a pigeon market in¬†Sanliurfa, Turkey.¬†Pigeon breeding in Turkey has been a pastime for hundreds of years and prized birds can fetch up to 3,500 lira (¬£665).
Photo: Fatih Aktas/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images

These billboards appeared the morning after election day in Italy. It looks like two relatively new political parties are rising in in the country: the anti-establishment Five Star Movement (M5S), which early results showed had 31% of the vote, and the anti-migrant and Eurosceptic League, formerly known as the Northern League, which performed far better than expected. While the former prime minister Silvio Berlusconi had been seen as leading the centre-right coalition, early results showed he was beaten by his younger rival on the right, Matteo Salvini, following a campaign in which Salvini emphasised support for radical immigration policies, including mass deportations of immigrants who are in Italy illegally.
Photo: Riccardo De Luca/AP

Last year, Donald Trump announced he would end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (Daca) program, which allows people brought to the country illegally as children to apply for renewable two-year work permits. Established in 2012, Daca shields 690,000 people from deportation. They certainly weren't forgotten at the Oscars last night - Guillermo del Toro, Lupita Nyong'o and Kumail Nanjiani all used their time on stage to stand up for their rights.

‚ÄúI have two words for you: inclusion rider.‚Äù This is how Frances McDormand's Oscar speech ended after she asked all the female nominees to stand up so that the producers in the room could take note of their talent. But what does "inclusion rider" actually mean? Tap the link in bio to find out.
Photo: Mark Ralston

This is the home of Rosa Parks, who in 1955 refused to give up her seat in the "whites only" section of a bus, acting as a major catalyst for the civil rights movement. It was about to be demolished when Berlin-based artist Ryan Mendoza joined forces with her family to ship the house from Detroit to Germany. After reconstructing it, they sent it on a tour of galleries around Europe in an attempt to raise awareness of its neglected existence in America. This month it returns to the US and will be on display at Brown University.
Photo: Fabia Mendoza

This protester took part in a recent demonstration in Mexico City to demand justice for female victims of violence. The words on her back read: "And if I disappear today, what would they say about me tomorrow?" Mexico has a high rate of gender-based violence, with organised crime and human trafficking making it one of the most dangerous countries in the world for women. 
Photo: Edgard Garrido

What authors and books are you celebrating today? 
#WorldBookDay

Tributes have been paid to Slovakian investigative journalist J√°n Kuciak who was murdered along with his partner Martina Ku≈°n√≠rov√° this week. He is the second journalist to be murdered in a European Union country in the past five months, after Daphne Caruana Galizia was killed in Malta last year. According to the @committeetoprotectjournalists, 18 journalists were murdered around the world in 2017. 
Photo: Vladim√≠r ≈†im√≠ƒçek

Thousands of mourning fans lined the streets of Mumbai today to pay their respects to Bollywood actor Sridevi Kapoor. Throughout the 80s she was the undisputed queen of Indian cinema, often eclipsing the male actors she starred with. In breaking through this glass ceiling she became one of the highest paid actors of her time.
Photo: Rajanish Kakade

The world's first plastic-free supermarket aisle opens in the Netherlands today. Sian Sutherland, co-founder of @weareplasticaddicts, the group behind the campaign, said that ‚Äúfor decades shoppers have been sold the lie that we can‚Äôt live without plastic in food and drink. Finally we can see a future where the public have a choice about whether to buy plastic or plastic-free. Right now we have no choice.‚Äù Scientists have warned that plastic pollution is now so widespread it risks permanent contamination of the natural world. Supermarkets are a major source of plastic waste, producing 1m tonnes a year in the UK alone. 
Photo: Ewout Huibers/PA

@greyhutton has spent the winter photographing homeless people with a thermal imaging camera, offering a new perspective on the growing problem of homelessness in the UK and highlighting the hardship that so many face on the streets of London in winter‚Äã. Click the link in bio to see the full gallery.

Freezing weather is hitting many parts of Europe right now. In the UK, forecasters are predicting 5-10cm of snow in most areas of the country, with the most likely to fall on high ground in Scotland. Heavy snow showers are expected to continue throughout the morning and could cripple much of the country‚Äôs travel network. Stay safe and warm out there!
Photo: Gyorgy Varga/EPA

Yesterday, Jesse Lingard and Paul Pogba of Manchester United celebrated a goal against Chelsea with a nod to Black Panther. The duo did the Wakanda Forever sign, which has become a global symbol to show appreciation for the film.
Photo: Matthew Ashton - AMA/Getty Images

Rebecca Bitrus, a Nigerian victim of Boko Haram, attended a weekend ceremony at the Colosseum in Rome to pay tribute to Christians persecuted around the world. The landmark was lit up in red to highlight the challenges Christian people face. The non-denominational mission Open Doors say that over 200 million Christians live in danger because of their faith. 
Photos: Alessandra Tarantino & Andreas Solaro

Weather in the UK is about to take another cold turn. Health officials have issued a warning as temperatures plummet over the weekend and Britain faces potentially the coldest end to a winter in five years. But remember that spring is around the corner! To keep you going, here's a photo taken this week in Fujian Province China.

Photo: VCG

Donald Trump is considering a proposal to arm school teachers in an attempt to prevent mass shootings. Journalist and former teacher Ross Barkan thinks this is a bad idea. Tap the link in bio to read why.

These protestors dressed up as rabbits on the opening day of Milan Fashion Week to challenge the use of rabbit fur in the fashion industry. Their placard slogans included "Rabbit Skin is Not Yours." Rabbits on fur farms live in very poor conditions. Many suffer the ordeal of live plucking, where they are physically restrained while their hairs are torn out. The protest was organised by @peta (People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals) and the Italian animal rights group La LORO Voce - lene Vegane. 
Photos: Nicola Marfisi

As recently as 10 years ago, Bolivia‚Äôs indigenous Aymara and Quechua women were socially ostracised and systematically marginalised. Known as ‚Äòcholitas‚Äô, they were banned from using public transport and entering certain public spaces and their career opportunities were severely limited. While these women have been organising and advocating their civil rights since at least the 1960s, their movement was invigorated by Evo Morales‚Äô election as Bolivia‚Äôs first indigenous president in 2006. In Cholita‚Äôs Rise, photographer @eduardoleal80 has created an exhibition of work that portrays their accomplishments and celebrates their success.

Parkland shooting survivor Emma Gonzalez is one of the many young people¬†calling for¬†tough action on gun control¬†after 17 people were killed at her school last week.¬†But as students rise up, the rightwing media is aiming to take them down, along with anyone who offers them support. Tap the link in bio for the full story.
Photo: @nraucheisen

Last year, more than 8,000 people braved freezing temperatures to raise money for homeless people in Scotland. The world's largest 'sleep-out' is now paying off. @Social_Bite has announced it will take a minimum of 600 people out of homelessness over the next 18 months and offer them fully funded support for clinical issues and practical concerns like finding furniture. The initiative is also backed by the Scottish government, which has pledged ¬£50m to tackle rough sleeping.

In the past three months over 700 people have been killed in the rebel-held Syrian enclave of eastern Ghouta, with dozens killed and hundreds injured yesterday in what has been described as "hysterical" violence at the hands of the Assad regime. Hospitals have been repeatedly bombed and food and medical supplies are scarce due to the ongoing siege.
