The local doctor we spoke to added that ‚Äúif the massacre of the 1990s was Srebrenica.. then eastern Ghouta is the massacre of this century.‚Äù Link in bio for our full report.

Demonstrators, the majority of them students, staged a "lie-in" protest outside the White House yesterday calling for urgent gun reform after last week's school shooting in Parkland, Florida. Over the weekend students from the Marjory Stoneman Douglas high school led the call for action, publicly mourning their classmates and demanding regulation of the powerful NRA.

Photos: Evan Vucci

As the stars wore black for the #TimesUp movement at the #BAFTAs last night, activists from @sistersuncut invaded the red carpet to take a stand against the government's domestic violence policies. In a statement they said that Theresa May's new bill is a distraction from devastating funding cuts to services and could end up criminalising survivors of abuse. Time‚Äôs up Theresa?

These young performers were spotted at a street parade in Hong Kong marking celebrations for the #YearOfTheDog üéâ
Photo: Anthony Wallace

In shock and disbelief hundreds gathered for a vigil in Parkland, Florida last night after a shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas high school where 17 people were killed. With the teenage suspect in custody people are demanding answers and justice. Democrat politicians have amplified the call for stricter gun control and questions have been raised about the influence of the NRA and the gun lobby.

Photos: Carolyn Cole

Borrowing a tactic from the Hollywood film Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri ‚Äì which sees a mother rent three billboards to demand attention to her daughter's murder ‚Äìcampaigners drove three billboards through London yesterday demanding justice for the 71 people who died in the fire eight months ago.

Photos: Justice4Grenfell

Every major sporting event has its unlikely heroes, and Ghana's skeleton athlete Akwasi Frimpong is one to watch at this year's Winter Olympics. The one-time vacuum salesman has come a long way, from sharing a tiny one-bed home in Ghana with ten others as a child to sliding down a frozen track in Pyeongchang. "For me, being at the Winter Olympics is about breaking barriers, to show black people can do this as well." Check out @guardian_sport for more spectacular stories and photos from Pyeongchang

Photos: Edgar Su, Wong Maye-E and Mark Ralston

Labour leader @jeremy_corbynmp left these flowers as a tribute to a homeless man who died near the Houses of Parliament yesterday. ‚ÄúThis should never have happened. As a country we must stop walking by", he wrote in an accompanying card. Rough sleeping in England has increased for seven consecutive years. Last year, 4,751 people slept outside overnight and the number of children stuck in temporary accommodation has risen over 120,000. But homelessness charity @crisis_uk believes that politicians are finally taking the issue seriously. This month, after a huge outcry from the public, Windsor council dropped its plan to fine rough sleepers ¬£100 for leaving their belongings outside.
Photo: Isabel Togoh

Whether it‚Äôs the backbend, full wheel or upward facing dog, yoga teacher Dipuo Smith helps schoolchildren in Alexandra, Johannesburg bring stability to their lives. Free classes are offered to help students cope with stress and anxiety. 
Photos: @kimludbrook

It's Pancake Day, but don't panic if you missed the memo. Tap the link in bio to find out how to make the perfect pancakes and follow @guardianfeast for all things food.
Photo: @katewhitaker01

It's been eight years since Amy Poehler's character in Parks and Recreation hosted the first #GalentinesDay. Since then, 13 February has become an unofficial holiday celebrating female friendship a day before Valentine's Day.

Official portraits of Barack and Michelle Obama, painted by @kehindewiley and @asherald, have been unveiled at Washington's National Portrait Gallery. It's the first time the gallery has commissioned official portraits by African American artists. Barack Obama thanked Sherald for "spectacularly capturing the grace, beauty, intelligence, charm and....hotness of the woman I love." Photos: Saul Loeb

These colourful nesting boxes, attached to an apartment building in downtown Istanbul, is the work of @nerminer. The Turkish artist wanted to offer birds a retreat in an urban area. "Birds were dwellers here but we destroyed their nests by cutting down trees and building mass housing sites instead. We need to remind people that we are not the only ones." Photos: @ozannkoseee

Queensland's Great Barrier Reef has never looked heartier. With his aerial shots of the 2,300 km long ecosystem, photographer @joshuaj.smith hopes to raise awareness of Australia's connection with the reef and the impact humans have on it.

North Korean leader Kim Jong-un‚Äôs sister has landed in South Korea for the Winter Olympics. She‚Äôs the first member of Pyongyang‚Äôs ruling dynasty to set foot in the rival country since the Korean war. South Korean President Moon Jae-in is hoping the Games will open a door for dialogue and help persuade North Korea to give up its atomic ambitions.
Photo: Francois-Xavier Marit/AFP/Getty Images

Police received more than 2,000 calls about violence against women in Rio during last year's carnival. This year, many women are using the festival as an opportunity to start a dialogue about the problem by organising street parties and giving out stickers with slogans like ‚ÄòMy breasts, my rules‚Äô, ‚ÄòNo is no‚Äô, and ‚ÄòGrabbing me won‚Äôt get you a kiss!‚Äô
Photos: Silvia Izquierdo/AP

Is this painting an erotic Victorian fantasy too far? John William Waterhouse's Hylas and the Nymphs is back on the wall at the Manchester Art Gallery, a week after it was taken down in an effort to provoke debate. Visitors were invited to give their reaction by sticking Post-it notes on the wall. 
Photos: Manchester City Galleries/Manchester Art Gallery

Last week, one of @alexattempts' art teachers told her to "dial down the feminism" in her work. This week Alex showed him her latest piece. 
Artwork: Alex Ruth Bertulis-Fernandes

This is what Cheddar Man, Britain's oldest complete skeleton, might have looked like 10,000 years ago. Groundbreaking DNA analysis suggests the first modern Britons had dark to black skin, blue eyes and dark curly hair, and that genes for lighter skin became widespread in European populations later than originally thought. 
Photo: Channel 4

The brutal rape of a 23-year-old student, known as ‚ÄòNirbhaya' (‚Äòfearless'), on a bus in Delhi shocked the world and triggered protests across India demanding dramatic improvements to women's rights. Five years later, has anything actually changed? Swipe left to hear from @kaul.sheen, @boxfit.in, @mahimasareen, @feminisminindia, @japleenpasricha, #iwillgoout, @vishalblackbelt, @sayfty and @shruticlicks. Link in the bio for the full film.

Video: @katyaochagavia + @irenebaque

Women may have won the right to vote 100 years ago, but there‚Äôs a long way to go until we reach full parity. Sexual harassment is an urgent issue that needs to be addressed, women of colour are still woefully represented in public life and many disabled, homeless, poor and older people are still disenfranchised. To end our #100years takeover, Laura Bates, Catherine Mayer, Rushanara Ali and Polly Tonybee reflect on the past century.

The decade leading up to 1918 was a pivotal time for the suffragettes movement as they demanded the right to vote. They mounted protests on horseback, mobilised women to take to the streets, set up exhibitions and marched on the Royal Albert Hall ‚Äì with many arrested and force-fed after going on hunger strike. Some of these moments were captured by Christina Broom, one of the UK‚Äôs first press photographers. 
Photos: @museumoflondon

100 years ago today some women won the right to vote, with full suffrage being realised in 1928. But who were the women that fought for it? And where do we stand on equality in 2018? Today we dedicate our feed to women, starting with suffragette leader Emmeline Pankhurst.

An exclusion zone has been in place around the Chernobyl nuclear power plant since the disaster in 1986. The area is sparse, home to only a handful of residents and a community of stray dogs - mainly the descendants of the pets that people were forced to leave behind. Julie McDowall went to meet them for the Guardian. Link in bio for more.

Thousands of doctors, nurses, dentists, pharmacists, and other members of the public marched in London over the weekend to demand more cash for the National Health Service, which is at breaking point after years of government austerity. These were some of the placards on display.

Clowns, young and old, descended on an east London church this weekend for an annual memorial service to Joseph Grimaldi (1778-1837). The 'King of Clowns' is widely credited with developing a clown act which is still copied by many today. 
Photos: John Stillwell

Santa Cruz del Islote is a Caribbean island the size of two football pitches. Eighteen families live in 97 houses and the youth population is around 65%. There are no reports of crime, but there is poverty with no clean drinking water or sewerage. The internet has inspired the youngest islanders to be creative and many of them plan to leave to build lives on the mainland. 
Photos: @charliecordero
Artist @aiww has experienced first-hand what it's like to live in a refugee camp. Follow the link in bio to read his take on how people can continue to coexist on this planet.

Another woman was arrested in Iran this week for taking off her headscarf, in defiance of rules which require women to cover up from head to toe in public. The protester (who has since been released) took off her red headscarf on a street in Tehran and held it up on a stick. Her actions follow a similar protest earlier this month, with photos emerging on social media of other women joining in solidarity. 
Photo:¬†@MaajidNawaz, Twitter

A protester poses in front of riot police in St Petersburg. They're one of thousands of people across Russia calling for a boycott of March's presidential elections, which are expected to return Vladimir Putin to power for six more years.

The White House has been offered the use of this gold toilet by the Guggenheim Museum. The 18-carat installation is the work of artist @mauriziocattelan. It's slightly different to the White House's original request of borrowing Van Gogh's 1888 painting Landscape With Snow. 
Photo: @guggenheim

In the wake of the recent Presidents Club event, where hostesses were allegedly groped and sexually harassed, a new survey by Unite reveals that nine out of 10 workers in the hospitality industry have experienced abuse. The government has been criticised for weakening protections for workers and there are calls for laws around sexual harassment to be strengthened.

Mark E Smith, iconic singer of the Fall, has died aged 60. Described by Ian McMillan as the "spiky poet of every awkward moment any of us has ever lived through," Smith powered the band through more than 30 studio albums since 1979.

This is rescue dog Rocket, a valuable emergency search specialist for the Windsor, California fire protection district. He has worked in disaster zones with engineer Mike Stornetta for the last three and a half years, most recently after the devastating landslide in Montecito. The National Disaster Search Dog Foundation identifies unadoptable dogs like Rocket in animal shelters, whose obsession with games like hide-and-seek make them unsuitable pets but potentially great rescuers. 
Photos: Susan Bollinger

Khanyi is from Phillipi, one of Cape Town's most dangerous townships. Many families in the area face acute poverty and social challenges and dropping out of school is common. Attending the matric ball represents a huge achievement for students. While the night gives them a chance to feel glamorous and socialise with their friends and teachers, it also signifies their success in reaching their final year of school and of having overcome odds that were stacked against them. Tap the link in bio to see the full story.
Photos: @alicemannnn

Violent deaths of LGBT people in Brazil hit an all time high last year, according to the watchdog group Grupo Gay de Bahia. Luiz Mott, president of the watchdog, said the rising violence was influenced by the prominence of ultraconservative politicians, many of whom are linked to the country‚Äôs powerful evangelical caucus in congress. In September, a Brazilian judge approved gay ‚Äúconversion therapy‚Äù, a week after an exhibition of gay art was cancelled.

This mother and her three-year-old child were photographed waiting inside a church after the Indonesian government sent support to tackle malnutrition in the remote Papua region, where measles has killed nearly 100 people. Papua is one of the poorest provinces in Indonesia.
Photo: Antara Foto
A story by leading Scottish writer Val McDermid is being projected on to buildings and landmarks in Edinburgh this month ‚ú®

Crowds returned to the streets yesterday a year after millions of people demonstrated in cities around the globe in an extraordinary rebuke of Donald Trump. Organisers hope the anniversary rallies and marches will help galvanise the movement ahead of the 2018 midterms. 
#womensmarch

"Don't compromise yourself. You are all you've got." American singer Janis Joplin would have been 75 today. Described as a raw and uncompromising talent, she became one of the biggest female rock stars before a heroin overdose cut her life short at 27. 
Photo: Crawley/Kobal/REX/Shutterstock

What would a society without work look like? Post-work, the radical idea of a world without jobs, has become popular with a new generation of thinkers. While work shapes our routines, they believe unethical working conditions and unstable wages is affecting our social mobility and self-worth. Tap the link in bio to see what they're suggesting.

Illustration: Nathalie Lees

This might not have been the best day for a quiet swim. Two beachgoers at the Bronte beach ocean pool in Sydney, Australia look on as stormy conditions keep them out of the water. While it's been another hot summer in New South Wales so far, recent thunderstorms have caused power cuts affecting both homes and businesses

Photo: Glenn Campbell

This fox was spotted walking past the UK Prime Minister's office earlier this week. While classified as a wild animal, urban foxes in London are regularly spotted patrolling the streets late at night or in the early hours. 
Photo: Dan Kitwood

Ever wondered what this beautiful spectacle in the sky is? It's called a murmuration and it's when hundreds - sometimes thousands - of starlings fly together as 'one'. Scientists believe this coordinated whirling effect helps protect the birds from predators and also keeps them warm.
Photo: Amir Cohen/Reuters

Flowers were placed at the memorial statue in Manila, Philippines this week to honour the Filipino "comfort women" who were forcibly taken to Japanese front-line military brothels during World War II. It's believed that over 200,000 Asian women, mostly Koreans, forcibly served as wartime sex slaves for the Japanese army. An increasing number of cities in Southeast Asia, America and Europe are putting up statues symbolising these women in solidarity with the few survivors left and to honour those who have died. Japan's government says the statues encourage anti-Japanese sentiment and insist that the women were provided by private brokers.

Photos: Romeo Ranoco, Yonhap, Aflo & NEWS1

Tributes have been paid to Irish singer Dolores O'Riordan who has died aged 46. As the lead singer in The Cranberries her unmistakable west Irish accent and heartfelt vocals drove the band's success on both sides of the Atlantic, selling more than 40m records worldwide.

Photo: Tim Roney

Cyrille Regis, one of the first iconic black footballers in Britain, has died aged 59. He suffered horrific racist abuse throughout his career in the 1970s and 80s and was sent a bullet by racists before his England debut in 1982. "I kept the bullet as a reminder of the evil some people had inside them. For the rest of my playing days, it was motivation that they weren't going to stop me", he once said. Fellow footballer Ian Wright said Cyrille was like Martin Luther King. He was always tuning the other cheek and did so much for the game and so much for the cause of black footballers." Photos: Harry Goodwin, Bob Thomas & Andy Hooper

Sisters embrace after an airstrike hit Hamouria in rebel-held eastern Ghouta, Syria. More than 15,000 civilians were killed by explosive weapons in 2017, a jump of 42% in a year. The rise coincided with US-led military operations to reclaim the Islamic State strongholds of Mosul in Iraq, and Raqqa in Syria. MPs said the figures were ‚Äúdeeply concerning‚Äù and raised questions over the transparency of legal criteria used by the Ministry of Defence to determine whether an individual is an Isis fighter.
Photo: Abdulmonam Eassa

Thousands of people across UK cities (including this woman and her dog) gathered on 30 January last year to protest against Donald Trump's travel ban targeting several Muslim majority countries. Almost one year on, Donald Trump has decided to cancel his planned visit to Britain fearing more mass protests. London mayor Sadiq Kahn said Trump had "got the message" that many Londoners strongly opposed his policies and actions. 
Photo: @eleni.stefanou

The anti-austerity protests in Tunisia show no sign of letting up any time soon, with more than 300 people arrested during violent demonstrations this week. The government has been criticised for raising prices and taxes to deal with the country's deficit, but people are concerned about the long-term damage of these measures, including high levels of poverty, inequality and youth unemployment. Many of the protesters are students. 
Photo: EPA

"The truth is of course is that there is no journey. We are arriving and departing all at the same time." David Bowie left us two years ago today 
Photos: Kirsty O'Connor and Barritt

This is the moment American photographer @scottmead_lon_ny leaned over the person in the window seat next to him on a shuttle flight to Boston and captured the glowing lights and bridges of New York. "This image is so peaceful compared to the intensity and bustle of the streets below. It makes everything seem manageable," Mead says.

Photo: Scott Mead

300 female Hollywood actors, agents, writers, directors, producers and entertainment executives kicked off the new year with a coordinated effort to counter systemic sexual harassment in US workplaces. They made their mark last night at the Golden Globes by asking attendees to wear black in solidarity. You can follow @timesupnow to find out more about the campaign.

@AccidentallyWesAnderson receives thousands of photos from fans with a passion for travel and architecture. Locations like the Opera Hotel in Prague, a bus stop in Aral and M√∂r√∂n Airport have all been included. So what makes a building look like something from a Wes Anderson film? ‚ÄúThe ones we see most often have a level of symmetry, a touch of colour and, most importantly, something unique or eye-catching‚Äù, Wally Koval, who runs the account, explains.

Photos: Valentina Jacks, @herwigphoto, @elizabethdaniels01, @kehnnee, @kimakimberlin, @kjphotos1022 & @funkyspion

In the middle of the worst NHS winter crisis since the 1990s, nurses are treating patients stuck in the back of ambulances outside their A&E units. These personal testimonies reveal a fear for patients whose health is already seriously damaged. Bad weather, flu, a lack of hospital beds and financial pressures built up over the last decade have all played a part in causing the current winter crisis.

A severe winter storm has enveloped much of the US east coast, delivering snow, strong winds and coastal flooding. Forecasters have referred to the storm as a ‚Äúbomb cyclone‚Äù because of an unusually rapid drop in atmospheric pressure that has triggered hurricane-like conditions. Ryan Maue, a US meteorologist, called the event ‚Äúone of the fastest-intensifying non-tropical storms in historical analysis‚Äù.
Photo: Adam Gray/Barcroft Images

@justinhofman's photo of a seahorse holding on to a cotton swab in Indonesia was one of the defining photos of 2017. "It‚Äôs a photo that I wish didn‚Äôt exist, but now that it does I want everyone to see it. I see trash and wildlife together a lot, but this is the most dramatic interaction I've seen." @plasticoceans claim eight million tonnes of plastic is dumped in our oceans every year, and one in three mammals have been found entangled in marine litter. According to @wwf, over 80% of current pollution comes from waste that didn't exist 60 years ago.

Richard is one of 14,721 readers who have donated to our charity appeal so far, raising money for the three charities @centrepointuk, Depaul UK and NACCOM fighting youth homelessness and destitution among UK asylum seekers. Click the link in our bio to add your support. Thank you for helping us #breakthechain.

Thought the festive season was over? Think again! This train, spotted yesterday in Moscow, is defying #backtowork gloom. 
Photos: Yuri Kadobnov/AFP

These teenage basketball players were denied the right to compete in a regional league in Italy because their parents were immigrants. They decided to fight back and in the process exposed Italian attitudes towards immigration and integration. Tap the link in bio to read their story.
Photo: @giuliopiscitelli

This photo was taken last week around the time when a wave of anti-regime protests spread across Iran in a way that no one anticipated. The demonstrations began over economic issues in north-eastern Iran and have now taken on a political dimension of huge scale. It is estimated that 21 people have died in unrest linked to the demonstrations, the largest in Iran since its disputed 2009 presidential election. It may look as if this woman is waving a white flag of truce, but given her geographical location (the capital city of Tehran), in a country where wearing a hijab is obligatory for women, it is a small ‚Äì yet audacious ‚Äì act of resistance. Although not directly linked to the protests, it embodies embodies the aspiration of a young nation frustrated with economic grievances and lack of social and political freedom.

After the party comes the clean-up operation in Times Square, where New York City Department of Sanitation workers have been cleaning the streets after New Year celebrations.

#NYC #happynewyear #NewYork #2018 
Photos: Amr Alfiky/Reuters

How's the snow where you are on New Year's Day? This dog is enjoying wintry conditions in Godewaersvelde in France. The country experienced cold weather last month, with 20,000 homes in the northern France left without power.

Photo: Philippe Huguen

Marco Fois dives into the Tiber river as part of traditional New Year celebrations in Rome. The tradition of diving into the river on New Year‚Äôs Day dates back to 1946, when an unemployed lifeguard who was trying to find work as a stuntman jumped into the water from the bridge to advertise his skills.

#HappyNewYear #2018 #Rome #dive 
Photo: Alberto Pizzoli/AFP/Getty Images

Happy New Year ... from London, Paris, Athens, Berlin, Hong Kong, Sydney, Frankfurt and Kuala Lumpur. 
#fireworks #2018 #newyear #celebration #happynewyear 
Photos: AFP/Getty Images/EPA

As one of the first countries to adopt Christianity, Ethiopia has a legacy of churches built on hilltops as well as vibrant traditions of worship. Visitors can find this small, modern church built on the flat-topped mountain Debre Damo in northern Ethiopia - one of the country's most important centres of Christianity.

Photo: Ethiopia - The Living Churches of an Ancient Kingdom

The Black Lives Matter activist Erica Garner has died, following a heart attack. She was 27. Garner was the daughter of Eric Garner, a man who died in a police chokehold in New York in 2014. His last words, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt breathe‚Äù, became a slogan for activists protesting police brutality against African Americans.¬†Bernie Sanders and Bill de Blasio are among those to pay tribute. 
Photo: Mike McGregor

Wiley, aka Richard Cowie Jnr, aka the godfather of grime has been awarded an MBE for services to music in the New Year honours list. The MC, who was among the early pioneers of grime, said: ‚ÄúIt feels like the school grade I wanted and didn‚Äôt get but now I‚Äôm finally there.‚Äù

This year's charity appeal - for three charities that work with homeless young people and destitute refugees and asylum seekers - has passed the ¬£1 million mark! Thank you all for your generosity. Click the link in our bio to find out more about the appeal and to donate. Thanks again!

Crowds in Monrovia celebrate the victory of ex-football superstar George Weah who won Liberia's presidential election with 61.5% of the vote. Weah beat the vice president in the first democratic transfer of power since 1944, following two devastating civil wars. 
Photo: Seyllouseyllou

Adorable! Newborn babies dressed in dog costumes to celebrate the New Year of the Dog in Bangkok, Thailand. 
Photo: Athit Perawongmetha

About 45 minutes away from Trump Tower people walk past politically charged street art designed by @adamfu and @dirtybandits in Brooklyn. Adam Fujita says he is tired of ‚Äúthe incompetence in Washington from the top down,‚Äù and shows his frustration through street murals in the working class neighbourhood of Bushwick and beyond.

Photo: Shannon Stapleton

From laughing dormice to shocked seals, there have been plenty of happy moments in the wild this year. The 2017 comedy wildlife awards have picked the best of the 3,500 entries across the world. 
Photos: Andrea Zampatti, Penny Palmer, Olivier Colle and George Cathcart

The silhouettes of the Lutheran Church of Our Lady (Frauenkirche), the Roman Catholic Cathedral (Hofkirche), the Yenidze former cigarette factory building and the tower of city's castle light up a beautiful Dresden skyline in eastern Germany.

Photo: Sebastian Kahnert

Have you got your transport sorted for the holidays? This little polar bear cub definitely has the right idea, hitching a ride with its mum in Manitoba, Canada.

Photo: Daisy Gilardini

It's been one year since iconic singer George Michael died. At the time of his death he had sold 115 million records worldwide, easily ranking him among the best-selling British acts of all time. His work as a LGBT rights campaigner and HIV/AIDS charity fundraiser should also be recognised. It's the perfect time to give Last Christmas another spin. 
Photos: Peter Still, Brad Branson, ITV, Evert Elzinga & Sarah Lee

Taxidermied endangered species, snakeskin footwear and red ant viagra are just some of the illegal goods the UK Border Force at Heathrow airport have seized this year. The officers help to identify and prevent the unlawful trade in endangered animals and plant material. 
Photos: Simon Dawson

This year the Guardian picture desk has chosen Reuters photojournalist @zohrabensemra as our agency photographer of the year. Zohra has covered a variety of subjects in 2017, from the drought in Somalia to the conflict in Iraq and Syria against Islamic State, to elections in her home country of Algeria. She talked to us about her work and some of her favourite assignments and images of the year. Link in bio. Photos: Zohra Bensemra

#photography #photojournalism #photojournalist

Meet Britain's only free-ranging herd of reindeer. The 150-strong herd have lived in the Cairngorm mountains in Scotland since they were introduced in 1952. Reindeer fans can visit them with guided trips all year round. Photos: Murdo MacLeod. 
#reindeer #Scotland #Christmas #animals

Period poverty can mean girls missing school, girls using socks instead of sanitary towels, with many afraid to ask for help due to the stigma associated with menstruation. Yesterday campaign group @freeperiods held a peaceful protest outside Parliament calling on the government to provide free sanitary products to girls who already qualify for free school meals.

Our Christmas charity appeal is focused on homelessness. Supporting people like Thomas Korpiela,¬†Brookemorgan Henry-Rennie,¬†Ann O'Shea and Kirk Rogers (clockwise from top right) who found themselves with nowhere to live after family breakdowns, bereavement¬†and mental health issues. Watch our Instagram story to hear more about their experiences, and how they found help, or see the link in bio to watch the film in full.

Was this the worst nativity scene of 2017? The effort by the bakery chain Greggs, which replaced baby Jesus with a sausage roll, was widely ridiculed and even condemned as ‚Äúsick" and "anti-Christian" by a rightwing pressure group. Maybe you've seen worse? Tell us about it in the comments below.
Photo: PA

Brave swimmer @ellachloeswims has pledged to take a dip in the rivers of Surrey and Berkshire throughout December ‚Äì including Christmas Day and finishing on New Year's Day. She is (apparently) finding that "the nip of the water and the zing of a swim is quite addictive". Click the link in our bio to read more about her experience. 
Photos: @rogertaylorphotography

Craving the cold this Christmas? Then this ice hotel might be the place for you. Situated 200km north of the Arctic Circle in Swedish Lapland the hotel is rebuilt every year in a different theme, with international artists helping to design the rooms. You might even see the northern lights. 
Photo: Ragnar Th Sigurdsson

Guardian and Observer readers have raised more than ¬£500,000 for homeless young people and refugees just 10 days into our annual charity appeal. The appeal is running over the festive period and is raising money for three charities, @centrepointuk, Depaul UK and NACCOM, fighting youth homelessness and destitution among asylum seekers in the UK. Click the link in our bio to add your support. Thank you for helping us #breakthechain.

A memorial at the Christmas market on Breitscheidplatz, Berlin remembers the victims a year after a truck attack killed 12 people and injured 70 others. German Chancellor Angela Merkel visited the market yesterday to pay her respects. 
Photo: Fabrizio Bensch

Tributes have been pouring in for the lead singer of popular K-pop band Shinee. 27-year-old Kim Jong-hyun, better known as Jonghyun, was found unconscious at his home in Seoul on Monday evening in an apparent suicide, according to South Korean media reports. Fans have taken to social media to express their grief and disbelief, urging people to seek out support if they need it. 
In the UK, the Samaritans can be contacted on 116 123. In the US, the National Suicide Prevention Hotline is 1-800-273-8255. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is on 13 11 14. Hotlines in other countries can be found at www.befrienders.org

Photo: Han Myung-Gu

A crew member of MV Open Arms rescues a migrant baby off the coast of Libya. The search and rescue ships, run in partnership with SOS Mediterranee and @doctorswithoutborders, were busy during a mid-sea transfer of migrants in the central Mediterranean on December 16. Maltese photojournalist @darrinzl's recent work focuses on the dangerous plight of people trying to reach Europe from Africa by sea.

Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

Amy Laker and Lauren Price made history in Sydney at the weekend by becoming the first gay couple to be legally married in Australia, after the law was changed last week. Thousands more same-sex marriages are expected to take place next year. 
Photo: Caroline McCredie

The steepest funicular railway in the world will finally open on Sunday in the Swiss village Stoos, after five years of construction. The village itself is car free and only has about 100 residents, but the new Stoosbahn will make it easier to gain access to the place as a ski resort for visitors.

Photos: Urs Flueeler

'Youthquake' has been named  word of the year by Oxford Dictionaries. Defined as "a significant, cultural, political, or social change arising from the actions or influence of young people," the word first built momentum in June, when young voters in the UK almost carried the Labour Party to an unlikely victory in the general election. Young people also had an influence on the Catalan independence poll, New Zealand's parliamentary elections and Australian's marriage equality referendum.

Photos: Matt Cardy, Dan Kitwood, Hagen Hopkins and Scott Barbour

Today marks six months since the Grenfell Tower fire, which killed 71 people and left hundreds of residents homeless. More than 1,500 people attended the memorial at St Paul‚Äôs Cathedral. In his address, the bishop of Kensington, Graham Tomlin, said that ‚Äútoday we ask why warnings were not heeded; why a community was left feeling neglected, uncared for, not listened to. Today we hold out hope that the public inquiry will get to the truth of all that led up to the fire at Grenfell Tower." He added that the extraordinary grassroots response to the disaster was ‚Äúa glimpse of what our society could be like; a place where we were, for a brief moment, more concerned about our neighbour‚Äôs wellbeing than we were about our own."

‚ÄòFeminism‚Äô has been named word of the year by the American dictionary @merriamwebster. It was first included in the English dictionary in 1841. Back then it was simply defined as ‚Äúthe qualities of females.‚Äù Other contenders for word of the year included "complicit", "recuse" and "dotard", which saw a 35,000% increase in searches year-on-year, after North Korean president Kim Jong-un called Donald Trump a "mentally deranged US dotard" back in September.

More than 6,700 Rohingya Muslims, including at least 730 children under the age of five, were killed killed between August and September in Myanmar, according to figures released by M√©decins Sans Fronti√®res. Their estimate is much higher than Myanmar's official death toll of 400. 69% of those killed were shot, while others were burned and beaten to death.
Photo: Dar Yasin

A Palestinian protester takes cover from Israeli tear-gas during clashes near the border with Israel. In the Gaza strip, and around the world, people are protesting Donald Trump's decision to recognise Jerusalem as Israel‚Äôs capital. 
Photo: Mohammed Saber
Former Facebook executive Chamath Palihapitiya has expressed regret for his part in building tools that have destroyed how humans interact. Do you agree? Let us know in the comments below

Yesterday was Human Rights Day. To mark the occasion, the Border Network for Human Rights organised an event to reunite families separated by the Mexico-US wall for three minutes.
Photo: Herika Martinez/AFP/Getty Images

David Attenborough's Blue Planet II is the most watched British TV show of 2017 with 14.1 million people enjoying the cinematic wonders of the ocean. But does the programme have a responsibility to move beyond entertainment and be more forthright in calling for marine conservation? Link in bio for more on the debate, let us know what you think in the comments. 
Photos: Lisa Labinjoh + Audun Rikardsen

Six months after the Grenfell tower fire four out of five families are still looking for homes and almost half face spending Christmas in hotel rooms, according to local resident's group Grenfell United. Politicians Jeremy Corbyn and David Lammy have joined survivors in condemning the response to the disaster, which killed 71 people, as a public inquiry begins two days of formal hearings.

Photos: Tolga Akmen

London is full of street art tributes to Amy Winehouse. Here‚Äôs one of the more ephemeral dedications spotted in Hampstead Heath today. #uksnow
Photo: @sonya_barber

@salihughes knows what it's like to be one of the ‚Äúhidden homeless‚Äù. Follow the link in bio to read her story.
#BreakTheChain

Last year, Guardian readers showed amazing generosity, compassion and solidarity by helping us raise ¬£1.75m for refugee charities. This year we're asking for your support to help us break the chain of homelessness. Follow the link bio to find out which amazing charities you can back. #BreakTheChain

Unseasonably warm weather and minimal rain provided the perfect conditions for wildfires that have swept through parts of southern California and encroached on the heart of Los Angeles. The so-called Skirball fire has destroyed hundreds of homes, forced thousands to flee and left a thick smoke which is expected to linger for days.
Photo: Mark Ralston

These protesters dressed as handmaids at a recent campaign rally for Republican senatorial candidate Roy Moore in Fairhope, Alabama. They wanted to draw attention to historic sexual assault allegations aimed at the 70-year-old. Moore has been accused by nine women of sexual misconduct in the 1970s, when they were teenagers and he was in his 30s. But his campaign is supported by both President Donald Trump and former White House chief strategist Steve Bannon. Margaret Atwood's 1985 novel The Handmaid's Tale explores misogyny in a society controlled by men.

Photos: Joe Raedle

This is the moment NFL star @kaepernick7 received Sports Illustrated's Muhammad Ali Legacy Award from Beyonce. The singer praised Kaepernick for "risking his career in order to remind Americans of the systematic racism denying African-Americans opportunities to equal education, jobs, health and even their lives." Photos: Slaven Vlasic/Stringer & Marcio Jose Sanchez

Meet @time magazine's Person of the Year: The Silence Breakers. Ashley Judd, Susan Fowler, Adama Iwu, Taylor Swift and Isabel Pascual represent the #metoo campaign that lifted the lid on sexual harassment across a number of industries worldwide.

Photo: Billy & Hells

Breaking with decades of diplomacy, Donald Trump is expected to honour one of his campaign pledges and declare Jerusalem as the capital of Israel later today. The decision is expected to ignite tensions in an already fraught region. Both Israel and Palestine insist that the holy city ‚Äì which is of great significance for Jews, Muslims and Christians ‚Äì should be their capital. The Palestinian ambassador to London says Trump's move amounts to "declaring war on 1.5 billion Muslims and hundreds of millions of Christians." Photo: Abir Sultan

This polar bear was at the centre of a @greenpeace stunt in London to highlight the number of plastic Coke bottles that end up in the ocean. Campaigner Tisha Brown said Greenpeace wanted to "focus on the billions of single-use bottles ending up in the Arctic, while Coke have their Christmas truck going about." According to Greenpeace‚Äôs website, Coke produces 3,400 plastic bottles every second, adding up to 110 billion single-use bottles every year.

Photo: Matthew Chattle

Christmas decorations aren‚Äôt the only thing lighting up this December. This starry scene graced the sky over the ruins of Dunstanburgh Castle in 
Alnwick, UK üôå
Photo: Owen Humphreys/PA

Too airbrushed? Or the best he's ever looked? A fashion icon? Or a dud in his Marks and Spencer suit? Debate has raged after Jeremy Corbyn was revealed as the cover star of the upcoming issue of GQ magazine, which goes on sale today. What do you think of the 'new look' Labour leader?

An Ed Sheeran¬†and Comic Relief¬†appeal has been branded 'poverty porn' by¬†Radi-Aid,¬†who hold annual awards for tone deaf charity campaigns. Their jury said the video, which shows the pop star offering to front the hotel costs for street children in Liberia, enforced the¬†white saviour stereotype and portrayed local people as victims.¬†Campaigns¬†fronted by Tom Hardy and Eddie Redmayne were also criticised.¬†Link in bio for the full story.

Last night was the final super moon of 2017 ‚Äì a¬†lunar phenomenon which occurs when a full moon is at its closest point to the earth and looks bigger than normal. Here's how it looked from Myanmar, Indonesia, Turkey, the US and Israel. 
Photos:¬†Aung Shine,¬†Adi Weda,¬†Anadolu Agency,¬†Jim Lo Scalzo and¬†Jack Guez

55-year-old Rohingya refugee Amina Khatun rests at the bank of the Naf river after crossing it on an improvised raft to reach Bangladesh. She said that two of her sons were killed by gunfire when her village was attacked by the Myanmar military. More than 700,000 Rohingya have fled Myanmar since the military launched its first round of ‚Äúclearance operations‚Äù in October last year. About 600,000 have been displaced since the second wave in August, which the UN has condemned as ‚Äúethnic cleansing‚Äù. Photo: Susana Vera/Reuters

For #WorldAidsDay a new exhibition has opened in Johannesburg documenting the courage of girls and young women across Africa affected by the disease. Photographer Karin Schermbrucker spent a decade travelling with @unicef witnessing the stigma and discrimination of these women first hand. Treatment remains out of reach for many pregnant women and mothers who have the virus.

This farmer is harvesting mistletoe from his family orchard in Tenbury Wells, Worcestershire. Some ancient cultures thought mistletoe had magical healing powers and was also an aphrodisiac because of the suggestive arrangement of its berries. Apparently, the association between mistletoe and fertility made it a traditional addition to ancient Greek myths, where the custom of kissing under mistletoe may have started. 
Photo: Christopher Thomond

Brendan Cox has spoken out after Donald Trump retweeted a handful of anti-muslim videos posted by far-right group Britain First. The widower of former Labour MP Jo Cox, called the president a purveyor of hate and called for tolerance and dignity to fight his rhetoric.

Today is¬†international Women Human Rights Defenders‚Äô Day. In its 2017 tribute to female activists, more than half the women cited by @awidwomensrights were murdered for defending their rights. Some of them are pictured here. 
Female activists across the globe face particular challenges, not just for their protests but because they are women. In some countries they are seen as breaking social norms by standing up for their rights and calling out injustice. 
Credit: AWID

In the shadows of the Mount Agung volcano, which has errupted for the first time in more than half a century. Bali's authorities have raised the alert to the highest level and ordered 100,000 people to evacuate. Travellers have also been left stranded by airport closures. 
Photos: Firdia Lisnawati

Prince Harry and actor Meghan Markle make their first public appearance after announcing their engagement. News of the wedding, scheduled¬†for next spring, has prompted a media frenzy likely to further test their relationship with the press. The prince has previously criticised the 'racial undertones' in comment pieces about Markle and talked of nightly legal battles to keep defamatory stories out of papers.

Bad news: the world is getting brighter. Satellite observations made by researchers during five consecutive Octobers show Earth‚Äôs artificially lit outdoor area grew by 2% a year from 2012 to 2016. This can harm people‚Äôs sleep, which in turn can affect their health. The migration and reproduction of birds, fish, amphibians, insects and bats can also be disrupted and plants can have abnormally extended growing periods. And forget about seeing stars or the Milky Way if the trend continues. About the only places with dramatic declines in night light were in areas of conflict such as Syria and Yemen.

In July 1995, close to 8,000 Muslims were executed in the fields around Srebrenica. This week, the Bosnian Serb army commander responsible for the massacre was finally found guilty. Ratko Mladiƒá's life sentence coincides with warnings that ‚Äúethnic cleansing‚Äù is taking place in Myanmar, where recent reports have laid bare the murder of infants and the use of rape as a weapon against the Rohingya. The UN high commissioner for human rights, Zeid Ra‚Äôad Al Hussein, thinks Mladiƒá's sentencing is a warning to other perpetrators. ‚ÄúThey will not escape justice, no matter how powerful they may be nor how long it may take. They will be held accountable,‚Äù he said.
Photo: Cris Toala Olivares/Reuters

Wat Mahathat is a 14th-century temple reduced to ruins in 1767 when the Burmese army invaded Ayutthaya in Thailand. Over time, a tree has grown around one of the remaining stone Buddha heads, which is now completely enclosed by its roots with only the face peeking out.
Photo: Mathew Browne

Is this the best view in Kyoto? A stunning blaze of autumn colours can be enjoyed at the Japanese city's Rurikoin temple. It used to be a hidden gem among the city's tourist attractions, but the temple's beautiful scenery has spread on social media and it has become a very popular place to visit.

Zimbabweans have gathered around a park opposite the parliament building in downtown Harare to pray for the country. Zimbabwe's recently fired vice president Emmerson Mnangagwa has called for President Robert Mugabe to "accept the will of the people" and resign immediately. The country's ruling Zanu-PF party is expected to start impeachment proceedings in parliament today in an effort to strip the 93-year-old of the presidency.

With our days getting colder and frostier, it‚Äôs important to enjoy as much sun as you can, like this horse in Swillington, West Yorkshire.

Angel with Broken Wings, Ball King with One Leg, Magic Boy - these are just some of the nicknames given to Chinese footballer He Yiyi. Thousands of students marched in London yesterday to demand free education funded by taxing the rich. Hansika Jethnani, one of the organisers, said: ‚ÄúTuition fees are fundamentally illegitimate. This is US Olympic fencer Ibtihaj Muhammad holding the first hijab-wearing Barbie. This is Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe with her husband Richard. The Iranian-British national has been sitting in a Tehran jail since April 2016, accused of trying to arrange a "soft overthrow" of the Islamic Republic by training journalists in Iran's capital - but she was actually on holiday with her three-year-old daughter. Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson made a comment last week suggesting Zaghari-Ratcliffe wasn't on holiday, which Iranian authorities reportedly used as proof that she was a threat. Johnson has apologised and is considering giving her diplomatic protection to help her reunite with her family. #freenazanin

If you think your commute is a lonely one, spare a thought for anyone on one of America's northernmost roads, the Dalton Highway. Stretching between central Alaska and Prudhoe Bay, it was only opened for public use in 1981. The highway offers no radio, mobile phone or internet connection.

Axel Scheffler, best known as the co-creator of the Gruffalo, has pooled the talents of children's illustrators across Europe to sum up people's feelings about Brexit. Scheffler told the Guardian that it was 'nice to do¬†some pro-EU propganda' and that, as a children's artist, he felt a 'responsibility to say something about the future.'

Residents gather outside in the city of Pole-Zahab in Kermanshah Province, Iran, after a¬†powerful magnitude¬†7.2 earthquake hit the region along the border near Iraq. Rescuers are still battling to find survivors, as the death toll has risen to 355.¬†

The gender pay gap for women in their 20s is growing after years of decline in the UK. It's now five times greater than it was six years ago, although older women still face greater pay discrimination than workers at the start of their career. Progress has stalled on closing the overall gender pay gap, which now stands at 14.1% according to the Office for National Statistics, with no movement on the figure in the last three years. At the current rate of change, it will take 100 years to close the gap. @fawcettsociety is encouraging people to take action by starting a conversation at work and speaking to their employers, while companies and the government are being urged to make tangible, effective changes. #EqualPayDay

Levels of airborne pollutants are off the scale in parts of India‚Äôs capital with effects likened to smoking 50 cigarettes a day. The Indian Medical Association said the country‚Äôs capital was suffering a health emergency and called for an upcoming half-marathon to be cancelled to avoid ‚Äúdisastrous health consequences‚Äù. Delhi‚Äôs air quality is extremely poor for most of the year because of road dust, open fires, vehicle exhaust fumes, industrial emissions and the burning of crop residues in neighbouring states. But conditions worsen in the winter when slow winds and cool temperatures trap pollutants closer to the ground. 
Photos: Sajjad Hussain, Dominique Faget, Money Sharma, Rajat Gupta, R S Iyer

Vietnamese photographer Quoc Nguyen Linh Vinh won the 10th annual Ciwem environmental photographer of the year competition with this image of a young girl and her mother making their living by collecting waste in the country. The unique U-shaped troughs of the The Wave in Arizona are very popular among hikers. European tourists are especially keen to visit. Because of the sandstone rock formation's fragility, a daily lottery system is used to hand out ten online hiker permits for the next day. Only then will you be given a map... Photo: Mark Ralston

On the Micronesian island of Pingelap, a high percentage of the population has a rare genetic condition called achromatopsia - meaning they see the world in black and white. @sanne_de_wilde experiments with photography to show how they might see the world.

1896 was the year of the first modern Olympics, Queen Victoria became Britain's longest reigning monarch and the world's oldest man, Celino Villaneuva Jaramillo, was born. According to his Chilean identity card, 'Don Celino' is 121 years old. That makes him four years older than the Guinness-listed oldest person. Exact details about his youth are hard to come by because he is 85% deaf, however, we do know that he never married or had any children.

Members of the No Trump coalition struggle with police officers during a rally opposing Donald Trump's visit to Seoul. These are prototypes for Donald Trump‚Äôs proposed border wall. They were selected from hundreds of entries in a bidding process that began in March. This month, they're being tested to see how they hold up against attempts to climb over, tunnel under, or bash through them.

Collins Dictionary have declared "fake news" the word of the year due to its ubiquitous presence ‚Äì thanks in part to Donald Trump. Other words on the list include "Corbynmania", meaning a fervent enthusiasm for Jeremy Corbyn and "cuffing season" the period of autumn and winter, when single people are considered likely to seek settled relationships.

As of 2019 tourists will no longer be able to climb Uluru after managers of the Australian‚Äã national park voted unanimously for the ban. Its traditional owners, the¬†Anangu, have long-requested that people don't climb the rock because of its¬†sacred¬†history¬†‚Äì but also because they felt¬†a¬†cultural responsibility for the high number of injuries and deaths.

The scene outside Banksy‚Äôs Walled Off Hotel in Bethlehem, where he is holding a surreal 'apology party' for Palestinians on behalf of the UK. Eight people were killed and 11 were injured after a man drove a truck into a cycleway in lower Manhattan last night. The suspect has been named as Sayfullo Saipov, a 29-year-old Uzbek national who entered the US in 2010. Just two hours after the attack, tens of thousands of New Yorkers attended the Village Halloween Parade, which officials said would continue despite the attack. ‚ÄúTo be honest with you, there‚Äôs a tragedy every day somewhere in the world, and we have to continue living,‚Äù said Windy Vargas, who went to the parade with her kids, wanting to give them something ‚Äúpositive‚Äù in a world full of negativity.

Photo: Andres Kudacki/AP

New Zealand‚Äôs new government is thinking about creating a new visa category to help relocate people from the Pacific who have been displaced by climate change. Under the current 1951 refugee convention people can only seek asylum if they are being persecuted by race, religion, nationality or by political or religious membership. But in places like Kiribati, ocean waters are threatening to shrink the land, increase storm damage and destroy crop-growing. A new humanitarian visa could be life-saving for those affected.

This eye-popping scene was captured in Barisal, Bangladesh, where water lilies grow across thousands of acres. The white water lily is the national flower of Bangladesh.

Did you know that some dolphins, whales and porpoises lead 'human-like lives'? Writing in the Nature Ecology and Evolution journal, researchers have revealed that complex social and cultural characteristics like hunting together, developing regional dialects and learning from observation are linked to the expansion of the animals‚Äô brains. They observed dolphins playing with humpback whales, helping fishermen with their catches and even producing signature whistles for dolphins that are absent ‚Äì suggesting the animals may even gossip.

Actor @rosemcgowan ‚Äì¬†one of the most outspoken accusers of the shamed Harvey Weinstein ‚Äì was suspended from Twitter after calling out fellow actor Ben Affleck for his silence. Bangladesh has announced it will build one of the world‚Äôs biggest refugee camps to house more than 800,000 Rohingya Muslims who have sought asylum from violence in Myanmar.

Today's shooting in Las Vegas has been named the deadliest mass shooting in US history. At least 50 people were killed and more than 200 injured when a gunman fired on a music festival from a hotel overlooking the event. The gunman has been named by police as 64-year-old Stephen Paddock.

Julia Louis-Dreyfus has gone public with her breast cancer diagnosis ‚Äì using the moment to remind her followers of the importance of universal healthcare.¬†The Veep¬†actress's statement has been met with a wave of support on Twitter,¬†including from former real life vice-president Joe Biden who said: "We Veeps stick together. Jill and I, and all of the Bidens, are with you, Julia."

Women in Saudi Arabia have finally been granted the right to drive after King Salman requested that drivers' licences be issued to women who wanted them. Manal al-Sharif, who became the public face of the campaign to allow female drivers in Saudi Arabia, tweeted: "Today the last country on earth to allow women to drive...we did it." Teenage girls are experiencing stress, anxiety and depression at a rising rate in England. New NHS data reveals that the number of times a girl aged 17 or under has been admitted to hospital because of self-harm has jumped by 68%. We spoke to young women and their parents about what triggered their depression and panic attacks and the strategies they're using to cope - follow the link in bio to read their experience.

Emergency crews and ordinary people were digging with their bare hards through rubble in search of trapped survivors after a powerful earthquake stuck central Mexico yesterday, toppling dozens of buildings and killing at least 216 people. The magnitude 7.1 quake is the deadliest to hit the country since 1985. Much of Mexico City is built on a former lake bed and the soil is known to amplify the effects of earthquakes even hundreds of miles away. Improved safety laws and better disaster preparation means that earthquakes since 1985 have caused less damage in the capital. But Tuesday‚Äôs quake struck without warning, despite an alert mechanism which normally sounds an alarm beforehand. #M√©xicoUnido

Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (Daca) is a US programme that protects young undocumented immigrants who were brought to the US as children or came with families who overstayed visas. Donald Trump has decided to end the programme, casting a shadow over 800,000 young people. 70% of them arrived as children from Mexico and 90% were born in Latin America. 15 states are currently challenging the decision in court, arguing that targeting these people shows racial hostility.

Rohingya refugees wait to cross the border to Bangladesh after a fresh serge of violence against them at the hands of Myanmar's security forces. 120,000 people have already fled Rakhine state, but 400,000 remain trapped in conflict zones. About 40 McDonald‚Äôs employees are striking today because of low wages and zero-hours contracts. It's the first strike the company is facing since it opened in the UK in 1974. India‚Äôs top court has banned a controversial Islamic practice that allows men to divorce their wives instantly by saying the word 'talaq' (divorce) three times. Legendary actor Jeanne Moreau has passed away at the age of 89. When asked if she ever felt nostalgic for the French New Wave, the cinematic period responsible for making her an icon, her answer was firm: ‚ÄúNostalgia for what? Nostalgia is when you want things to stay the same. I know so many people staying in the same place. And I think, my God, look at them! They‚Äôre dead before they die. That‚Äôs a terrible risk. ‚ÄãVenezuela is fast sliding into chaos. Clashes between protesters and security forces have caused more than 100 deaths in recent months. Photos from the frontline of the anti-government protests have dominated the news, but this image shows another view: a shortage of basic food and medicine has plagued Venezuela, which, along violence and spiralling inflation, is driving millions to leave the country. The US has warned that Venezuela is heading for a dictatorship after president Nicol√°s Maduro won the vote to form an assembly tasked with rewriting the constitution. The assembly will have sweeping powers to reform or dissolve other state institutions, including the opposition controlled parliament.

Donald Trump says that the Pentagon can't be ‚Äòburdened‚Äô with the ‚Äòtremendous medical costs‚Äô of covering trans military members ‚Äì but a closer look at the cost of healthcare for transgender military members (which includes treatments like counselling and hormone replacement therapy) ‚Äì suggests it‚Äôs more like a drop in the ocean of the Pentagon‚Äôs annual budget. According to a 2016 study by the Rand Corporation, transgender-related healthcare for active duty military would cost between $2.4-$8.4 million. In 2014, the Pentagon spent $6.27 billion on healthcare costs for all active-duty personnel. That same fiscal year, the Pentagon spend $49.3 billion on all healthcare costs for members of the military, their family members, and retirees and their families.
Illustration: Guardian US Data Editor @mona_chalabi 
Illustration data:  US Transgender Survey, 2015, University of Chicago, 2016 and CDC 2017

Linkin Park frontman Chester Bennington has died at the age of 41. He was a compelling performer in one of this century‚Äôs biggest-selling musical acts. In 2011, after Linkin Park released their concept album A Thousand Suns, Bennington spoke to us about the band's leftfield shift: "When you come out of the gate with a record like Hybrid Theory, from a business point of view it's really dumb not to keep on doing that. But we aren't a manufacturer. We are artists, and we've gone philosophically back to where we were writing music before we sold a record. When we were excited about a song." #RIPChester

Hundreds of people marched in London yesterday to protest against the government‚Äôs response to the Grenfell Tower fire, which has killed at least 79 people. @Banksy has offered voters in a number of constituencies a free limited edition print if they vote for anyone other than the Conservatives in the general election on 8 June. The offer applies to voters who live in Bristol North West, Bristol West, North Somerset, Thornbury and Yate, Kingswood, and Filton and Bradley Stoke. ‚ÄúSimply send in a photo of your ballot paper from polling day showing you voted against the Conservative incumbent and this complimentary gift will be mailed to you,‚Äù he writes on his website. But there are strict rules about taking photos inside polling stations. According to the law: ‚Äúno person shall directly or indirectly induce a voter to display his ballot paper after he has marked it so as to make known to any person the name of the candidate for whom he has or has not voted or as to the number on the back of the ballot paper given to the voter at that station.‚Äù

Emmanuel Macron has won the French presidency with a decisive victory over the far-right Marine Le Pen. Macron, 39, a former economy minister who ran as an independent promising to shake up the French political system, took 65.1% of the vote to Le Pen‚Äôs 34.9%, according to initial projections from early counts. But Le Pen‚Äôs score marks a historic high for the French far right. The anti-immigration, anti-EU Front National‚Äôs supporters asserted that the party has a central place as an opposition force in France. Macron, who has never held elected office and was unknown until three years ago, is France‚Äôs youngest president. He will take over a country under a state of emergency, still facing a major terrorism threat and struggling with a stagnant economy after decades of mass unemployment.

Tens of thousands of people took to the streets of Caracas, Venezuela to express their anger and frustration at an administration that has led the country with the planet‚Äôs biggest oil supplies into the world‚Äôs deepest economic recession. If there were such people in Chechnya, the law-enforcement organs wouldn‚Äôt need to have anything to do with them because their relatives would send them somewhere from which there is no returning.‚Äù Human rights activists are trying to get dozens of gay Chechens out of Russia to protect them from the authorities or even their own relatives.

A painting in this year‚Äôs Whitney Biennial in New York is being protested for perceived racial insensitivity. 'Open Casket' by American painter Dana Schutz depicts the mutilated corpse of Emmett Till, a 14-year-old black boy murdered in 1955 after it was falsely claimed he flirted with a white woman. üîπüîπüîπ
Parker Bright has been protesting in front of the painting every day since the exhibition opened last Friday with a T-shirt that says ‚ÄúNo lynch mob‚Äù on the front and ‚ÄúBlack death spectacle‚Äù on the back. ‚ÄúI wanted to confront people with a living, breathing black body", he explains. üîπüîπüîπ Artist Hannah Black has written an open letter asking for the painting to be destroyed. "The painting should not be acceptable to anyone who cares or pretends to care about Black people because it is not acceptable for a white person to transmute Black suffering into profit and fun", she wrote.
üîπüîπüîπ
‚ÄúIt is easy for artists to self-censor‚Äù Schutz, who created the painting, said in response to the protests. ‚ÄúTo convince yourself to not make something before you even try. There were many reasons why I could not, should not, make this painting ‚Ä¶ (but) art can be a space for empathy, a vehicle for connection.‚Äù She also added that the painting won't be for sale.

This four-year-old girl walked miles through the freezing Siberian wilderness to get help for her sick grandmother. Saglana Salchak was living with her grandparents at their farm in the taiga forest near the Mongolian border. Last month she woke up and found that her 60-year-old grandmother wasn't moving. She decided to walk to the next homestead for help, according to local news. She only took a box of matches with her in case she had to light a fire and set out into the early-morning darkness, where temperatures hit -34C (-29F). Luckily, she didn't get stuck in the snow or encounter any wolves. After five gruelling miles Saglana finally reached her neighbours‚Äô house. They called in medics from the village, who checked on Saglana before trekking to her grandparents‚Äô place. There they discovered that her grandmother had sadly died of a heart attack. Although she caught a cold, Saglana quickly recovered at the local hospital and is now living at a social centre, where she just celebrated her fifth birthday. Her mother is facing criminal charges for leaving a minor in danger. 
Photo: Yury Darbaa/Siberian Times

Alma de √Åfrica (Soul of Africa) play in the third division in Andaluc√≠a, that great gateway for African migrants to Spain. Some of their footballers came by sea in small boats. Others came over land, climbing over fences or clinging to the underside of trucks. All of them have been brought together by football. 
The game is an opportunity to shrug off the difficulties of their daily lives: being unemployed, worrying about money, not knowing where they'll sleep tonight, let alone next month. Then there's the fear that they won't get their paperwork issued or renewed or, worse still, that they'll be thrown out. 
The Guardian, along with three other newspapers, have launched a new project to learn more about Europe's new arrivals and the communities in which they are making their homes. Click the link in our bio to find out more about the new arrivals project.

Tucked away in a landscape of granite and hills in south-west France, dozens of miles from the nearest city Limoges, the village of Bugeat is an unlikely place to resettle a refugee family from Sudan. But that is the plan - and the villagers can speak of little else these days. 
Despite a national picture in which the likes of the French far right are making immigration a dirty word, there is a frisson of excitement about the expected new arrivals - a Christian family from South Sudan consisting of a single mother with four children who is coming over with her mother, two of her brothers and a sister.

Today the Guardian is liveblogging from The Royal Brompton hospital in Chelsea. The hospital is one of three London hospitals with the facilities and staff to treat children with heart defects, but the congenital heart disease services at the Brompton are under threat of closure. 
Up to 6,300 babies are born with congenital heart disease in the UK each year, all of whom require specialised care. Some will need many operations throughout their life. Click on the link in the bio to follow today's liveblog.

Meet Sana and Ghena of the Abu Rasheed family from Damascus. They are generally relieved to have swapped the misery and danger of Syria for the cool tranquility of L√ºneburg in Lower Saxony. 
The family is an archetype of the new arrivals in Germany, grateful but wistful, eager but uncertain, willing to assimilate but not to abandon their own culture. Their successes and failures will tell us much about how Germany is going about dealing with its biggest migration challenge since the immediate aftermath of the second world war. 
The Guardian, along with three other newspapers, have launched a new project to find out what is going on with the 1 million-plus people who have entered Europe over the past couple of years. Click the link in our bio to find out more about the new arrivals project.

"They left Afghanistan a family of nine. They arrived in the UK a family of two." Meet nine-year-old Wali Khan Norzai and his father Said. Having fled their homeland of Afghanistan together as a family, they have not heard from Wali Kahn's mother or his six siblings since being separated from them in the mountainous, borderland darkness between Iran and Turkey over a year ago. 
As an asylum seeker, Said is not allowed to work and has few connections in Derby where he and his son have been sent to live by the Home Office. He is tormented by thoughts of his missing wife and children daily.

The Guardian, along with three other newspapers, have launched a new project to learn more about Europe's new arrivals and the communities in which they are making their homes. Click the link in our bio to find out more about the new arrivals project.

Former Soviet gymnast Olga Korbut, who dazzled spectators at the 1972 Munich Games, has sold her Olympic medals after apparently falling into financial difficulty.

The US auction house Heritage Auctions claimed she "single handedly upended the stereotype of the Soviet athlete as a stone-faced automaton" and there was "hardly a gymnast alive who doesn't credit this tiny force of nature for the explosion of the sport's popularity on a global level." Photo: AP

As #blackhistorymonth comes to an end in the US, it's worth revisiting the fantastic data visualisations Guardian US Data Editor @mona_chalabi has recreated. Originally created by WEB Du Bois in 1900, the illustrations were made to challenge the belief that black Americans were inferior to white Americans. Mona found data to redraw the original images and show what America is like 117 years later.

This particular illustration shows how wealth varies by race in America today. The bottom line is that for every dollar a black household in America has in net assets, a white household has 16.5 more. Click the link in our bio to find out more.

Elizabeth Warren was silenced for reading out a letter during a debate about whether Jeff Sessions should be the next US attorney general. The letter was written 30 years ago by Coretta Scott King (Martin Luther King's widow), in which she urged against making Sessions a federal judge. "Mr. Sessions has used the awesome powers of his office in a shabby attempt to intimidate and frighten elderly black voters. For this reprehensible conduct, he should not be rewarded with a federal judgeship", Scott King wrote in 1986. Mitch McConnell, the Republican majority leader, objected that by reading this letter Warren was breaking a rule against one Senate member attacking the conduct of another. "She was warned. She was given an explanation. Nevertheless, she persisted‚Äù, McConnell said. Sessions has been confirmed as nominee for attorney general despite controversies surrounding his reported views on race and civil rights. 
Illustration: @kimothyjoy

It's taken almost 100 years to come to fruition, but the first phase of New York City's 2nd Ave subway was finally opened to the public at noon on 1 January 2017. Martin Luther King Day is a federal public holiday in the US celebrating the birth of the civil rights leader. It wasn't easy to establish this holiday. The bill proposing the day was introduced just a few days after King's death in 1968, but the first MLK holiday didn't happen until 1986. There was fierce resistance, particularly from conservatives and some white southern politicians. In fact, consensus that King was a man worth celebrating is relatively new. Ronald Reagan once described him as a "near-communist" and John McCain, the man Obama defeated in 2008, voted against recognising the day. Fierce campaigning by black legislators, trade unionists and civil rights workers helped pass the bill.

This is three-year-old Maesa Omar in the Idomeni refugee camp. She is pictured here hiding from the rain under one of the few covered areas in the camp, which regularly became badly flooded. Reem carries her child over the train tracks in the Idomeni refugee camp, where she lived for four months after leaving Deir ez-Zor in Syria. She left a good life, she told me. She was an English teacher and her husband was a university professor. @aliceaedy #guardiantakeover

Status Quo guitarist Rick Parfitt has died aged 68. The band's career spanned five decades, including 22 top ten singles in the UK. Their first UK hit single came in 1968, with their most recent in 2010. Parfitt is pictured during a concert in 1973.

I met sisters Maesa, Milaf and Zayneb Omar on my second day volunteering in the Idomeni refugee camp. A Kurdish family of six from al-Qamishli, Syria, they lived in a two-man tent for four months. With absolutely nothing to do, our days were structured around meal times. A common misconception about refugees is that they don‚Äôt have smartphones. In fact, their phones are a crucial way to stay in touch with family and one of the only forms of entertainment in camps where there is nothing to do. @aliceaedy #guardiantakeover

I took this photo of three-month-old Zuheira following a few days of snow in northern Greece. Many of the camps in Greece are inadequately prepared for winter: in warehouses without insulation, heating or flooring. While a child might be born in hospital, the mother has to return to the camp immediately, despite the shocking conditions. @aliceaedy #guardiantakeover

This is Zayneb, a seven-year-old Kurdish girl from al-Qamishli, Syria. This photo shows her playing dress-up with her mother. Zayneb suffers from severe night terrors and her mother regularly loses consciousness. One evening, her mother fell unconscious for about five minutes. When I called for medical assistance I was told it was the result of stress and there was nothing we could do. After this, they became classified as a vulnerable case and were recently moved to a one-bedroom apartment. While living outside of camp is undeniably a better option, it is in some ways a double-edged sword. As more families move off-site, the crisis becomes less visible and it‚Äôs a greater challenge for NGOs to keep track of the families, give them access to education, medical care and food. - @aliceaedy #guardiantakeover

22-year-old photographer @aliceaedy is taking over our Instagram today. British photojournalist @jimmy.nelson.official spent four years documenting the world's indigenous cultures for his Before They Pass Away project. The images are to go on display this week at @laphotographiegalerie in Brussels. 
This photograph is of a young woman of the Miao tribe from the southern province of Guiyang in China. In the Miao tribe women wear woollen headpieces that were traditionally made from the hair of their ancestors - in remembrance. These headdresses are first fixed to the women's real hair, then a decorative bun of linen, wool and ancestral hair is wrapped around the horn. Together with the native costumes, the headdress composes the standard attire for festival season. 
Photograph: Jimmy Nelson

Giraffes are at risk of extinction after suffering a 38% decline in their numbers since 1985, falling from about 157,000 to 97,500 today. Ellen DeGeneres received a Presidential Medal of Freedom yesterday. This is what Barack Obama said in her honour üèÖ "It‚Äôs easy to forget now, when we‚Äôve come so far, where now, marriage is equal under the law, just how much courage was required for Ellen to come out on the most public of stages almost 20 years ago. Just how important it was, not just to the LGBT community but for all of us to see somebody so full of kindness and light, somebody we liked so much, somebody who could be our neighbour or our colleague or our sister, challenge our own assumptions. Remind us that we have more in common than we realise. Push our country in the direction of justice. What an incredible burden that was to bear. To risk your career like that, people don‚Äôt do that very often. And then to have the hopes of millions on your shoulders. But it‚Äôs like Ellen says, ‚ÄúWe all want a tortilla chip, that can support the weight of guacamole.‚Äù Which really makes no sense to me. But I thought would break the mood because I was getting kind of choked up. And she did pay a price. We don‚Äôt remember this. I hadn‚Äôt remembered it. She did, for a pretty long stretch of time, even in Hollywood. And yet, today, every day, in every way, Ellen counters what too often divides us, with the countless things that bind us together, inspires us to be better, one joke, one dance at a time."

Hi everyone! This is @paulshiakallis. I‚Äôll be taking over the Guardian‚Äôs Instagram account today to show you my portraits of the female ‚ÄòMarok‚Äô, a thriving part of #Botswana‚Äôs #heavymetal sub-culture. Dr Susan Bowie has a small practice of 760 patients, nearly everyone in a community of 764 dispersed over 77 sq miles of open country in #Shetland. She knows them all. Bowie‚Äôs patients regard her surgery as the glue that helps bind the community, which relies on interdependency and on mutual aid. It appears to be thriving; youngsters are returning home to start families. For her patients, Bowie is the quintessential rural #doctor. Barring rare days off or her infrequent holidays, she is on call around the clock and routinely makes house calls, checking on the health of her elderly, frail and housebound patients and delivering prescriptions. #ThisIsTheNHS
Photo: Murdo Macleod

Photographer Laurent Kronental spent four years documenting the lives of older citizens living in the #GrandsEnsembles housing estates built around #Paris after the second world war. This is Cit√© du Parc et cit√© Maurice-Thorez, Ivry-sur-Seine.
