Jennifer Allison is the senior research #nurse manager at the NIHR Wellcome Trust Southampton Clinical Research Facility, which has about 300 clinical studies and trials taking place at a time. Coming from the US, where she qualified as a paediatric and neonatal intensive care nurse, the #NHS seems ‚Äúa gift. Just an amazing institution, one that I feel extremely proud and privileged to be a part of." Her job, she says, ‚Äúis ultimately about making the best research available to every patient. And research has to be key to the organisation‚Äôs future. How can you ensure the care you spend money on is the best care unless you do research?‚Äù #ThisIsTheNHS
Photo: David Levene

"Sometimes patients don‚Äôt just need medicines, they need kindness, a little love. So I am happy here.‚Äù Arvin Pagkaliwangan has been a general porter at Southampton General Hospital for 13 years. His job entails taking hospital patients to and from the theatre and transporting samples and specimen. ‚ÄúI not only enjoy it, I‚Äôm proud to be doing it,‚Äù he says. #ThisIsTheNHS
Photo: David Levene

‚ÄúNursing is like an addiction,‚Äù says Anne Barks. ‚ÄúI believe there‚Äôs a special quality in people who want to #nurse: a compassion that makes you want to help people, treat people with dignity.‚Äù Barks is a nursing care coach at Royal Stoke University Hospital. Following her retirement, she came back to Stoke part-time last year to help train newly qualified nurses, who are mainly from overseas. The hospital recruited about 150 overseas nurses over the course of the year, in small groups ‚Äì most from Spain and Portugal, but also from Italy, Greece and Croatia. #ThisIsTheNHS 
Photo: David Levene

Rob Hinchliffe is a consultant vascular surgeon. He wears many hats: ‚ÄúClinically, I deal here with the broad problems associated with vascular disease ‚Äì aortic aneurysms, blocked arteries, that kind of thing,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm an academic, part-employed by the university. And I‚Äôm an editor at the British Journal of Surgery.‚Äù Hinchliffe feels the organisation ‚Äúis at a crossroads. The government has to decide whether to put more money in so it remains free at the point of care, or to introduce a rationed, insurance-based system.‚Äù He objects to insurance-based systems because ‚Äúultimately they are not fair‚Äù, and believes the most appropriate solution would be ‚Äúto spend more, which probably means paying more tax." #ThisIsTheNHS
Photo: David Levene

A broad and smiling Zimbabwean, Witness Dzobo arrived in Britain as a biomedical scientist in 2003. ‚ÄúHe has since completed an MSc ‚Äì and is studying for a doctorate ‚Äì in a field he describes as harbouring ‚Äúthe hidden professions‚Äù of the #NHS. ‚ÄúSeventy per cent of patients in the NHS receive an intervention from a pathology service, and our labs provide 94% of objective medical data,‚Äù he explains. Like many of his overseas colleagues, he remains astonished at how some Britons view the NHS. ‚ÄúThey complain about the parking! From where I come, this service is wonderful. Some people could be a little more aware of how they use it.‚Äù #ThisIsTheNHS 
Photo taken at Southampton General hospital by David Levene

Meet Karolina Elias. She's 29 and works as a staff nurse at St George's Hospital. Elias moved to London three years ago; her boyfriend was already here, working as a bus driver. Armed with a master‚Äôs in nursing, she spent her first year working in a nursing home but found it ‚Äúa little bit ‚Ä¶ boring‚Äù. She is now on a general surgery ward, with 22 beds and five other nurses, working from 7.30am to 8pm, or nights from 7.30pm to 8am. "I try to make people on my ward a little bit happier, a little bit calmer. My father always told me, you are someone who helps people ‚Äì it‚Äôs what you do." #ThisIsTheNHS is the story of one of the most complex organisations in the world, told through the voices of those on the frontline. In #Iran, girls are held criminally accountable by law from the age of nine and can be sentenced to death by hanging for crimes such as murder, drug trafficking and armed robbery. One week later, a group of youths attacked her in a park in #Tehran to gang-rape her. To save herself, she wounded her own arm with a knife she carried in her purse. The police officers found her unconscious on the ground, and after treatment, she was transferred to the juvenile delinquents correction centre.

#YearInPictures - 13 November 2015: "Usually #Paris at midnight on Friday is very festive, noisy, there‚Äôs a lot of people on the street. That night, I sensed an eerie quietness. There was barely any traffic. As I approached the 18th arrondisement, there were more and more police, firefighters, first responders, even the army. Triage centres were set up in restaurants across from the #Bataclan. It was very hard to get through ‚Äì the last thing I wanted was to get in the way of these people doing their jobs, but I had to do my job and find out what was happening. I spotted this one body lying on the pavement, and I just snapped three frames ‚Äì bam, bam, bam ‚Äì without thinking much. I was absolutely stunned by the response. People saw things that I didn‚Äôt see. There are the posts, which look almost like people at a funeral. The dead leaves surrounding the body. The picture represents all the victims." - Jerome Delay for AP

#YearInPictures - 2 September 2015: "When pateras (refugee boats) arrive at #GranCanaria, they usually don‚Äôt make it to the beach ‚Äì there are surveillance systems that intercept them miles away. This time they reached land, and it all happened very quickly ‚Äì I got a call from the #RedCross, grabbed my equipment and got there before the emergency services. There were people scattered over the beach with wet clothes, resting or lying down, and it was dark. I often wonder what would make someone risk their life on a crammed dinghy ‚Äì and you realise it when you look them in the eyes. That look of fear, sadness, pain, anger, helplessness ‚Äì it‚Äôs telling you his entire story." - Photographer Borja Suarez for Reuters

#YearInPictures - 22 April 2015: "When the #Calbuco volcano started erupting, I was getting ready to celebrate my birthday. We were about 30km from #PuertoMontt, the city closest to the volcano. It was the first time the Calbuco had erupted in 43 years. At first no one noticed, but soon people were freaking out, as it‚Äôs impossible to predict how dangerous a #volcano will be. The opportunity for the photo came at dusk, 45 minutes after the eruption. I took others, but they don‚Äôt have the same colour scheme. I didn‚Äôt have my usual equipment with me ‚Äì just a small compact camera." - @imaginario11 
Photo: Alex Vidal Brecas/EPA

#YearInPictures - 26 September 2015: "This #highline was strung between two sides of #Mol√©sonPeak, a mountain which curves round at the top like a circle in the Swiss Prealps. The peak is 2000m, just up above this huge area of sea fog. There were about 20 guys taking it in turns to walk the entire length of the highline without falling off, and they couldn‚Äôt do it. They kept falling. They were attached with a little rope, but I still had vertigo watching them. For these guys, walking across the rope without falling is a personal and artistic achievement. It‚Äôs about man fighting nature, fighting the elements, and fighting against fear." - Photographer Jean-Christophe Bott for EPA

Sightseeing usually revolves around buildings, parks and sprawling vistas, but when German photographer @SebastianErras was in Marrakech a few months ago, he turned his gaze downwards to the #mosaic floors. Once back in Paris, where he lives, he started photographing the floors there: ‚ÄúI had no idea there was such a variety of floors in Paris. It‚Äôs like a treasure hunt.‚Äù He then went to Venice, where he spent four days seeking out floors for an interactive article on website Pixartprinting. ‚ÄúA lot of these are hidden in churches and monuments. People who live there have told me, ‚ÄòI walk here every day and I never noticed the floors‚Äô. It‚Äôs a different way of discovering a city.‚Äù

The Suijia railway in #Heilongjiang province, photographed by Wang Wei, who has spent 10 years travelling all over #China to photograph trains and new lines. In just over seven years, about 11,800 miles (19,000km) of high-speed track ‚Äì about 55% of the global total ‚Äì has been laid in China. ‚ÄúWhat the world did in half-a-century, we have done in 10 years,‚Äù said Zhao Jian, a transport expert from Jiaotong University in Beijing.

From the 1960s to the 1980s, Arkady Bronnikov visited correctional facilities all over the #SovietUnion, photographing thousands of tattooed inmates to decode their body art. Arkady helped to solve many crimes by identifying criminals based on their ink. In this tattoo, the Madonna and Child is a thieves‚Äô talisman, acting as a guardian from misfortune and misery. It also means that the bearer has been a thief from an early age: ‚Äòa child of prison‚Äô.

This photo was taken on the outskirts of Islamabad, #Pakistan in 2014. Vendors pass by who sell balloons and bubbles; simple stuff that people can afford to buy. For these children it‚Äôs way more than a balloon. It could be the only toy that they could ever have. I have seen them playing with stones, happier than children with PlayStations. These were the messages I used to learn walking in these environments: that you don‚Äôt need much to be happy. @mmuheisen #guardiantakeover

A simple image can show through the body language of the mum‚Äôs hand how worried she is, how lost she feels. She has no idea what to do or what‚Äôs next, but she can still provide the maximum she can to protect her children. This is Kutana al-Hamadi, a 24-year-old Syrian refugee who is tending to her seven-month-old son who is suffering from malnutrition in an informal settlement on the outskirts of Mafraq, Jordan. @mmuheisen #guardiantakeover

A refugee woman from Iraq holds her child shortly after arriving on the island of #Lesbos in November 2015. I always noticed that in very hard conditions families stick together. A mother or a father has one goal in these circumstances: to protect their children. They could be powerless, they could be with no money, but at least they do their best to protect their children and to give them as much love as possible. @mmuheisen #guardiantakeover

This portrait was part of several other portraits of #Afghan refugee children that I photographed in January 2014. I decided to put a name and an age to every child that I photographed. Instead of writing ‚Äòan Afghan refugee‚Äô, I started presenting them by their names. This girl is laiba Hazrat. She‚Äôs six years old. She‚Äôs an Afghan refugee who lives in a slum in Pakistan with her family. It‚Äôs just a small introduction, but I think her haunting beauty, which is mixed with the hard environment, makes you as an audience think: ‚ÄúI wonder what life could be like through the eyes of an Afghan child.‚Äù @mmuheisen #guardiantakeover

On this day in November 2015, there was news that only Afghans, Syrians and Iraqis are allowed to cross the border to keep on their journey to Europe. So people of other nationalities were stranded on the Greek-Macedonian border. These people were stranded for weeks, they lost hope, they felt powerless. There was this man who just collapsed, he couldn‚Äôt take it any more. He was approached by another migrant who embraced him and gave him comfort and calmed him down. All this man needed was to feel safe, to feel part of the pack. @mmuheisen #guardiantakeover

In my photography, I like to look for hope through the rubble. If you go through any camp or any story there are two sides: there is the side where you show the dirt, you show the poverty, and there is the side that shows how life goes on. So I point my camera and I try to show how life doesn‚Äôt stop, even in the middle of these difficult circumstances. This is Zubaida Faisal, a Syrian refugee girl who I photographed skipping in an informal settlement near the Syrian border in July 2015. @mmuheisen #guardiantakeover

Syrian refugee children attend a class at a makeshift school near the Syrian border on the outskirts of #Mafraq, Jordan in August 2015. Children inside these camps could attend classes for some hours to learn the maximum possible with the minimum resources. These moments that I capture, the spontaneous moments, a child could never fake. Children are the most affected by any conflict, so in my coverage of refugees I mostly focus on children. @mmuheisen #guardiantakeover

Hello! This is @mmuheisen and I‚Äôll be taking over the Guardian‚Äôs Instagram feed today. I‚Äôm the Chief Photographer for the Middle East, Afghanistan & Pakistan at The Associated Press and have been photographing #refugees since 2005. In 2009, I started focusing totally on refugee issues and contribute most of my work around this theme. Follow #guardiantakeover to discover the stories behind some of my photos.

High up in the slate mines in #Khanayara, Himachel Pradesh in northern India, the air is thin and the track is steep and covered in small rocks and slate. Efrida‚Äôs son was born at night, and the midwives used their torches as they worked to deliver him safely. Malawi is officially the poorest country in the world, according to the World Bank. It‚Äôs not a big deal: when the floods come, we take our stuff and leave for a while. The only problem is the thieves; we have to visit almost every day to protect our homes."

Common in the winter, radiation fog builds when the land cools under clear night skies by thermal radiation. As the ground chills, so does the air directly above. And since cooler air holds less moisture, the further the temperature drops, the more moisture condenses to form layers of #fog.

#China has announced the end to its decades-long one child policy. All couples will be allowed to have two children for the first time in more than three decades. China's highly controversial family planning rule was introduced in 1980 amid fears of a calamitous population explosion. China‚Äôs Communist rulers credit their policy with preventing 400 million births, but the draconian regulation has also been blamed for millions of forced abortions. Opponents say it has also created a demographic ‚Äútimebomb‚Äù with China‚Äôs 1.3 billion-strong population ageing rapidly and the country‚Äôs labour pool shrinking. The #UN estimates that by 2050 China will have nearly 440 million over-60s.

Photo: Frederic J Brown/AFP/Getty Images

3 of 3. 'Not so very long ago, Detroit was a rich, beautiful city, full of #vibrant people. I have been there twice recently and I was saddened by the status of the abandoned buildings and factories I saw. I imagined how the city, its streets and buildings might have looked in past decades. I found pictures from the previous century and combined them with the photographs I took during my most recent visit to #Detroit.' Photo: @floraborsiofficial

2 of 3. The City of Detroit has gone through a major economic and demographic decline in recent decades. The population of the city has fallen from a high of 1,850,000 in 1950 to 701,000 in 2013. The #automobile industry in has suffered from global competition and has moved much of the remaining production out of #Detroit. Photo: @floraborsiofficial
1 of 3. Photographer Flora Borsi has repopulated #Detroit with characters from its golden age, who wander the #modern streets. Photo: @floraborsiofficial

6/6. The Cromer Pier Show (also known as the Seaside Special) features more than 150 costumes, 48 pairs of shoes, 40 pairs of tights, 33 hats, 31 fascinators and 24 petticoats, all made by just two people: Laura Whyte and Beryl Patterson. It runs until 19 September, with two different shows each day. Photo: David Levene for the Guardian.

5/6. The Pavilion Theatre at the end of the pier is host to the last surviving pier show in Europe. Hugely popular in the 60s and 70s, this traditional variety format ‚Äì with song, dance, music, comedy and costume in one performance ‚Äì has largely died out. Photo: David Levene for the Guardian.

4/6. Harry,12 and Olly, 8, from Norwich, feed the seagulls on the pier. An early summer evening is the time for throwing stones and beachcombing as the light fades. Photo: David Levene for the Guardian.

3/6. 'I've never been so relaxed looking at an empty bucket in my whole life ... simple thrills are the best'. Crabbing is an essential part of British seaside life. The appeal of catching buckets full of crabs for hours is not entirely obvious, but it is a serious business on Cromer. Tourists flock to the pier to catch crabs over its side and then return them to the sea. Photo: David Levene for the Guardian.

2/6. The 500ft iron pier, was the inspired work of London engineering firm Douglass and Arnott. It opened in its current form in 1901. There were earlier timber attempts in the 19th century, but they did not withstand the heavy onslaught of the sea. Photo: David Levene for the Guardian.

1/6. As families head off to their #summer holidays, Britain‚Äôs piers are filling up with visitors. Guardian photojournalist David Levene has been to spend the day in #Cromer in #Norfolk. Cromer pier is 112 years old. It was a fashionable attraction for Victorians and Edwardians, after being built along with a string of grand hotels on the seafront at the end of the 19th century. The pier is home to the last end-of-pier show in Europe, now in its 38th year. Photo: David Levene for the Guardian.

6 of 6. A featherless chicken prances across the stage like a plump ballerina. This breed draws on the naturally occurring recessive mutation that eliminates feathers and is crossed with one of a favoured strain of broiler chicken. Photo: Tim Flach

5 of 6. This Hungarian puli, snapped mid-leap, has a wild, mop-like coat. The puli was originally a herding dog, used by the nomads of the Hungarian plains to round up livestock. Its curious corded fur is extremely thick and almost entirely waterproof. Photo: Tim Flach

4 of 6. This highly constructed image is of an Arabian halter, a supermodel of the #horse world. It has been composed to allude to George Stubbs‚Äôs famous painting Whistlejacket, utilising similar tones. Taken at the pristine Ajman stud in the United Arab Emirates, it was lit by a flash indoors, looking out of the window to the bright sunshine. Photo: Tim Flach
3 of 6. An axolotl, a type of salamander native to freshwater habitats around Mexico. Photo: Tim Flach
2 of 6. Diatou, left, and Cheka, a pair of bonobos. The species is native to the Congo basin in central Africa. Photo: Tim Flach

1 of 6. Tim Flach, renowned UK photographer, is exhibiting a series of his animal portraits at the Retina Scottish International Photography Festival, Edinburgh. Crossing the divide between a commercial photographer and fine artist his work often examines the anthropomorphism of creatures often in an abstract way. The photographs will be on display at the Gayfield Square venue, Edinburgh until 30 July. In this shot Kanja, a Bengal #tiger, shakes water off her coat. Photo: Tim Flach

Solar powered lights are photographed along the Hoernli ridge on the Matterhorn in Zermatt, Switzerland. The first ascent of the mountain on the Hoernli ridge was made by Briton Edward Whymper 150 years ago, on 14 July 1865, with six roped team members. The red light, fourth from top, marks the point where four men fell to their deaths on their descent of the North face.

Photo: Denis Balibouse/Reuters

Originally staged by the mayor of #Henley it included a fair and other amusements, but the emphasis quickly shifted to competitive amateur rowing. The 1839 regatta took place on a single afternoon but proved so popular with rowers that the racing was extended to two days from 1840. In 1886 the regatta stretched to three days, then four in 1906, and five in 1986. Photo: Sarah Lee

#Henley's royal regatta is a highlight of summer's traditional social and sporting season. It is probably the best-known regatta in the world, attracting thousands of visitors over a five-day period. There are more than 250 races of international standard, with Olympians taking part as well. Photo: Sarah Lee

Suggestions by climate campaigners that the reservoir of fossil fuel in Guanabara is a ‚Äúcarbon bomb‚Äù that should be left in the ground, are dismissed by some as hypocrisy. ‚ÄúThe big countries of the world today developed without any concern for the environment. The base of US development was the oil in the Gulf of Mexico. The base of the UK‚Äôs industrial revolution was coal. How can they now say we can‚Äôt use our own pre-salt?‚Äù says Guilherme de Oliveira Estrella, the retired Petrobras geologist whose team made the discovery of the deep-laying oil underneath a layer of salt on the sea bed.

He is not blind to the impact of his industry. Estrella grew up on Rio‚Äôs Ilha do Governador. ‚ÄúIt was a paradise in the 1940s and 50s,‚Äù he recalls. ‚ÄúThe big change came when Petrobras built their first refinery in 1961. That began the destruction of Guanabara Bay. It has been destroyed by so-called progress.‚Äù But, having found what he estimates to be 50bn barrels of oil, he says the government is right to put fossil-fuels first.

Alexandre Anderson, a local fisherman, vows to fight against the threat of oil in Guanabara. But the odds are stacked against him. Far more than BP in Britain or Exxon in the US, Petrobras stirs up nationalist passions in Brazil.

Established in 1953 by president Get√∫lio Vargas, it has been at the forefront of Brazil‚Äôs drive to catch up with the world‚Äôs leading economies. Until recently, it was the pride of the country, with the greatest stock valuation of any company in Latin America thanks to the pre-salt fields, which are its most valuable asset.

President Dilma Rousseff, a former energy minister and honorary chair of the state-controlled firm‚Äôs board, is the industry‚Äôs greatest cheerleader. Her ruling Workers Party claims oil revenues will fund programmes for education and poverty alleviation.

For more on this story and all our reporting on carbon bombs around the world, visit theguardian.com/carbon-bomb. Clickable link in bio

Photograph: Felix Clay for the Guardian

#keepitintheground #climatechange #climate #energy #environment #brazil #guanabarabay

It seems that Guanabara Bay has become Petrobras Bay.  Altogether, there are at least two refineries, four terminals, four shipyards, as well as countless storage tanks, support ships, service factories and underwater pipelines.

The waters - now deemed too dirty to swim in - are like the forecourt of a giant petrol station. But instead of cars lining up at the pumps, there are 30 huge tankers waiting to load or unload oil and gas at the terminals. A huge new refinery will soon be added to the list. Petrobras‚Äôs Comperj plant is now under construction close to the northeast - and currently least spoiled - corner of the bay. It will be the destination for gas from the pre-salt fields once a new pipeline is completed later this year.

On the surface, this 412 sq km body of water dotted with more than 100 islands is picture-postcard Brazil, a symbol of the country‚Äôs immense natural wealth and beauty and a backdrop for Rio‚Äôs world heritage tourist sites.

But oil-fuelled development is transforming this iconic landscape into a petrochemical and service centre for the oil and gas fields more than 200km offshore in the Campos and Santos basins.

The discovery of tens of billions of barrels of oil in fields far off the coast of Rio de Janeiro was billed as one of the biggest finds of this century when it was announced in 2006.

Many hoped it would deliver a bonanza for education and health and make Brazil one of world‚Äôs major economies.

But with the country‚Äôs biggest energy company, Petrobras, mired in debt and scandal, the low price of oil and the dangers of a second Deepwater Horizon, the viability of this massive undertaking has never been under more scrutiny.

When Alaska was bought by the US government in the mid 1800s for $7.2m (¬£4.6m) critics called it Seward‚Äôs folly after the secretary of state who was accused of overpaying the Russians.

It is tempting to think that the decision by Washington to grant drilling rights to Shell in the waters off Alaska this month may yet become known as something worse: Mankind‚Äôs folly.

Those against big oil‚Äôs Arctic adventure are aware that any success by Shell will have major reverberations around the top of the world. ConocoPhillips and other oil companies are present in Barrow and interested in the icy waters.

The Polish Institute of International Affairs (PISM) warned recently that Moscow is setting up a naval infantry brigade, an air defence division, and a coastal missile system, in outlying archipelagos in the Arctic Ocean.

The Ukraine crisis has ramped up tension ‚Äì as has a provocative visit to the Svalbard archipelago in the Arctic by Russia‚Äôs deputy prime minister, Dmitry Rogozin.

All the states surrounding the Arctic Ocean are involved in a kind of land grab, applying for right to license oil and gas by making territorial claims under a UN Law of the Sea Treaty.

In the Arctic there is irony: drilling for oil is only possible because
manmade climate change is already causing the region to grow warmer twice as fast as the rest of the planet. The melting ice makes more accessible these huge reserves of oil and gas.

A drop in the price of oil from $115 per barrel last summer to $65 now has forced oil companies ‚Äì including Shell ‚Äì to slash their annual capital spending.

But such is the lure of the Arctic for Shell that it has ring fenced this operation despite having spent $6bn on fruitless drilling so far.

Circumpolar Council, which represents 160,000 indigenous peoples from Alaska, through Canada and Greenland to Russia.

Aqqaluk Lynge, the chairman of the Council expressed his worst fears a few years ago when he said: ‚ÄúWhen I'm lying awake at night, I pray we don't find oil.‚Äù #keepitintheground #climatechange #climate #arctic #alaska #environment

Barrow, the most northerly city in the US, is ground zero for the world‚Äôs most controversial oil drilling campaign. Less than 1,200 miles from the north pole, Barrow is also known as a base for climate change study.

Originally called Ukpeagvik, place where the snowy owls are hunted, the town of 4,500 residents was renamed in 1825 after Sir John Barrow of the British Admiralty by naval officers mapping the region for the UK.

Now a new British presence is being established by the Anglo Dutch Shell and it is also not one which is welcome by all, especially some of those who live in the tumble of single story wooden homes that hug the shoreline.

Shell is exploring its own small section of the far north, but the US Geological Survey has estimated there could be 412bn barrels of oil equivalents reserves in the wider Arctic region.

A successful strike by Anglo Dutch energy group will trigger a black gold rush to the wider polar region which is believed to hold the last remaining giant reserves in the world.

The most vulnerable potential victims of big oil - the migrating eider ducks, the whales, walruses, seals and polar bears - have no say.

Rosemary Ahtuangaruak describes herself as an environmental justice adviser but is also a former mayor, trained health worker and stalwart defender of Inupiat culture. ‚ÄúI work with non¬≠profit organisations that want to protect the Arctic Ocean and wilderness areas. It‚Äôs about raising the importance of health, tradition and culture in the venues of those (Shell and others) who want to change our lands and waters,‚Äù she says, one eye on three grandchildren she is minding. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about the (any future oil) spill. They cannot clear up in ice conditions which we have for eight or nine months of the year. The eco system renewal, which is needed for the many different animals that migrate here, is important because we are feeding our families from the ocean. We must keep this environment pristine.‚Äù #keepitintheground #climatechange #environment #energy #arctic #alaska

It's hard for us to choose just one, but we went for the coastlines...after all, it is #WorldOceansDay.

Ma Haiming, one of the last remaining residents of Zhoutau village. Ningxia Province, China. 
Zhoutao would be one of the last villages to be officially resettled, into a bleak ranks of small brick houses outside a nearby town. Residents were encouraged to take doors, window frames, tiles and even bricks to expand their new homes, a programme that also made returning impossible.

Government threats to cut off power to a few light bulbs and flickering TVs after the village were eventually dropped, and those left behind says they are unbothered by officials, perhaps because they can see a few basic comforts will not be enough to revive a dying settlement.

The shuttering of the school, in a country that values education above almost all else, had already ensured that. There would be no new generation of children brought up in Zhoutao, the village killed off by drought and climate change.

Check out the full interactive at theguardian.com. Clickable link in bio.

#keepitintheground

There are no springs in the village, or natural wells, says farmer Wu Zhengfang, one of the few remaining residents. Instead underground tanks dug out by hand store the few inches of rain that fell each year, but as the population grew and the skies dried up, supplies often fell short. ‚ÄúWhen the water ran out we had to get together and pay for a driver to bring a tank,‚Äù she said in the one-room house she has refused to leave after four years of government cajoling and orders. ‚ÄúAnd nine out of ten years, we had drought.‚Äù They spent over ¬£500 on trucking water in when it ran out, half a year's earnings in a farming community.

Where migrants from other towns used wages to build new homes or educate their children, in Zhentao people drank away their earnings. ‚ÄúSometimes people come back,‚Äù Wu says. ‚ÄúBut only to visit the graves of their ancestors.‚Äù Check out the full interactive at theguardian.com. Clickable link in bio.

#keepitintheground

The near deserted village of Zhoutau. Ningxia Province, China.

Unlike almost everywhere else in China, the state is in retreat here. It is a community doomed by drought. The school is shuttered, its classrooms used as hay storage to feed goats and the village committee building, seat of Communist Party power for decades, is abandoned.

Over five decades average temperatures have risen 2.2 degrees, beyond the limit scientists and politicians have agreed is safe for the world overall, further drying out an already arid region.

Check out the full interactive at theguardian.com. Clickable link in bio.

#keepitintheground

Air pollution in China, from its factories and power stations, has got so bad that it kills over half a million people a year, and China's image has been dented by countless stories of the choking air, children playing under air purification domes, others struggling behind face masks.

Less visibly dramatic for now, but far more worrying to the government, is the threat coal poses to China's already scarce water supplies, its ability to feed itself and its vulnerability to extreme weather, by fuelling climate change.

Check out the full interactive at theguardian.com. Clickable link in bio.

#keepitintheground

Most of the mines burrowed into the parched hillsides of Wang Family Mountain have been closed for several years, but their shadow lingers in the blackened, failing lungs of the He family.

The mining carried He Jinbao off first, then two of his seven sons. Now two more He brothers are waiting to die, condemned by dust inhaled long ago on underground shifts.

They all hung up their hard hats years before their diagnoses, and thought they had escaped the mines with not just their lives but also a tiny slice of the country's new-found prosperity. ‚ÄúUntil fifteen years ago, we lived in a cave,‚Äù says He, now 50.

Check out the full interactive at theguardian.com. Clickable link in bio.

#keepitintheground

The landscape around Wang Jiashan coal mine. 
The fuel China dug up last year alone will produce around 9 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide as it burns, more than the all the coal used around the world in 1990.

The Chinese government accepted the scientific evidence for global warming years ago, but still faced bitter internal debates over what to do about it. 
The problem for those fighting to keep global warming within two degrees though, is that Chinese demand has expanded so fast that anything short of a dramatic cut in coal use ‚Äì something no one is even advocating ‚Äì leaves terrifying amounts of carbon dioxide pumping into the atmosphere.

Although it overtook the US nearly a decade ago to become the biggest emitter of greenhouse gases, per person it still produces barely a third as much carbon dioxide as the US and half Russian levels. 
Check out the full interactive at theguardian.com. Clickable link in bio.

#keepitintheground

He Quangfa. Coal miner who has black lung disease.  Ningxia Province, China. ‚ÄúI never heard anyone mention black lung disease,‚Äù said He Quanfa ‚Äì there is no cure for the illness which slowly hardens the lungs as they try to expel trapped coal dust. ‚ÄúIf I had, I might have worn a mask.‚Äù The tiny airborne specks pose a risk few miners understand as they head down into the country's pits, haunted by the more immediate fear of the explosions and collapses which claim hundreds of lives each year. 
Check out the full interactive at theguardian.com. Clickable link in bio.

#keepitintheground

Until the 1960s, Fort McKay First Nations people lived off the land by hunting and trapping, selling the pelts of lynx, beaver, and martens.

They were the days before bridges or snowmobiles. The only way to Fort McMurray was by barge in summer and dog sled in winter. 
Nobody from Fort McKay hunts anymore, or fishes from the river. Even the blueberries and herbs used in traditional medicine are coated in a thick layer of dust. Most homes use bottled water, supplied by the band. Short showers are advised. #climatechange #oil #canada #alberta #energy #environment #fortmckay #fortmcmurray Photo: David Levene for the Guardian

Find out more about the #keepitintheground campaign on theguardian.com

Of all the sights on the road to Fort McKay in Canada the most striking may be the forests reduced to a thin and spindly shell of their former majesty.

The draining of the land for strip mining and steam plants robbed the black spruce, larch, Alaska birch and other trees of the water they needed for survival.

Trees were entombed in thick coatings of dust. Sulphur and nitrogen dioxide ‚Äì two or three times above permitted levels in Europe ‚Äì inflicted a slow poisoning. Other trees leaned so far over they seemed almost parallel to the ground ‚Äì drunk trees, they call them here ‚Äì their roots loosened by the melting permafrost.

Photo: David Levene for the Guardian

#keepitintheground #climatechange #oil #alberta #canada #activism #energy #environment #trees

Today is Alan Rusbridger's last day as editor-in-chief of the Guardian, after a whopping 20 years at our helm. Here he is leading his final morning conference with Guardian staffers. And in case you didn't know, @arusbridger is an excellent instagrammer himself‚Ä¶

The Alberta government claims these tar sands are the third biggest proven crude reserve in the world after Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, with proven reserves of about 168bn barrels.

It demands huge amounts of energy to extract thick black petroleum from the earth, 3.2 to 4.5 times more greenhouse gas intensive than conventional oil. But the vast majority of the tar sands, 142,200 sq km, are too deep to mine, forcing the industry to resort to the far more energy intensive steam-assisted gravity drainage to melt the tar sands and flush it up from the depths to the top.

Photo: David Levene for the Guardian

#keepitintheground

Amid the strip mines and steam plants sprawled across the northern Alberta wilderness, Fort McKay is just a tiny dot on the map.

It is also one of the single biggest source sites of the carbon pollution that is choking the planet.

This tiny First Nations community grew rich on oil, and was wrecked by oil. Local Cece Fitzpatrick grabbed what she saw as a last chance for Fort McKay and decided to run for chief, promising to stand up to the industry which came here 50 years ago.

Photo: David Levene

#keepitintheground

A fourth year of severe #drought in California prompted the approval of emergency regulations to cut #water usage last week. The rules, which will be reviewed by state legal advisers before being implemented, require cutbacks of 4% to 36%. Communities that use the most water will be asked to take the deepest cuts. Saudi-led forces conducted air raids at dawn on Sunday in the Yemeni capital, Sana‚Äôa, targeting former president Ali Abdullah Saleh‚Äôs house, sources in his political party and residents said. Saleh and his family were safe and ‚Äúwell‚Äù after the air strikes, said Khabar, a news agency allied to the former Yemeni president said. 
The renewed bombing has thrown into question a proposed five-day ceasefire announced on Thursday by the US secretary of state, John Kerry, and the Saudi foreign minister, Adel al-Jubeir, to let humanitarian aid reach millions of civilians caught up in the conflict, which has killed more than 1,400 people since the Saudi-led campaign started on 26 March. ‚Ä¢ Photo: Mohamed Al-Sayaghi/Reuters #Yemen #News

Nigel Farage has resigned as the leader of #Ukip. He says he is a man of his word, having promised to step down should he fail to secure South #Thanet. The Guardian endorses Labour. "We believe Britain needs a new direction. At home, the economic recovery is only fragile, while social cohesion is threatened by the unequal impact of the financial crisis and the continuing attempt to shrink the postwar state. Abroad, Britain remains traumatised by its wars, and, like our neighbours, is spooked by Vladimir Putin, the rise of jihadist terrorism and by mounting migratory pressures ... Our view is clear. Labour provides the best hope for starting to tackle the turbulent issues facing us. On May 7, as this country makes a profound decision about its future, we hope Britain turns to Labour." #GE2015

The death toll in the #Nepal #earthquake rose to more than 3,700 on Monday and could climb higher as fears grow for the fate of people living in remote villages that remain out of the reach of search and rescue teams.

The earthquake ‚Äì Nepal‚Äôs worst in more than 80 years ‚Äì also injured more than 6,500 people and left thousands sleeping in the open while authorities battled against time to rescue anyone still alive beneath the rubble. Photo: Niranjan Shrestha/AP #News

In 2008, Oregon had no wolves. They were reintroduced to Idaho from Canada in 1995, in an attempt to revive an endangered species that was extinct in most of the American west. The last of the original Oregon population was shot in 1947 for a $5 bounty.

Having being systematically extirpated, they have bounced back quickly. "People used to think they were a really fragile species‚Äù, says Klavins, ‚Äúbut if we just don‚Äôt shoot them, they will recover‚Äù. Now there are 77 confirmed to be living in Oregon, and almost certainly more. Read the full story: bit.ly/wolves-return #wildlife #animals #oregon #wolves

Day in the life in Za‚Äôatari refugee camp, part IV

Younis and his family are having a meal. "We usually eat two meals a day: breakfast and a late lunch or early dinner. Today we had chicken with potatoes, salad and yogurt. It‚Äôs not my favourite dish but it was good. My favourite thing to eat is mansaf ‚Äì rice with yogurt and meat or chicken. We have that about three times a week. Is there anyone who doesn‚Äôt like mansaf? My mum does most of the cooking and she‚Äôs very good. Tomorrow may be a little different, but it will probably be pretty much the same.‚Äù More at: theguardian.com/world Photo: Sean Smith/The Guardian #News #Syria #Jordan

Day in the life in Za‚Äôatari refugee camp, part III

In a sprawling camp with little to do, the gym is a magnet for young people, and the principal hang out for Younis and his friends. "I come here every day. It‚Äôs also really the only place where me and my friends can meet, so I spend most of the day here from about 11am til 3pm. Back in Syria, I used to meet friends at school and in the gym. Most of the youths here are reckless and there are a lot of fights. It would be good if there was a youth centre where people could meet and become more responsible: a fight here between two kids can quickly spread of their fathers get involved and then the villages and tribes pile in.‚Äù More at: theguardian.com/world Photo: Sean Smith/The Guardian #News #Syria #Jordan

Day in the life in Za‚Äôatari refugee camp, part II

Younis is figuring out what to do with his morning. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve just been to the market to buy rice, chicken, bananas and cooking oil from the local mall. It‚Äôs the first time I‚Äôve been as we have a relative who works there and he normally brings us food. I spent 25 dinars on our E-card. Every member of the family gets 10 dinars a fortnight that are put on the electronic card. It‚Äôs not enough to get everything you need, so people have to spend cash at the stalls in the camp, which are half the price of the mall." More at theguardian.com/world Photo: Sean Smith/The Guardian #Syria #Jordan #News

Day in the life in Za‚Äôatari refugee camp, part one

To mark four years since the start of the #Syria conflict we're devoting a day to the tragedy. Over 200,000 people have died and almost half the population has been uprooted in the biggest refugee crisis since the second world #war. 100,000 people are stuck in the Za‚Äôatari #refugee camp in #Jordan, a desert settlement that has rapidly mushroomed into Jordan‚Äôs fourth largest city. Younis, 19, has lived in the camp for two years. Today, he will walk us through an average day in the camp. More at: theguardian.com/world Photo: Sean Smith/The Guardian

The Guardian picture desk has chosen Turkish photographer Bulent Kilic, of AFP, as our hotly contested agency photographer of the year.

Mount Sinabung #volcano erupts in North Sumatra, #Indonesia, on 8 October 2014. "I was very tired after covering the story for five days. I had just filed some pictures and was looking for a place to eat. While eating, I saw the lava dome fall down. I ran to my motorbike to grab my camera. Without my tripod or cable release with me I struggled to use the table and the camera‚Äôs timer. Local villagers stood around me crying and praying for people‚Äôs safety. I tried to be calm and shot until the low battery warning on the camera came on. I thought I had a good photo and forgot that I was hungry." Photo: Yt Haryono/Reuters

‚ÄúMy son and I spotted smoke, and given #California‚Äôs extreme drought I knew it was not good. We jumped in the car but had only gone a mile when burning ash rained down like falling snow. The rangers and police were ordering a mandatory evacuation and we had to go home to prepare. Then we returned to the Falls area of Bass Lake and I resumed shooting. The picture combines a beautiful #forest reflected in the calm waters, and then slams home the fact that it is being consumed by the #fire. It conveys the sense of awe, horror and feeling of loss I felt while standing there watching the forest burn.‚Äù
Photo: Darvin Atkeson/AP

#Ferguson. Reporters awaiting the arrival of Gov Jay Nixon. He'll speak from this lectern at 5.30pm CT, less than three hours before the Grand Jury decision over whether to prosecute a white police officer over the fatal shooting of the unarmed black teenager Michael Brown.

A lot of #Ferguson is looking like this right now. Store fronts have been boarded up for days in anticipation of the Grand Jury decision over the death of Michael Brown, which we're now expecting in the next couple of hours. You can follow my account here: @paullewisreporter

Keylin Hodges was celebrating his birthday in Cathy's Kitchen in Ferguson when the news came through. The Grand Jury has reached it decision over whether to bring charges against the police officer who shot dead black teenager Michael Brown in August. The decision is expected to be made public later today. Keylin's mom, Pinky, said she'd been shielding her son from all news about the case and associated protests. "Pray it stays peaceful," she said.

You can follow me @paullewisreporter for pictures from Ferguson, which is bracing itself for the possibility of more unrest. #Ferguson

Obama just came to the back of the plane to cancel a scheduled press briefing, claiming his spokesman Josh Earnest deserved a break because it was Halloween. Offered reporters a slice of his chocolate cake instead. Amusing, but odd attitude for someone whose party has an election in four days.
This is a pretty well-drilled schtick by now but there is no really casual way to enter a restaurant when you are the president. "See, I'm real," he says to one diner. @danroberts73 for #guardiancam

My trip covering politics in Louisiana and Georgia ended here, at Dulles Airport. Follow my future travels: @paullewisreporter

Picture by @paullewisreporter. Downtown Atlanta, Georgia. So many volunteers at Democratic Senate candidate #MichelleNunn's headquarters that they've run out of phones. The primary election, that she'll walk, is tomorrow.

Republican Senate candidate Jack Kingston, his barber Tommy Thomas and - in the mirror - me (@paullewisreporter). Kingston granted the Guardian this 7.30am interview - it was the only time I could get him - in Atlanta, Georgia, ahead of tomorrow's tight primary election.

Meet Edwin Edwards, Louisiana's most eccentric, controversial and oldest congressional in November's midterm elections. He served as Louisiana's Governor for a record four-terms but in 2001 was found guilty of fraud, racketeering and extortion. He's 86, and his son, Eli, is nine months old. He sat on his Dad's lap throughout our interview. The man in the picture is also Edwards - or The Silver Fox, as he is know in these parts - in his younger days. Edwards and his third wife, Trina (she's 35-years-old) met when he was in prison. He initially refused to meet her, until she sent him a photo. Eli was conceived using sperm that had been frozen in 1997, when Edwards tried - unsuccessfully - for a child with his second wife, Candy. When I left his home, Edwards shook my hand and whispered: "Try to write something nice." Photo and caption by @paullewisreporter. 
#EdwinEdwards #Louisiana #Politics #Midterms

Flying into Louisiana. A quarter of the oil that fuels America passes through this state. I am here to report on the forthcoming Senate election race which many here believe the Democratic incumbent, Mary Landrieu, risks losing because the Obama administration is not considered sufficiently pro-energy. Pic and caption by @paullewisreporter.

Sitting in the reception area of a swanky downtown law firm #OnlyinColorado
White River national forest in the Colorado Rockies may look peaceful, but the road just west of here was closed yesterday after a state trooper was shot pulling over a car. #guardiancam

It's Europe Day! To celebrate the European Parliament have opened their doors to new ideas from 5000 young people. One of our trainee digital journalists Emma Howard, will be reporting from Strasbourg #EYE2014

Seven months on from devastating flooding, parts of Lyons, Colorado, are still in ruins. Some residents are unable to reach their homes due to destroyed bridges. Two could be seen sleeping in their cars this morning in this street. #guardiancam

One of many still damaged homes in Lyons seven months after the flooding. A neighbour out digging foundations said he had spent four months battling with planning authorities to replace his wrecked basement with a small raised extension. #guardiancam

A group of volunteers from elsewhere in Colorado were in Lyons today to help local authorities cope with vast amounts of detritus from the flooding that even after seven months still litters the river valley. #guardiancam
Storm clouds brewing over Colorado. #guardiancam is in Denver today reporting on the increasingly narrow midterm Senate race and, er, pot.
Supporters of mainstream Republican candidate for Senate Thom Tillis greet news from Associated Press that he has defeated Tea Party backed rival Greg Brannon in the North Carolina primary election.

Weighing up the prospect of the Republican Party establishment taking back control of the party during the primary election night party in Charlotte, North Carolina for mainstream candidate Thom Tillis.

Scene of the lunch counter sit-ins that helped spark the civil rights movement. Museum director Bamidele Demerson tells #guardiancam of ongoing panel discussions on voter suppression and the Affordable Care Act. "Although our exhibition focuses on the efforts of African Americans to dismantle segregation in the 20th century, our programs are both historical and contemporary and help us to envision where we want this society to go," he says.
Just in case I was tempted to steal any hickory to try to recreate Greensboro BBQ back home in DC. #guardiancam
So that's how they make North Carolina BBQ taste so good. This pork is smoke for 12 hours over hickory by three old guys in a hut out back. #guardiancam

Election day in North Carolina is a lot less nerve-wracking if you are a Democrat, whose incumbent senator Kay Hagan is only facing token opposition in today's state-wide primary to pick candidates for November. This is her campaign spokesman Ben Ray showing #guardiancam the delights of Greensboro BBQ.

These students have travelled down from the hills of western North Carolina to support would-be Republican candidate for Senate Greg Brannon. Fired up by his brand of libertarianism, Aaron Littlefield (second from left) is typical of several in the crowd who say they would be unwilling to campaign for GOP establishment favourite Thom Tillis if, as expected, he wins tomorrow's primary election. "There is no passion there," Littlefield tells #guardiancam

54 years ago Clarence Henderson took part in the famous civil rights sit-in at a whites-only Woolworth lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina. Today he is campaigning for the Tea Party candidate for US Senate and describes the Affordable Care Act as another form of government oppression. "Healthcare is nothing more than a way to control the American public," the conservative activist tells an almost exclusively white campaign rally for Greg Brannon. #guardiancam

Senator Rand Paul is out in Charlotte, North Carolina, today campaigning for the Tea Party candidate in tomorrow's primary election. He's behind in the polls to mainstream Republican frontrunner Thom Tillis but Paul doesn't care. "It's a big party," the blue-jeaned libertarian tells #guardiancam regram by @danroberts73

Fighting in Unity, a state of South Sudan, has driven 10,000 people from their homes to the relative safety of Ganyiel, a small town in the south of the Greater Upper Nile region. But river routes have been disrupted by the conflict, reducing the availability of food, and many people have been forced to eat water lilies to survive. Jacob Zocherman has photographed the human toll of the crisis. To see the full gallery, go to theguardian.com/global-development

Photo by @zocherman

Whether they're climbing on them, crawling into them or trying to best them with their claws, pets never seem to live too peacefully with everyday objects. Photographer Mishka Henner has spent many long nights trawling Google Earth in search of oilfields. His work is painstakingly put together: by capturing shots of small areas on Google Earth satellite images he has been able to knit together large-scale aerial views of oilfields across the world. To see more photos, go to theguardian.com/artanddesign

Mishka Henner's work will be shown at Carroll Fletcher Gallery in London until 31 May and in @prix_pictet at the @vamuseum from 22 May to 14 June. Photo by @mishkahenner

Damon Albarn interview: 'Pop's gone back to showbiz. It's like the Beatles or Dylan never happened.' The Blur frontman's first solo album is an introspective affair that delves into childhood, old English ways and heroin use. He explains why it was time to lower his guard in today's Observer. For the full interview, go to theguardian.com/music

Photo by Linda Brownlee

It's the weekend. Time to let your dyed-black hair down, put on your darkest eyeliner and descend like a colony of bats on the unsuspecting residents of Whitby. It's that time of year when gregarious goths gather in the April gloom of the North Yorkshire seaside town. This year the festival celebrates its 20th birthday, having started as a gathering of penpals who met via NME magazine. The organisers chose Whitby as home of the biannual event because of its links with Bram Stoker's Dracula. Getty photographer Ian Forsyth documented the day. Find the full gallery on www.theguardian.com/uk-news

Photo by Ian Forsyth

Photographer @amivitale was allowed exclusive access into the Wolong National Nature Reserve, managed by the China Conservation and Research Centre for the Giant Panda, as it trains pandas to be released into the wild. 
While only about 1,600 giant pandas exist in the wild, the centre has been successful at teaching them to survive by mimicking conditions of their natural habitats. These pictures show the extraordinary lengths the keepers go to with the pandas. Here, a keeper in disguise cleans a panda enclosure under the watchful-eye of a real panda. For the full gallery, go to theguardian.com/world/animals

Photo by @amivitale

Love-hearts and satin sheets, juicy lips and neon hips... Guy Bourdin's erotic images were a staple of French Vogue for more than 40 years ‚Äì and they changed fashion photography forever. As rare offerings from his vast archive go on show for the first time at @parisphotofair in Los Angeles, we published a gallery of some of his boldest and brightest creations. For more, go to theguardian.com/artanddesign

Credit: Guy Bourdin Estate/Louise Alexander Gallery

This was the one pic I got of the President, who was at a Maryland High School to announce the winners of government grants. There were 15 students, boys and girls, all in the 10th grade, and two teachers, gathered around two tables in safety goggles and aprons. It was a microbiology class. Each table contained two microscopes, two laptops, iodine and beakers labeled 'H20'. On the board was written: 'Essential Question: how can patients with pathogenic microbes identify and treat the problem?' The first thing Obama said was: "Hello everybody. This is serious. I'm not going to catch anything by getting too close am I?" He asked the students whether taking this class had encouraged them to consider a career in medicine.

A girl replied in the affirmative. "Oh, you're into the CSI thing," Obama said.

Pic and caption from @paullewisreporter

Last night was one of my favorite #parades: #Bacchus!! Bacchus, in Greek #mythology, was the god of #wine and vegetation. 
This #float is part of the #bacchagator: A Bacchus mainstay for years, the Bacchagator was introduced in the Krewe's 1986 parade. The 105-foot, three piece float can accommodate 86 riders. Originally debuted as green, the float was modified in 1997 to resemble the rare white "leucisitic" #alligator that makes it home at the New Orleans Aquarium of the Americas.  The alligator returned to green in the 2005 parade and remains that way to the present date. #neworleans #stcharlesavenue #guardiancam @lockheedsophie

What the North American press corps looks like if you happen to be a head of state in #toluca about to take some very carefully stage-managed questions. #guardiancam by @danroberts73
I'll say this for #Toluca - it has great courtyards. #guardiancam from @danroberts73

Sadly, much of the North American leaders summit is off limits to journalists who aren't lucky enough to be on one of the reporting pools - leaving several left taking pictures of TV screens while the room is full of business people. It's almost as if they don't want anyone asking awkward questions. #guardiancam @danroberts73

Extending the hand of friendship, or something. Presidents Obama and Pena Nieto pose for the cameras at the start of North American leaders summit in Toluca, Mexico. POTUS declined to answer a question from #guardiancam reporter @danroberts73 on the Ukraine, which oddly is the main topic of concern among White House officials here today.
Waiting for Obama to arrive in the foyer of Toluca city hall and wondering if this building has ever seen quite so much pomp and official nervousness before. #guardiancam @danroberts73

Inside the security cordon however, the historic centre of Toluca is locked down and utterly deserted. Hard to see any anti-government protestors making it anywhere near the North American leaders summit. #guardiancam @danroberts73
Quite astonishing levels of security in the Mexican city of Toluca for North American leaders summit. Heavily armed troops and federal police on every street corner. #guardiancam @danroberts73

The #guardiancam police escort for traveling the five miles or so to the North American leaders summit. There are an estimated 5,000 Mexican police and army and 10,000 security barriers on the streets of Toluca ahead of the arrival of Obama later this morning. Pic by @danroberts73

One press filing room looks much the same as the next, except this one is at 2667m above sea level -an altitude that generates more headaches than that carpet. Tomorrow #guardiancam should be able to escape the hotel and see something of Toluca for the summit of North American leaders. @danroberts73

The summit does not start until Wednesday but the US and Canadian press have just arrived at the hotel in the industrial town of Toluca where the Mexican president grew up. Needless to say, security is absurdly tight. Protests against Mexico's energy policy and education reforms are expected.

Only the rotating pool reporters get to travel on Air Force One sadly so the traveling White House press pack tend to charter a plane for foreign travel. It's actually rather less glamorous than it sounds and looks just like a regular Delta jet but the menus are fun and nothing beats leaving from Andrews Air Force base to avoid the crowds. #guardiancam @danroberts73

The #guardiancam is in warm and sunny Toluca Mexico on Tuesday and Wednesday for a summit of North American leaders. This is the view that Obama is leaving behind. He did spend the weekend in Palm Springs though. Pic and summit coverage by @danroberts73
